and caried: he was plagued, ſmitten, humbled, wounded, and broken: Chaſtiſement, and Stripes. Surely hee hath borne our Infirmities, and carried our Sorrowes, yet wee did iudge him as plagued and ſmitten of God, and humbled, but he was woū ded for our tranſgreſſions, hee was broken for our Iniquities, the chaſtiſement of our peace was vpō him, & with his ſtripes we are healed.

When I ſay the Meanes our Saviour vſed was his Paſſion, I meane not ſo his Paſſion, as if all his Vid. Maſter Deering on the Heb. Lect. 9. p. l. 4. and Mr Fox of Chriſt crucified, p. 51. Life beſides had beene impertinent to that purpoſe, for he was made our Redemption, through the whole courſe of his Life, and what ever hee did was ſomewhat towards the effect of that Redemption. But the holy Scripture attributing cō monly our Redemption to his Death, becauſe that Death of his was the very chiefeſt, and the greateſt worke of all, hence it is I obſerue his Paſſion to be the very true Meanes indeed. Concerning which his Paſſion, ſince the foure Evangeliſts ſo ſufficiently record it in their Writings, & whatſoever they record is oftentimes read vnto you, I ſhall not neede to rehearſe the particulars as being well knowne (I hope) to every of you, only ſomewhat ſhall I ſay of his DEATH, as the very vpſhot of all the reſt. To omit then his heavy Soule, even heavy to the Death, his Agony & bloudy Sweat trickling down vnto the ground: his going forward, and recoyling backe, and going forwards againe, and againe recoyling, almoſt like that of the Poet:
Ovid. Triſt. l. 1 cleg. 3. Ter limen tetigi, ter ſum revocatus, & ipſe
Indulgens animo Pes mihi tardus erat.
As, Mat. 26 39. O my Father if it be poſſible, let this Cup paſſe from me. And againe, Ver. 42. O my Father if this Cup cannot paſſe away from me, but that I muſt drinke it, thy will be done. And againe the third time, O my Father if this Cup cannot paſſe away from me, but that I muſt drinke it, thy will be done. Alas what Ifs were theſe? How almoſt lyable in a vulgar appearance to that of Proſper de vocat. Gent. l. 2. c. 26. p. 344. b.
Proſper, Virtus nolentium nulla eſt:
Not to do a thing willingly is no vertue: almoſt to that of Senec Epiſt. l. 18. ep. 108. Seneca, Malus miles eſt, qui Imperatorem gemens ſequitur: That Souldier is none of the beſt, that marching after his Generall puts finger in the eie: to omit I ſay al this, as alſo Iudas that whoriſh Dalila that betrayed him with a kiſſe: the Vid. Mr Fox of Chriſt crucified. p. 48. b. toſſing of him to and fro, from Annas to Caiphas, from Caiphas to Pilate, from Pilate to Herod, from Herod to Pilate againe: The Quae bona in illa beata vita faciet cos ſumere, pro quibus in hac miſeria vnigenitum ſuū Filium voluit vſ
que
〈◊〉 mortem mal • tanta p • rferre? Aug. de Civit. Dei. l. 22. c. 24. ſpettings in his Mat. 26.67. Face, and buffettings, and vpbraiding him with Propheſie: the putting on him a Mat. 27.28. Scarlet Robe, the very die, and reflex of their bloudy Sinnes: the inveſting him with a Crowne of Thornes, the precious Stones whereof, the clots of his pretious Bloud: a Reed given him inſteed of a Scepter, as if he had beene but a king of Straw: their impoſing his owne Ioh. 19.17. Croſſe vpon his owne Shoulders, who was ſcarcely able to carry himſelfe: Ver. 18. their crucifying him betweene two Theeues, as the moſt notorious Malefactour of all three: Freſh volies of Skornes, and Skofs, as, Mat. 27.40. Thou that deſtroyeſt the Temple, and buildeſt it in three daies, ſaue thy ſelfe: If thou be the Sonne of God come downe from the Croſſe. And againe, Ver. 42. If he be the king of Iſrael, let him now come downe from the Croſſe and we will beleeue him: but nay, nay, He ſaved others, but he cannot ſaue himſelfe. And againe, Ver. 43. He truſteth in God, let him deliver him now if he will haue him. And againe, when as he prayed to God ſaying, Eli, Eli, That is, My God, my God, This man Ver. 47. ſay ſome, calleth Elias: other ſaid, let be: let vs ſee if Elias will come and ſaue him, to omit I ſay all this, and to come to his very Death.

The torments of others when they are violent B. Bilſon of Redemp. p. 7. ſaith a Reverend Prelate of our age, either haſten death, or overwhelme the ſence, and ſo the paine when it is moſt grievous, is least of all perceived. Now concerning our Savior Chriſt there was in him no ſuch thing: he dyed not by Vid. Mr Perkins on the Creed p. 358. degrees as we doe, his ſenſes did not decay, no pangs of death tooke hold of him, but in perfect ſenſe, and perfect patience both of Body and Soule, he voluntarily, and miraculouſly,
as he was praying to his Father, reſigned his Spirit into his Fathers hands. In all men elſe, be the Spirit never ſo willing, & the meaſure of faith never ſo ſtrong, yet vnleſſe it pleaſe God to ſhorten, or lighten the rage of their paine, the Fleſh repineth at the preſent anguiſh, howſoever Grace ſupport the Soule that it ſincke not vnder the burthen: but He
Bernard. de Paſſ. Dom. c. 41. p. 70. ſaith St Bernard, which or cleane taketh away, or lightneth, or ſhortneth the force of torments in his Saints, when they are laid vpon them by their Perſecutours, would not haue his owne paines leſned awhit. He spared not himſelfe, that knoweth how to spare his owne. Now the Manner of rendring his Soule to God, the Scriptures obſerue moſt carefully, and ſo doe the Fathers to. St Iohn in his Goſpell thus Ioh 19.30. deſcribes it: Now when Ieſus had received of the Vinegar, he ſaid, It is finiſhed, and bowed his head, and gaue vp the Ghoſt. Wherevpon St Bernard: It is
Bern. Feria 4a Hebd. Paenoſ. p. 31. col. 2. ſaith he, a great infirmity to die, but to die after ſuch a ſort, argues a power no leſſe then infinite. St Luke Luk. 23.46. reportes that Ieſus cryed with a lowd voice and ſaid, Father, into thy hands I commend my spirit: and when he thus had ſaid, hee gaue vp the Ghoſt. Wherevpon St Ierome obſerues that the Centurion hearing his Prayer, and ſeeing him preſently of his owne accord to ſend forth his Spirit, Moved,
Hier. Quaeſt. ad Hedib. Qu. 8. p. 146. ſaith he, with the greatneſſe of the wonder, he ſaid, truely this man was the Sonne of God. St Auſten obſerving the manner of this his Death thus deſcribed: Who
Aug. in Evan. Ioh. Tract. 119. p. 375. ſaith he, can ſo betake himſelfe to ſleepe when he will, as Chriſt dyed when hee would? who can ſo put of his garment at his pleaſure, as Chriſt put of his fleſh? Who can ſo eaſily remoue from the place hee ſtands in, as Chriſt removed from his life? With how great power ſhall he come to iudge, that ſhewed ſo great power when he dyed. And againe in an other place, His power to die was ſuch
Aug. in Evan. Ioan. Tract. 31. p 172. ſaith he, as that ſome more admired it, then his power of working miracles. Our Saviour himſelfe ratifieth theſe obſervations with his owne mouth: I, Ioh. 10.18. ſaith he, lay downe my life that I might take it againe. No man taketh it from
me, but I lay it downe of my ſelfe: I haue power to lay it down, and haue power to take it againe. The laying downe then of his life was no puniſhment impoſed on him, for Ioh. 8.46. who could rebuke him of ſinne? Nor was it a forcible invaſion of Death, for 1. Cor. 15.56. the ſting of Death is ſinne: but it was a Sacrifice moſt voluntary rendred to God for our ſakes. I, every thing he did, every thing he ſuffred, he voluntarily did it, and voluntarily ſuffred it: Thou
Aug. in Evan. Ioan. Tract. 49. vid. B. Bilſons Survey. p. 355 and p. 526. ſaith St Auſten, art troubled againſt thy will, but Chriſt was troubled becauſe he would. He hungred, ſaith he, it is true, but becauſe he would: he ſlept; it is true, but becauſe he would: he ſorrowed; it is true, but becauſe he would: he died, it is true, but becauſe he would. It was in his power to be ſo, or ſo affected, or not to bee affected at all. And this it is that here in this place the Prophet intimates with ſo many words: He was plagued, ſmitten, humbled, wounded, and broken: Chastiſement and Stripes. Or if Stripes, and Chaſtiſement, and Breaking, and Wounding, and Humbling, and Smiting, and Plaguing, be not ſufficient to expreſſe this Death of his vnto vs, goe we to the ſeaventh verſe of this Chapter, and there ſhall wee finde him, Brought as a Sheepe to the ſlaughter. Or if that be not enough neither, goe we farther to the eight verſe, & there ſhall we finde him, Cut out of the land of the living. Or if that neither be enough, then let vs go to the twelfe verſe, and there ſhall we finde him, Powring out his Soule vnto death, as if ſo be the Prophet had now ſeene (and he ſaw it no doubt with the eies of Faith) that which the Evangeliſt ſaw with his bodily eies, how one of the Souldiers with a ſpeare piercing his Side, there iſſued forth BLOVD, and WATER, Ioh. 19.34.

Why but the Ignorant perhaps wil here reply, to what end & purpoſe is all this? What is it to vs or to any other, if ſo be Chriſt were thus handled? Be it (as you ſay) he never ſinned, & that he dyed guiltleſſe, doth that advantage vs? Yes Beloved, exceeding much, for had not he thus dyed, we had dyed everlaſtingly Body and Soule. Now by
this meanes the wrath of God is wholy appeaſed, the law of God ſatisfied that lay ſo Deut. 27.26 Gal. 3.10. heavie vpon our Shoulders, and Sathan that old Serpent our Adverſary the Divell, he was taken in his owne trap. Muſcipula Diaboli, Crux Domini,
Aug. de Temp. Ser. 174. p 698 ſaith S. Auſten, The Croſſe of our Lord, was a trap to take the Divell in, the Bayt wherewith hee was caught, was the Death of our Lord. It fared a while with the Divell, as it did with Turnus that ſlew Pallas, and was ſo Ioviall therevpon,
Virg. Aeneid. l. 10. Quo nunc Turnus ovat spolio, gaudet
que potitus
who but Turnus now, hauing ſlain his Enemy in the field, but the Poet adds ſhortly after,
Turno tempus erit, magno cum optaverit emptum
Intactum Pallanta, & cum Spolia iſta, Diem
que
Oderit
The time would come whenas Turnus would much repent him of that bargaine, and hate thoſe Spoiles he had, and the very Time he tooke them in, and ſo indeed fell it out with Sathan. This prowd Goliah, this Plaut. Miles. Glor. Act. 4. ſc. Iamne eſt.
Vrbicapus, occiſor Regum, Sacker of Cities, and Queller of Kings, who thought no man in all the world able to match him, found One even in Iſrael, Fleſh of our Fleſh, and Bone of our Bones, not able to match him only, but alſo to Vid. Mr Fox of Chriſt crucified p. 43. b. and p. 46. a. overmaſter him, and to doe as David did by Goliah, with his own Sword to cut of his Head. For Sathā forſooth was ſo greedie to devoure vp all, and every of vs, I meane by Death, as that hee ſwallowed vp ſuch a Morſell as made him caſt vp all that ever he had eaten before. So that as Adam being Lord of Paradiſe, for preſuming vpon ONE FRVIT that was forbidden him by the Lord, loſt his intereſt in all the reſt, which hee might haue enioyed all his life: right ſo Sathan having authoritie giuen him ouer all Sinners throughout the VVorld, for that he ſo far preſumed over ONE that was in truth no Sinner at all, hee forfeited to him ipſo facto all his Authoritie hee formerly had. Thus our Saviour by his Death as it was propheſied
long before, being bruiſed (as it were) by the Divell, did breake the Divels Head. Gen. 3.11. For as if hee had committed but one ſinne, one only ſinne whatſoever, he could never haue recouered himſelfe, but by his Death, and Puniſhment, ſhould haue ſatisfied eternally, even for that one only Sin: ſo being guiltleſſe of committing any, I, the very leaſt that Heart can thinke, all what ever hee did, and ſuffered, was only for our ſakes, even as many of vs as beleeue in him, & endeavour to liue a godly life. And thus much of the third point, namely the Meanes our Saviour vſed in redeeming vs from deſtruction. Now to apply what hath beene ſpoken, and to make it the fitter for our Soules health. Surely he hath borne our Infirmities, and caried our Sorrowes: yet we did iudge him as plagued, and ſmitten of God, & humbled. But he was wounded for our Tranſgreſſions, he was broken for our Iniquities, the chaſtiſement of our peace was vpon him, & with his ſtripes we are healed.

It may ſeeme, doubtleſſe, ſomewhat ſtrange, to ſuch as are converſant in holy Scriptures, that reading there of the Death of any, and finding mention alſo of their Parents, they alwaies finde ſome Items concerning the Sorrowes of thoſe Parents for the death of thoſe their Children: only when wee read of the Death of our Saviour, and how his Bleſſed Mother then was by, wee can finde nothing there of her Sorrow, nor of any moane at all that ſhe made. Stantem lego,
Ambr. de Obitu Valentiniani p. 9. ſaith St Ambroſe, ſtentem non lego. I read how ſhe ſtood by the Croſſe there, but that ſhe wept at all, I read not. Iob, when after thoſe many Meſſages, firſt, of the loſſe of his Oxē: ſecōdly, of his Aſſes; thirdly, of his Sheepe; fourthly, of his Camels; and in every of theſe of his Servants miſcarying; newes was brought him at the length, of the loſſe of his Children too; Then Iob aroſe, Iob. 1.20. ſaith the Scripture, and rent his garment, & ſhaved his head, and fell downe vpon the ground, in all which howſoever he ſinned not, nor charged God fooliſhly, as there
it is Iob. 1.22. ſaid in that place, yet hee ſorrowed no doubt very deepely, as was to be ſeene by theſe Signes. Iacob ſaw but Ioſephs Coat imbrued with blood, and ſuppoſing him to be ſlaine, he rent his cloathes, Gen 37.34. ſaith the Scripture, and put ſackcloth about his loynes, and ſorrowed for his ſonne a long ſeaſon. Thoſe tender Babes in Bethleem that were murthered by Herod, Quibus in primo naſcendi limine, as Aug. de Sanct. Ser 9. one ſpeaketh, aeterna vita obviam venit: whom Life everlaſting did meet (as it were) on the very Threſhold of their Birth, what a voice did they cauſe in Rama, Mat. 2.18. Mourning & weeping, and great lamentation, Rachel weeping for her children, and would not be comforted becauſe they were not. The Prophet David when his Sonne Abſolon died, that wicked and vngratious Sonne, what bitter moane did hee make for him? O my ſonne Abſolon, 2. Sam. 18.33 ſaith hee, my ſonne, my ſonne Abſolon: would God I had died for thee, O Abſolon my ſonn, my ſonne. But come we to our Saviours Death, and caſt we our eyes vpon his Mother, to ſee how ſhe takes it, and all the Evangeliſt will enforme vs concerning her is, that there indeed ſhee was, not a word of her Sorrow for the ſame, though no doubt it was then fulfilled which Simeon ſpake of long before, That a Sword ſhould peirce through her ſoule, Luk. 2.35. It is Tully Orat. ad Brut. & Plin. Hiſt. Nat. l 35. c. 10. ſtoried of a Painter that being to deſcribe how a certaine Damſell was going to her Death (who vpon occaſion was to be ſacrificed) he tooke vpon him to expreſſe it with all the cunning that hee had. One of her Friends that was a Mourner, and to goe in the firſt ranke, he painted, ſaith Tully, with a countenance exceeding ſad, and ſorrowfull. After him there followed a neerer Friend, and his countenance (as it was to be) ſo he made it much more ſad. Next to him followed her Vncle, and him he made the ſaddeſt of all. In ſetting downe of which three Sadneſſes, when he had ſpent al his cunning, and the Father of the Damſell was next to followe, who was in all congruitie, to bee ſadder then all the reſt, the Painter for he could not expreſſe that Sadneſſe, in as liuely
a ſort as it ſhould haue beene, drew a Vaile over his face, as if ſo be his Sorrow had beene ſuch, as that Art it ſelfe, or Pencill, could not poſſibly expreſſe it. I cannot thinke, Beloued, that the Spirit of God did in this reſpect conceale the Sorrow of the Bleſſed Virgin towardes her Son, as vnable to expreſſe it. For what cannot hee expreſſe that diues ſo deepely into our thoughts, as not a corner there, but is diſcloſed to him, Pſal. 139.1. Nay if it bee Plin. Nat. Hiſt. l. 35. c. 10. written of Apelles, that hee would ſeeme to pourtray thoſe things which indeed cannot be pourtraied, as cracks of Thunder leames, or flaſhes of Lightnings, Thūderbolts, & ſuch like, what could not the Spirit of God haue expreſſed, that is ſuch a Diſcerner of our thoughts, and intents of the heart, Heb. 4.12. And would you knowe the reaſon then why her Sorrow here is not expreſſed? It is, as I conceiue, to intimate thereby vnto vs, another point then to be penſiue, and to be ſorry at his Croſſe. It is the maner of Friers, and Ieſuits, as an induſtrious Writer hath Mr Perkins on the Creed p. 251. obſerved, to vſe the conſideration of the Paſſion of Chriſt, as a meanes to ſtirre vp compaſſion in themſelues: partly towards Chriſt, partly towards the Virgin Mary, and withall to kindle in the hearts of their Hearers, an indignation towards the Iews that put our Saviour vnto Death. And indeed to ſay the truth, ſome place there is for this compaſſion, eſpecially towards Chriſt: ſome for this indignation towardes the Iewes, but yet we muſt not here reſt, wee muſt goe farther then ſo, we muſt acknowledge OVR SELVES the very cauſes, of all that ever was done vnto him:
— Virg. Aeneid. l. 9. Mea fraus omnis, nihil iſte nec auſus,
Nec potuit.
They were our owne Sinnes that crucified him: our owne Sinnes they were, that nayled him to the Croſſe. And yet notwithſtanding all this, if wee conſider the caſe aright; that which Tully Tull. ad He
• en. l. 2. ſaid of Teares in generall, Nihil lachryma citius areſoit: Nothing ſooner dryes vp thē Teares, the ſame may be ſaid, and done, concerning our Teares in this
kinde. For vnleſſe our Saviour thus had died, we had died everlaſtingly. Si ille non occideretur,
Aug. de Temp Ser. 174. p. 698 ſaith St Auſten, Mors non moreretur. And therefore St Auſten againe, Hodierno die Dominus noſter pependit in cruce,
Aug. de Temp. Ser. 130. p. 638 ſaith he, & nos epislamur, vt diſcati • quoniam Crux Chriſti Feriae ſunt & Nundinae spiritales. O my Brethren, ſaith S. Auſten, it was vpon this Goodfryday that our Lord did hang vpon the Croſs, and yet we feaſt, and all to learne thereby that the Croſſe of Chriſt is a Ioviall time, and a ſpirituall kind of Mart. And againe in another Aug. de Temp. Ser. 181. p. 706. place, Illuſiones & probra quae pertulit Chriſtus. Crucem, Mortem
que eius non ſuspirijs ingemiſcimus, ſed continuis celebramus laudibus. Thoſe Scoffes & Scornes that Chriſt endured, that Croſſe & Death of his, we doe not bewaile with teares, but laud and celebrate with continuall prayſes.

Rowſe vp thy ſelfe then diſtreſſed Soule, thou that grieveſt, & groaneſt ſo much vnder the Burthen of thy Sinnes: thou whom Sathan hath made to ſee ſo many Horſes and Chariots about thee, whoſe names are LEGION for they are many, and cryeſt out in great agony, Mark 5.9. Alaſſe Maiſter, how ſhall we doe? My anſwere ſhall be vnto thee that of 2. King. 6.16. Eliſha, Feare not, for they that be with vs, are more then they that be with them. Nay CHRIST thus crucified, and CHRIST once crucified but thus, & but one only CHRIST, how is he more then all of them, were they againe as many more. Witneſſe the Apoſtle to the Coloſſians, You Coloſſ. 2.13. ſaith he, which were dead in ſinnes, and in the vncircumciſion of your fleſh, hath he quickned together with him forgiving you all your trespaſſes, and putting out the handwriting of ordinances that was againſt vs, which was contrary to vs, he even tooke it out of the way, and faſtned it vpon the CROSSE, And hath spoyled the Principalities, and Powers, and hath made a ſhew of them openly, & hath triumphed over them in the ſame CROSSE. And againe to the Rom. 8.34. Romanes, Who ſhall lay any thing to the charge of Gods choſen? It is God that iuſtifieth. Who ſhall condemne? It is Chriſt
which is dead, yea or rather which is riſen againe, who is alſo at the right hand of God, and maketh requeſt alſo for vs. And therefore in the words immediatly following, Who Rom. 8.35. ſaith he, ſhall ſeparate vs from the loue of Chriſt? Shall Tribulatiō, or Anguiſh, or Perſecution, or Famine, or Nakednes, or Peril, or Sword? In all theſe things we are more then Conquerours through him that loved vs. For I am perſwaded that neither Death, nor Life, nor Angels, nor Principalities, nor Powers, nor Things preſent, nor Things to come, nor Height, nor Depth, nor any other Creature, ſhall be able to ſeparate vs from the loue of God, which is in Chriſt Ieſus our Lord.

Oh, but thou wilt ſay, this is nothing vnto ME in particular, this is to the Elect in general, but what ſhall I finde in Gods word in particular to My ſelfe? What? But to apply by a true Faith that to thy ſelfe in particular, that which is generally there ſet downe. So the Prophet Eſay, as a Miniſter, to another in particular, Eſay 50.8. Hee is neere that iuſtifieth thee, who will contend with thee? Behold the Lord God will helpe thee, who is he that can condemne thee? So the Apoſtle S. Paule, vnto himſelfe, I liue Gal. 2 20. ſaith he, by the faith in the Sonne of God, who hath loved ME, and given himſelfe for ME. Nay, will you ſee how the ſame Apoſtle applyeth that in particular to any one, which in particular was ſpoken to an other? The place is, Heb. 13.5, where that which was ſaid to Ioſhua, Ioſh. 1.5, As I was with Moſes, ſo will I be with thee: I will not leaue thee, nor forſake thee, the Apoſtle applies to any Hebrew, any Chriſtian whatſoever, Let your converſation ſaith he, be without covetouſneſſe, and be content with thoſe things which yee haue: for he hath ſaid, I will not faile thee, neither forſake thee. To apply then the words of my Text. Are they here ſet downe in generall, Surely he hath borne our infirmities, & carried our ſorrowes: he was wounded for our tranſgreſſions, he was broken for our iniquities, & ſo forth? Heb. 4.2. Mix with Faith but what thou heareſt, and thou maiſt as truely ſay of thy ſelfe in particular,
Surely he hath borne MY infirmities, and carried MY ſorrowes. He was wounded for MY tranſgreſſions, he was broken for MINE iniquities: the chaſtiſment of MY peace was vpon him, and with his ſtripes, I am healed.

But alas to what end and purpoſe ſpeake I now to Diſtreſſed Soules? Where are they? Where liue they? Where may we but heare of ſuch an one? I for my part would honour the ground that ſuch an one treads vpon, I would kiſſe even the ſhadow of ſuch an ones Feet. We may ſee on the contrary a world of hayry Pſal. 68.21. Scalpes that goe on ſtill in their wickednes, that add (as Moſes Deut. 29.19. ſpeakes) Drunkennes vnto Thirſt, that is, Security vnto Sinne, & aſſemble them ſelues by Ier. 5.7. companies in Harlots houſes. To ſuch indeed may I venture to ſpeake, for where are there not ſome ſuch, and therefore even in this Aſſembly ſuppoſing there may be ONE at the leaſt, let me ſingle him out in a word, or two, be it at his owne choice to be bettered by it.

When Iſrael Pſal. 114.1. ſaith the Pſalmiſt, came out of Egypt, & the houſe of Iacob from among the ſtrange people, the Sea ſaw that and fled, Iordan was driven backe. The mountaines leaped like Rams, and the little hils like young ſheepe. Wherevpon the Pſalmiſt beginning to reaſon with them, What ayleth thee, O thou Sea, that thou fleddeſt? And thou Iordan, that thou waſt driven backe? Yee mountaines that yee skipped like Rams, and yee little hils like young ſheepe? The anſwere there is, as it is in one of our Engliſh Bible printed 1608. Trāſlations, Pſal. 114.7. The earth trē bled at the preſence of the Lord, at the preſence of the God of Iacob. Aske in like māner, oh thou Miſcreant, aske of that greater Light of heaven, why at the death of IESVS he became ſo farre eclypſed, as that he was nothing like his wonted ſelfe whē he ſo much Pſal. 19.5. reioiced to run his courſe, and will not he tell thee of like preſence of the ſelfe ſame Lord, & God of Iacob, & how he then died on the Croſſe? Will not he tell thee, that the ſame Ieruſalē which IESVS had Pſal. 48.2. crowned with ſuch Glory, that it was the ioy of the whole Earth, crowned him againe with thorns? That that
People which IESVS Exod. 12.36 laded with ſpoyles out of Egypt, ſpoiled him of the Robes he wore? That they for whō IESVS Pſal. 106.9. dryed vp the red Sea, to lead them through the Deep as through a wildernes, dryed vp the Ocean of his bloud by ſpilling it on the ground? That they whom in the daie time IESVS Pſal. 78.15. led with a clowd, and all the night through, with a light of fire, conſpired againſt him by day, and in the night came with Ioh 18 3. Mat. 26.55. Lanterns, and Torches, and Weapons, as if they had come to take a Thiefe? That IESVS who rained downe Pſal. 78.24. Manna for them, and made them bread of the wheat of heaven, had from them, and by their meanes Ier. 11.19. Vulg. Wood mingled with his bread? That IESVS who gaue to them water out of the very Num. 20 11. Rocke, had Mat. 27.48. Vinegar and Gall given him againe by way of amends? Exceeding great Ingratitude, and as a Body would thinke vnmatchable, and yet ſee, oh ſee, thou Dan. 13.56. Seed of Canaan, and not of Iuda, whether thy Ingratitude towards him be not more by much, much more. For they for their parts knew not, no they knew not what they did, our Saviour himſelfe did beare thē witnes, Father, Luk. 23.34. ſaith he, forgiue them, for they know not what they doe: & had they knowne it 1. Cor. 2.8. ſaith the Apoſtle, they would not haue crucified the Lord of glory: but thou canſt not be ignorant, how thou doeſt crucifie him Heb. 6.6. againe. They did it then, & at that time when as his Glory was not known, and the Pſal. 2.2. Kings of the earth ſtood vp againſt him, and the Rulers tooke counſell togither: thou when Kings are his nurſing Eſay 49.23. Fathers, and Queenes his Nurſes. They did it then, and at that time when they had not yeelded him any alleageance, nor caſt downe their crownes before him, thou after thou haſt beene named with that moſt ſacred name of a CHRISTIAN, and haſt beene obliged to him by Baptiſme. But what doe I ſpeake to ſuch Beloved, as if ſuch were now preſent. Such were I ſure were here, I would ſpeake vnto them as this our Prophet doth to their like in his time: Eſay 1.10. Heare the word of the Lord oh Princes of Sodom, hearken vnto the law of our God,
oh People of Gomorrah. Such wete I ſure were here, I woulde ſpeake vnto them as the Prophet Ieremy doeth, Ier. 25.27. Drinke, and be drunken, and ſpew and fall, and riſe no more, becauſe of the ſword which the Lord will ſend among you. Such were I ſure were here, I would ſpeake in the wordes of the Prophet Habakkuk: Habak 2.15. Woe vnto him that giveth his Neigbour drinke: thou ioineſt thine heate, and makeſt him drunken alſo, that thou mayſt ſee their privities. Thou art filled with ſhame for glory: drinke thou alſo and be made naked: the cup of the Lords right hand ſhalbe turned vnto thee, and ſhamefull spewing ſhall be for thy glory. But for in truth I am perſwaded that there are no ſuch here in this Audience, let me now come to you that are here, and ſee what vſe our ſelues may make, of all that hitherto hath beene ſpoken.

Wee haue heard then out of this Scripture the Summe of the Whole Bible, even of the Old, and New Teſtament, to wit, CHRIST IESVS, and him CRVCIFIED: or to ſpeake in the Apoſtle St Pauls Coloſſ. 1 20, phraſe, Sanguinem Crucis, THE BLOVD OF THE CROSSE. We haue ſeen what our Saviour hath done for vs many hundred yeares agoe before that ever we were borne. How the blood of IESVS CHRIST doth 1 Ioh. 1.7. cleanſe vs from all ſinne. St Peter ſpeaking of this his Croſſe, and how our Saviour bare our Sins in his Body on the tree, inferreth immediatly after: That we, 1. Pet. 2.24. ſaith he, being delivered from ſinne, ſhould liue in righteouſneſſe. So Zacharias, Iohn Baptiſts Father, but he goeth one ſtep farther, That wee, Luk. 1.74. ſaith he, being delivered out of the hands of our enemies, ſhould ſerue him without feare all the daies of our life, in holineſſe and righteouſnes before him. So the Apoſtle vnto Titus, and hee adds one thing more then Zacharias did. The grace of God, Tit. 2.11. ſaith he, that bringeth ſalvation vnto all men, hath appeared, and teacheth vs that we ſhould denie vngodlineſſe, and worldly luſts, & that we ſhould liue ſoberly, and righteouſly, and godly in this preſent world. All comes to one reckning, and you ſee, Beloved,
withall, the true vſe we are to make of this CROSSE of CHRIST ſo much ſpokē of. If ſo be we make a B. Andrews Sermons of the combate betweene Chriſt & Satan. Ser. 5. pag. 68. b & Ser. 7 p 95. Dungcart of it to lade it every day with Sinnes, groſſe and enormous Sinnes, and the next time it is brought vnto vs, to haue as much more for it againe, and all for it hath rid vs ſo well already, we much miſtake this CROSSE of CHRIST, nor is it giuen vs to ſuch purpoſe. The Mercies of God are great, but his Iudgements are great too. If after deliverance from Sinne (the effect of this his CROSSE, and which principally wee obtaine in receauing the holy Sacrament) we liue not In righteouſneſſe, as ſpeaks S. Peter, or ſerue him not In Holineſſe, and Righteouſneſſe, as Zacharias ſpeakes, or liue not Soberly, and Righteouſly, & Godly, as ſpeakes the Apoſtle S. Paule, Soberly in regard of our ſelues, Righteouſly in regard of our Neighbours, Godly in regard of our Saviour, well may wee talke of this his CROSSE, but wee ſhall bee benefitted by it never awhit. Howſoever it proue to others, doubtleſſe to vs it may proue but a Dreame. An hungry man dreameth, Eſay. 29.8. ſaith this our Prophet, and behold he eateth, and when he awaketh his ſoule is emptie: a thirſtie man dreameth, and loe hee is drinking, and when he awaketh, behold, he is faint, & his ſoule longeth. Right ſo in this caſe; They ſuppoſe all is well, Come, Wiſd. 2.6. ſay they, let vs enioy the pleaſures that are preſent, and let vs cheerefully vſe the creatures as in youth. Let vs fill our ſelues with costly wine, and oyntments, and let not the floure of life paſſe by vs? Let vs crowne our ſelues with Roſe buds afore they be withered. Let vs all bee partakers of our wantonneſſe: let vs leaue ſome token of our pleaſure in every place: for that is our portion, and this is our lot: our Saviour hath paid al the Shot; And ſo they betake themſelues at length to Sleepe, even to their Dead ſleepe. But when the Trumpe ſhal awake them at laſt with this, or the like ſound, Behold the Bridegroome commeth, Mat. 25.6. the Fooliſh Virgins can tell thē how they themſelues ſped in like caſe. Mat. 25.11. Lord, Lord, open to vs, was but ſilly Rhetoricke to perſwade that
the Doares of Heaven ſhould be opened. Nor ſhall they ſpeed a whit better, who ſhall vſe more wordes to that purpoſe, Many, Mat. 7.22. ſaith our Saviour, will ſay vnto me in that day, Lord, Lord, haue wee not by thy Name propheſied? and by thy Name caſt out Divells? and by thy Name done many great workes? And then, ſaith our Saviour, will I profeſſe to them, I never knewe you: depart from mee yee that worke iniquitie. Let vs not flatter then our ſelues in our Sinnes. Excellent are the words which the Sonne of Syrach hath, and worthy to be written in letters of gold: Say not I haue ſinned, and what evill hath come vnto me? Ecclus. 5.4. for the Almightie is a patient rewarder, but hee will not leaue thee vnpuniſhed. Becauſe thy ſinn is forgiuen, be not without feare to heap ſin vpon ſin. And ſay not the mercy of God is great, he wil forgiue my manifold ſinnes: for Mercy & Wrath come frō him, & his indignation commeth downe vpon Sinners. It is ſomewhat ſhorter which hee hath in another Ecclus, 7.8. place, but it is as effectuall to the purpoſe, Bind not two ſinnes together: for in one ſinne ſhalt thou not be vnpuniſhed. True it is, it is very true, that Chriſt Ieſus came into the world to ſaue Sinners, the Apoſtle St Paule 1. Tim. 1.15. ſaith it of him, I, he ſaith it of himſelfe, The ſonne of man, Luk. 19.10. ſaith he, is come to ſeeke, and to ſaue that which was loſt, and therefore he preferred whē time was, the Luk. 18 14. Publican, before the Phariſee, Luk. 7 44. Mary Magdalen before Simon, Luk. 15.23. banquetted his Prodigall Sonne more ſumptuouſly then his ever obedient Brother: Luk 15.5. carried on his owne Shoulders his loſt Sheep, Luk. 15.8. lookt moſt narrowly for his loſt Groat, Mat. 20.10. requited their Paines with equall Wages that came to worke at vnequal Houres: in a word, that Mat. 18.22. taught S. Peter that moſt Chriſtian Arithmetike (and therefore himſelfe no doubt was moſt expert in it) of Multiplying Seaven Times, by ſeaventie times ſeaven times, in forgiving his Chriſtian Brother: and yet is that as true which the Apoſtle hath to the Hebrews, and ought eſpecially to be heeded by vs, Heb. 12.28. Let vs pleaſe the Lord with reverence & feare, for even our God is a conſuming Fire. He
is not now as hee was to the Buſh, Exod. 3.2. The buſh burned with fire, and the buſh was not conſumed: no, For behold, the day commeth that ſhall burne as an oven, and all the proud, yea, and all that doe wickedly ſhall be ſtubble, and the day that commeth ſhal burne them vp, ſaith the Lord of hoſts, and ſhall leaue them neither root nor branch, Malachy 4.1. As ſoone as Sinne then begins to ſprout in vs, bee it but (as it were) a dram of Pride, a thought of Pleaſure, a deſire of Revenge, or vnlawful Gaine, &c: let vs doe as was to be done to the Pſ. 137.9. Children of the Daughter of Babylon, even take them, and throw them againſt the Stones. Dum parvus eſt hoſtis,
Hier. ad Euſtoch. de Inſt. Virg. ſaith S. Ierom, interfice: ne zizania creſcant, elidatur in ſemine: Let vs ſtrangle Sinne while it is but a Brat, leaſt if we ſuffer it ſtill to grow, in continuance of time it ſtrangle vs. It was a wiſe ſaying of Ʋlyſſes in the Senec. Treas Act 3. ſc. Matris quidem. Poet,
Matris quidem me moeror attonitae movet,
Magis Pelaſgae me tamen Matres movent,
Quarum iſte magnos creſcit in luctus puer.
Right ſo, Beloved, ſay to COVETOVSNES; Of a trueth thou moveſt me ſomewhat, in that thou doeſt promiſe vnto me ſuch heaps both of Silver, and of Gold, yet our Saviours words mooue me Mat. 16.26. more, What ſhall it profit a man though he ſhould winne the whole world, if he looſe his owne Soule? So likewiſe vnto PLEASVRE; Of a truth thou moveſt me ſomewhat, thy Beauty is ſo pleaſing, & I well remember Solomon Prov. 9.17. ſaith, Stollen waters are ſweet, & hid bread is pleaſant: but foraſmuch as hee addeth withall, That the Dead are there, & That her Gueſts are in the depth of Hel: packe hence, be gone, for out of Hell is no Redemption. So likewiſe to CAROWSING; Of a truth thou moveſt me ſomewhat, thy Cuſtome is now a daies growne ſo great, howbeit ſince the Prophet Eſay Eſay 5.11. ſaith, Woe vnto them that riſe vp earely to follow drunkenneſſe, and to them that continue vntill night, til the wine doe inflame them: And Ver. 22. againe, Woe vnto them that are mighty to drinke wine, and
to them that are ſtrong to poure in ſtrong drinke: let them follow their Liquor that liſt, I ſhall be rather of their Society, Pſal. 35.9. Vulg. Qui inebriabūtur ab vbertate Domus tuae: et Pſal. 36.8. Torrēte voluptatis tuae potabis eos: who ſhall bee ſatiſfied with the plenteouſneſſe of thy Houſe, O Lord, and to whome thou ſhalt giue drinke of thy Pleaſures, as out of the River.

Concerning Sins already paſt, you ſee what God hath now done for you. He hath not only forgiven them to you, vtterly wiped them away, but this Day as many as would, he hath admitted to his TABLE. He hath given you there his beſt Welcome. Thouſands of his deare Children are this day deſirous of the entertainment you haue had, and what in one reſpect, what in an other, they cannot obtaine it, no not with teares. Happy we, if we knew our Happyneſſe. But if ſo be we now returne againe as doth the 2. Pet. 2.22. Dogge to his owne Vomit, or as the Sow that was waſhed, to the wallowing in the mire, our ſtate is dā gerous, our caſe fearefull. St Auſten ſpeaking of the Dog, Si Canis,
Aug. in Pſal. 83. p. 630. ſaith he, hoc faciens horret oculis tuis, tu quid eris oculis Dei? If thou abhorreſt to ſee a Dog to doe ſo beaſtly in thy ſight, imagine what thou thy ſelfe art, if ſo bee thou ſhouldſt ſo doe, in the ſight of God. But enough now at this time.
div.closer: The God of Heaven ſo bleſſe vs, and the ſeed that hath beene ſowen, &c.

div.head: OVR SAVIOVRS RESVRRECTION.

p.hi: But now is Chriſt riſen from the dead, & was made the first fruits of them that ſlept. For ſince by man came death, by man came alſo, the reſurrection of the dead.

div.p:
THE compariſon is not vneven, Right Worſhipfull, and dearely Beloved, which that golden mouthed Father St Chryſoſtom doth make, betweene St Paule, & that glorious Sunne in the Firmament. The Pſalmiſt ſpeaking of that Sun: It commeth forth, Pſal. 19.5. ſaith he, as a Bridegroome out of his chamber, & reioyceth as a Gyant to runne his courſe. It goeth forth from the vttermost part of the heaven, and runneth about vnto the end of it againe, and there is nothing hid from the heat thereof. And St Chryſoſtom ſpeaking of S. Paule, The Apoſtle S. Paul,
Chryſ. Tom. 3. ele laud. D. Pauli. Hom. 8. ſaith he, is vnto men as it were a ſecond Sunne, who with the radiant Beames of his Tongue hath illightned the whole World, and compaſſing about all Nations hath followed the courſe of the Sunne indeed. Which that we may conceiue the better, let vs compare more at large the Sun, & St Paule togither. Firſt then for the Creating of this Sun, we ſhall finde it in the ninth Chapter of the Acts when
like that other Sun in the firmament being produced out of darknes, there fell from his eies as it had beene ſcales, and ſuddainely he received ſight, and roſe, and was baptiſed, Act. 9.18. The riſing of this Sunne was in the thirteenth of the Acts, & yonder Sunne as it riſeth to vs, when it appeareth aboue our Caſtle of knowledge. p 54. Horizon: ſo aroſe the Apoſtle St Paule aboue the Horizon of the Church, when as it was ſaid vnto the Church by the mouth of the Holy Ghoſt, Separate me Barnabas and Saul, for the worke wherevnto I haue called them, Act. 13.2. The way whereby the Sunne goeth is called by Aſtronomers the Zodiacke, in the which are twelue Signes, which being divided into foure Triplicities, ſquare out into foure partes, the foure Seaſons of the Yeare. The Signes, (as it were) in our Apoſtles Zodiacke, were the Regions of the world, which himſelfe dividing into as many parts as are the Seaſons of the Yeare, in viſiting every of them he made (as it were) foure Moſis Pſtacheri Analyſ. Typ. p 546. &c. Travailes. His firſt Travaile is compriſed in the 13. and 14. Chapters of the Acts: his Second, in the 15, 16, 17, and part of the 18. Chapter: his Third, from part of the 18. to the 26: his fourth, & laſt, in the 27, and 28. being the two laſt Chapters of that Booke. The Degrees (if I may ſo tearme them) of every of theſe Signes, or (to ſpeake a little more plainely for the capacity of ſome among you) the Places through which he paſt in every of theſe his Travailes, were in his firſt Travaile, Selcucia, Cyprus, Pamphylia, Antioch in Piſidia: & his more ſpeciall Places of aboad, were Iconium, and Lyſtra. The places through which he paſſed in his ſecōd Travaile, were Syria, Silicia, Aſia minor, and Greece: and the more ſpecial Places of his aboad were Theſſalonica, Beraea, Athens, Corinth, and Epheſus. The Places through which he paſt in his third Travaile, were Galatia, Phrygia, & Greece againe: and the more ſpeciall Places of his aboad, were Epheſus againe, Macedonia, Troas, Aſſos, and Miletum: from whence returning by Coos, Rhodes, Phaenicia, Tyrus, Ptol • mais, Caeſarea, and ſo forth, he arrived at length at
Ieruſalem. The places through which he paſt in his fourth and laſt Travaile were Sidon, Cyprus againe, Mira, Gnidus and Creet, and the moſt ſpeciall Place of his aboad was Rome. And at Rome this Sun did ſet, even as the Sunne ſets at his going downe, being (as Antiquitie deliuers to vs) beheaded at Rome the ſelfe ſame day that St Peter there was crucified. Then was Peter,
Tertul Scorg. adverſ Gnoſt. p 615. ſaith Tertullian, girded by another, whenas he was girded to the Croſſe. Then was Paule a freeman borne of the City of Rome indeed, when by the nobilitie of Martyrdome, he was borne (as it were) againe. And ſpeaking in another place of the Church of Rome: Where Peter,
Tertul de Praeſcript. adverſ. Haeret. p. 83. ſaith he, was crucified like to our Saviour Chriſt, & Paul beheaded like Iohn the Baptiſh.

Now Greece, Beloved, being one of the Places which this our Apoſtle paſt in his ſecond Travaile, and Corinth in that his Travaile, one of the more ſpeciall Places of his aboad, wee ſhall finde in the 18 Chapter of the Acts, both from whence it was he thither came, and what it was hee there did, and how long it was he there ſtaid. The Place he came from, was ATHENS the moſt famous place in all Greece. Athens, the Greece of Greece, as Thucyd Hiſt. l. 1. one calls it; the Grecian Veſta, as Coel. Rhodig. l. 18 c. 25. another; The Sunne, the Soule of Greece, as a Demoſth de Cor. third; Athens, the common ſchoole of Mankind, for ſo Diodor. Sic. Biblioth. Hiſt. l 12. Diodorus Siculus tearmes it; Athens,
Philo Iud. lib Quod omnis probus liber ſaith Philo Iudaeus, the ſame in Greece, that the Apple is in the Eye, or Reaſon in the Mind; Athens within whoſe Wals the only wits of Greece were incloſed, ſo Paterculus; In a word, Athens was as OXFORD is, an Vniverſitie, and a City. What it was he did at Corinth, is related by himſelfe in divers paſſages of this Epiſtle. He for his part there 1 Cor. 3.6. planted,
Vell. Paterc. l 1. that is as Aug ep 48 p. 122 S. Auſten vnderſtandeth it, hee did there Evangelize, there it was Apollos watered, that is, as the ſame Father interpreteth it, there Apollos did baptiſe, Sed Deus incrementum dedit, but God gaue the increaſe. According to the grace of God giuen vnto him, as a 1. Cor 3. • 0. skilfull Maſter Builder he there laid the Foundation. 1. Cor. 4.15. In Chriſt Ieſus he beget
them through the Gospell. They were his worke in the Lord, and had he not beene (as himſelfe 1. Cor. 9.1. writes) an Apoſtle vnto other, yet doubtleſſe he was vnto them, for they were the ſeale of his Apoſtleſhip in the Lord. The aboad hee made in this Citie was ſomewhat longer then vſually hee made in other places, it being ſome Twelue month & an halfe: ſoiourning at the firſt with Aquila, & Priſcilla, of whome he ſpeakes in divers places: and afterwards with one Iuſtus, who dwelt Act. 18.7. neerer to the Church then they did.

Having thus long ſtaid among them, and gone at laſt from thence (& cauſe there was he ſhould be gone, for he was as the Sun I told you, not alwaies fixed in one place) then Sathan, loe, began his prizes, he made havock of the Flocke, he 1. Cor. 3.3. ſent in Envying, he ſent in Strife, he ſent in Cō tentions, and Diviſions among them. And as they that are once going downe a ſteepe Hill, cannot poſſibly ſtay thē ſelues till they come to the very bottome: ſo theſe Corinthians forgetting their old Inſtructor, and wholy addicted now to New, came at length to that downefall as that they ſtucke not to call in queſtion (nay more then to call) the very cheefeſt Article of Chriſtian beleefe, THE RESVRRECTION OF THE DEAD. Some
Vid. Chryſ. in 1. Cor. 15. Hom. 38. p. 625. affirming that it was not at all; ſome that it was already paſt; & ſome that it concern'd not the Body ſo much as the Renuing of the minde, into ſo many wandring Errors did they wofully caſt themſelues, who ſo wilfully forſooke that Path that the Apoſtle at firſt trod out vnto them.

The Apoſtle, who vpon this Newes was by all likelyhood much daunted, and well perceauing that if he helpt not in time, it would be the hazard of ſo many Soules, betakes himſelfe vnto his PEN, and Quod voce nō poterat Manu & Literis eſt locutus Ambr. in Luc. 1.2. de Zacharia Evā gelizo manu & ſcriptione quoad poſſum. Dr Reyn. de Idol. Eccl. Rom Ep. ad Com. Eſſex, preacheth now vnto them by way of Writing, that he who in former times by the high Priſts Letters had ſo much perſecuted the Chriſtians, might by Letters of his owne, indeavour as much as might be, to preſerue them againe in all good ſort.

Among his ſeveral Letters to this purpoſe, ſome foureteene
in all, is this Epiſtle of his to the Corinthians written vnto them from Philippi. Wherein after ſundry paſſages of a many matters he had in hand. As firſt and formoſt in the foure firſt Chapters, concerning the Schiſmes that were among them: in the Fift, concerning the inceſtuous Perſon: in the Sixt, concerning their quarrels: in the Seaventh, concerning Queſtions about Mariage and Virginitie: in the Eight, concerning things that were offered vnto Idols: in the Ninth, concerning the weake Brethren: in the Tenth, concerning Puniſhments that befel the Iſraelites for ſinne, and might in time befall themſelues too: in the Eleventh, concerning their behaviour in their publike Aſſemblies, and Congregations, and Adminiſtration of the Sacraments: in the Twelfe, Thirteenth, and Foureteenth, concerning Spirituall Gifts: he commeth in this Fifteenth Chapter (from whence the words of my Text are takē) to the grand Queſtion of all, concerning the Reſurrection of the Dead, which vntil he commeth vnto my Text, he hādleth in this manner.

Firſt, and formoſt, he makes a Preamble, and that in the firſt, and ſecond Verſes. Secondly he proues by many Reaſons the Reſurrection of the dead: two of them before my Text, foure, come after. The Firſt he proues it by, is by the example of our Saviour, and it is in this Chapter from the third verſe to the eighteenth, and it is in effect thus much: If there be no Reſurrection of the dead, then was Chriſt not raiſed from the dead: but Chriſt is raiſed from the dead, therefore is there a Reſurrectiō. The Second reaſon is in the nineteenth Verſe, & the Summe of it is this: If ſo bee Chriſtians in this life only, doe hope in Chriſt, then are they of all men the moſt miſerable: but Chriſtians are not miſerable, much leſſe of all men the moſt miſerable, therefore in this life onely, they hope not in Chriſt, and conſequently they are to riſe againe from the dead, that they may bee partakers of that Hope concerning the Life that is to come.

Being thus farre on his way, he turnes a little aſide to
the better confirming of that which hee had deliuered a little before. Hee had delivered a little before, namely in the ſixteenth verſe (and it was part of the firſt Reaſon hee had made) that if ſo bee there were no Reſurrection of the dead, thē that Chriſt was not raiſed at all. He now aſſumes that Chriſt is raiſed, and it is the whole ſcope of this my Text, & whereof I ſhall God willing entreat at this time, But now is Chriſt riſen from the dead, and was made the firſt fruits of them that ſlept, for ſince by man came death, by man came alſo the Reſurrection of the dead.

Which words, were I to handle before the Learned only, ſuch as ſome of you are, that here are preſent, I would obſerue out of the ſame theſe ſeverall parcels to be conſidered: Firſt, a Propoſitiō: Secondly, the Reaſon of that Propoſition. The Propoſition in theſe wordes: Chriſt is riſen from the dead, and was made the firſt fruits of them that ſlept. The reaſon in theſe, For ſince by man came death, by man came alſo the Reſurrection of the dead. In the Propoſition I would obſerue theſe points, Firſt, the Matter, then the Maner. The Matter in theſe wordes: But now is Chriſt riſen from the dead. The Manner in theſe, And was made the first fruits of them that ſlept. In the Reaſon I would obſerue theſe points, Firſt the Antecedent, Secondly the Conſequent. The Antecedent in theſe words, Man, and Death: the Conſequent in theſe, Man, and the Reſurrection of the dead: Rom. 1.14. 1. Cor. 3 1. but being a many of you as you are, and my ſelfe being a Debtor to the Wiſe, and to the Vnwiſe, to ſuch as are Strong in Chriſt, and to ſuch as are Babes, I will betake my ſelfe to a plainer Method, ſuch as the meaneſt of you may conceaue, namely firſt by diſcourſing of the words of this my Text as here they lye in order, and then by gathering thence ſuch Inſtructions as the ſame ſhall afford vnto vs. Firſt and formoſt then as touching the Words: But now is Chriſt riſen from the dead.

Who it is, is meant by Chriſt here, the meaneſt amongſt vs is not ignorant of. Our very Beliefe informes vs of him
when even in our Infancie we learne to ſay, And in Ieſus Chriſt his only Sonne, our Lord. Beſides that afterwardes when we come to greater groath wee make not a Prayer or in the Church, or in our private houſes at home, but the Concluſion you know is, either in ſo many words, or in ſenſe, Through Ieſus Chriſt our Lord. The ground whereof, is that of our Saviour, Ioh. 16.23, Verely, verely, I ſay vnto you, whatſoever yee ſhall aske the Father in my name he will giue it you. And againe, Aske and you ſhall receiue, that your ioy may be full, Ioh. 16.24. Howbeit all of vs that aske in Chriſt his name, doe not all perhaps know why our Saviour was named Chriſt. The word in truth is a Greeke word, and ſignifies Annointed. Now as among the Iewes before the comming of our Saviour three ſortes of men were annointed with oile, as Saul and David. 1. Sam. 10.1. & 1. Sam. 16 13. PRINCES, Aaron, and his Sonnes. Exod. 30.30. & Levit 8.12. PRIESTS, and Eliſha the Prophet, 1 King 19.16. PROPHETS, Vid. P. Mart. Loc Com. Claſſ. 2. Loc. 17. partly to ſignifie the great Conflicts they were every of them to indure, partly the plentifulneſſe of Gods Spirit, that by that annointing was given vnto thē: right ſo Beloved, our Saviour himſelfe being annointed by the Lord, Firſt to be our PROPHET, Secondly to be our PRIEST, & Thirdly to be our PRINCE, had therevpon this name Chriſt, that is, Annointed, given vnto him. He was a Prophet, I, A Great Prophet, Luk. 7.16. He was a Prieſt, I, An High Prieſt, Heb. 5.5. He was a Prince, I, A Prince for ever, Luk. 1.33. The time he was thus annointed in, was the time of his Conception, even before he was borne, & therefore he was no ſooner borne, but an Angel Luk 2.10, ſaid vnto the Shepheards, Behold, I bring you tidings of great ioy that ſhal be to all the People: that is, that vnto you is born this day, in the City of David a Saviour which is Chriſt the Lord. So that this Annointing though it were not with material oile, yet was he annointed notwithſtanding. The Lord annointed him, Eſay, 61.1. & God, evē his God, hath annointed him with the oile of gladnes aboue his Fellows, Pſ. 45.8. And thus much of Chriſt here in this place, now cōcerning the Wordes annexed. But now is Chriſt riſen from the dead.

This word Now, here in this place Muſc. in hunc loc. ſaith a learned Interpreter, Non temporis habet connotationem, ſed praemiſſae argumentationis concluſionem, betokens not the time whē this Reſurrection was performed, but the Concluſion of the Reaſon that was made a little before. I told you the Reaſon was, If there be no Reſurrection of the dead, then was Chriſt not raiſed from the dead: but Chriſt is raiſed from the dead, therefore is there a Reſurrection. The Aſſumption which in ſome reſpect may be called the Concluſion of the former Reaſon, is here ſet downe in the words of my Text, and therefore the Apoſtle here in this place, But now is Chriſt riſen from the dead, without any reference to the time at all, like as he ſaith elſewhere, Now then there is no condemnation to them that are in Chriſt Ieſus, Rom. 8.1. And thus much of theſe words, But now is Chriſt. It followeth, Riſen from the dead.

The riſing of our Savior Chriſt from Death to Life, doth argue that he paſt whē time was, from Life to Death. The time he paſt in from Life to Death, was (as it were) three daies ſince, when on GOOD-FRIDAY, as we commonly cal it (Good for vs indeed, though never Day more diſmall to that Prophet, and Prieſt, and Prince of ours, if we reſpect his manifold Sorrowes in it) when on Goodfryday I ſay, he humbled himſelfe, and became Philip. 2.8. obedient vnto the death, even the death of the Croſſe. When to ſpeake in St Bernards
Bernard de Paſſione c. 17. words, The incomprehenſible God, would needs be comprehended; the highest, humbled; the moſt mighty, despiſed; the moſt beautiful, deformed; the moſt wiſe, be like a beaſt; the immortall would ſuffer death; and to speake all in few wordes, when God would become a worme. What is higher then God, ſaith he, what is baſer then a worme? Howbeit as Moſes ſaid to the Children of Iſrael when they were environed with their Enemies, & they ſaw nothing at all but Death, Death before them, and Death behinde them, and Death on each ſide, Exod. 14.13. Feare yee not, ſtand ſtill, and behold the ſalvation of the Lord, which he will ſhew to you this day: right ſo
Beloved, let vs not feare at what hath beene ſaid concerning our Saviour, but behold the Salvation of the Lord which he hath ſhewed vnto vs this day. This Day, this very Day, our Saviour reſtored himſelfe to Life againe, 1. Cor. 15.54. Death was ſwallowed vp into Victory. He that ſpake to the Fiſh, and it caſt vp Ionas, ſpake to the Earth, and it caſt vp Ieſus. Whom God Act. 2.24. ſaith St Peter, raiſed vp, and looſed the ſorrowes of death, becauſe it was vnpoſſible that he ſhould be holden of it. Praedixit
Bernard in Paſc. Ser. 1. ſaith St Bernard, & revixit: hee told vs before that ſo it ſhould be, and ſo indeed it came to paſſe. Vid. My Lord of Lond on Ionas, Lect. 30. p, 411. The Earthquake at the very time of his Reſurrection; the teſtimony of Angels; his manifeſtation to his Diſciples, to one, to two, to twelue, to more then fiue hundred at once; his breaking of bread amongſt them; the prints of his Hands and Sides; their fingers and nailes even thruſt in his Sides; his appearing at laſt to him who did moſt of all misbeleeue it, the Writer of this Epiſtle, are all ſufficient Witneſſes of the truth of this matter. Quid expreſſius at
que ſignatius,
Tertull. de Reſurrect. carnis, p. 34. ſaith Tertullian, in hanc cauſam, aut cui alij rei tale documentum? What can be alleaged for better proof in behalfe of the cauſe we haue in hand, what other thing hath ever been better cōfirmed to vs? So that as Tully
Tully Orat. pro Q. Roſc. Com. ſaid in Roſcius his caſe, Hoc ego loco, ſoluto & quieto ſum animo, & quorſum recidat responſum tuum, non magnopere laboro: firmiſſimis enim & ſanctiſſimis teſtimonijs Viroroum optimorum cauſa Roſcij communita eſt: wee in this caſe may ſay much better, that concerning our Saviours Reſurrection, we are, as we ought to be, fully reſolved, nor doe we paſſe a whit what Iew, or Gentile, can ſay againſt it, ſince it is ſo confirmed to vs by ſo many ſundry kindes of ſeverall Witneſſes. It followeth: And was made the firſt fruits of them that ſlept.

That in this place by Them that Slept, are meant the Dead, is a Note perhaps that needes not, were there not ſome in this Aſſembly, not ſo skilfull in Holy Scripture as are the reſt. Such as they are, are to know, that it is an vſuall
phraſe of ſpeech both in Old, & the New Teſtament. Thus is it there ſaid of king David that he 1 King. 2.10. ſlept with his Fathers, and of 1. King. 11.43. Solomon, and 1 King 14 20. Ieroboam, and Ver. 31. Roboam, and the reſt. Thus is it there ſaid of Act. 7.60. St Stephen alſo, and our Saviour himſelf ſo Ioh 1.13 ſpake of his Frend Lazarus being dead. The very Heathens ſpake ſo of Death to, and therefore one of them, he cals Sleepe, the Stulte quid eſt ſōnus geiidae niſi mor •… imago? Ovid. Amor. l. 2. cleg 9. Picture and Counterfait of Death:
Conſanguineus lethi ſopor Virg Aeneid. l 6. an other, the Kinſman of Death,
Frater fratrē amplectitur. Vid. Aelian Var. Hiſt. l. 2. c. 35. an other, The Brother of Death: a Menander in M • noſtch. fourth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , little myſteries of death. And to ſay the very truth, diverſe and ſundry are the properties that Death hath with Sleep, and Sleepe, with Death. Firſt, no man living can alwaies wake, and no man aliue but once muſt die. Secondly, a man going to his reſt puts of his Garments, and we when we are to die muſt of with this Body of ours, which is, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Cyril. Hyeroſ. Catech 4 p 91. St Cyril cals it, the Garment of the ſoule. Thirdly, Sleepe as Philoſophy teacheth vs, comes from the vapours in the Head, and the fruit forbidden that Adam our Head taſted of, hath exhaled ever ſince ſuch a noiſome vapour in every of vs, that die we muſt, we muſt die, we muſt all and every of vs fall at length into this dead ſleepe. Fourthly, Sleepe is a ſweete Recreation to vs for all the labours of the Day paſt,
Ovid. Met. l. 11. Somne quies rerum, placidiſſime ſomne Deorum,
Pax animi, quem cura fugit, qui corpora duris
Feſſa miniſterijs mulces, reparaſ
que labori:
and Death is a ſweet Repoſe for all our Labours, & all our Travailes. O Death, Eccleſ 41.2. ſaith the Sonne of Syrach, how acceptable is thy iudgement vnto the needfull, and vnto him whoſe strength faileth, and that is now in the laſt age, and is vexed with all things, and to him that despaireth, and hath loſt patience Fiftly, no man goeth to his Reſt but he hopes to riſe againe, and no man goeth to the Graue but he ſhal riſe againe indeed. Ideo dormientes appellat
Aug de verb. Apoſt. Ser. 32. p. 277. ſaith St Auſten, Scripturae veraciſſima conſuetudo, vt cum dormientes audimus, evigilaturos minimè deſperemus. Laſtly, he that
is eaſily awaked if ſo he be cald, and ſo ſhall wee awake when we ſhall be ſummond by ſound of Trump, for the Trump ſhall blow, and the dead ſhall bee raiſed vp incorruptible, and we (that liue) ſhall be changed; 1. Cor. 15.52. And againe, The Lord himſelfe ſhall deſcend from heaven with a ſhout, and with the voice of the Archangell, & with the Trū pet of God: and the dead in Chriſt ſhall riſe firſt. Then ſhall we which liue and remaine, bee caught vp with them alſo in the Clowds, to meet the Lord in the ayre: and ſo ſhall we ever be with the Lord, 1. Theſſ. 4.16. But it is not my proiect & purpoſe to deliuer vnto you at this time all the mutuall correſpondences that are betweene Sleep and Death, it is enough that you vnderſtand that the Dead are meant in this place by thoſe that Sleepe, and now muſt I ſhew vnto you why our Saviour is here named, The firſt fruits of the Dead, in that it is here ſaid, And was made the firſt fruits of them that ſlept.

The Firſt Fruits among the Iewes were thoſe Primitiva ſunt animantiū, & inanimantium, quae prima naſcuntur, & quae primùm terra gignit. Hier. in Ezec. c. 44. pag. 549. Col 1. Primitiae quantum ad terrae noſcentia de ſeptem rebus tantùm dabantur, ſcilicet de Frumento, Hordeo, Vinea, Oliva, Malogranato, Ficu, & Palma. Lyra in Deut. 26. ex Rabbi Solomone kind of fruits that were firſt of all ripe, & brought into the Temple. They were brought into the Temple for the Prieſt to bleſſe, that in bleſſing of the ſame, the reſt alſo that were as yet abroad in the Fields, might participate of that bleſſing. This it is that this our Apoſtle ſaith, Rom. 11.16. If the firſt fruits be holy, ſo is the whole lumpe: and if the root be holy, ſo are the branches. Of Firſt fruits we may read, Levit. 23.10. & 10.24. Deut. 26.1. and Ezech. 44.30. Such then being the Firſt fruits, the meaning is, That our Saviour was the Firſt that roſe againe from the dead, who in that caſe being ſanctified as the firſt fruits of the dead vnto God, the Dead likewiſe that then were, and ſhall bee to the worlds end, ſhall be ſanctified alike with him. I meane ſuch as are ſuch fruits as he himſelfe was, VVheat, not Chaffe, Grapes, not Wild Grapes, Oliues, not Wild Oliues, and ſo forth of the reſt. Howbeit here it may bee obiected that ſeeing many before our Saviour were reſtored from death to life, as the 1. Kin 17 22 Widowe of Sareptaes Sonne by Elias
the 2. Kin. 4.34. Shunamites Sonne by Eliſha, the Mark. 5.42. Daughter of Iairus by our Saviour himſelfe, as alſo the Luk. 7.15. Widows Sonne of Naim, and Ioh. 11.44. Lazarus of Bethania, how our Saviour could poſſibly be the firſt fruits of the dead: it is true they were thus reſtored indeed, howbeit after their returne to life, they were ſtill ſubiect to Sinne and Death as they had bin alwaies before that. Vid. B. Bilſons Full Redempt. p. 154. & p. 217. But the firſt that ever roſe into a happy and heavenly life, that without all doubt was our Saviour, who in that reſpect is tearmed The firſt that ſhould riſe from the dead, Act. 26.23: and, The firſt begotten of the dead, Rev. 1.5. The firſt begotten of the dead,
Baſil. Cont. Eunem. l. 4. p. 349. ſaith S. Baſil, quia cauſa fuit, & eſt, vt omnes mortui reſurgant ad vitam immortalem: becauſe he was, & is the cauſe that the Dead ſhould riſe againe to life immortall. It followeth in the laſt words, For ſince by man came death, by man came alſo the Reſurrection of the dead.

How Death came firſt by Man, and by what Man, what Death, is apparant to all ſuch as haue but read, or heard read, the firſt three Chapters of Gods Booke. It is a ſtory ſet downe at large, and ſhould I as largely relate it to you, the time would cut me of, and prevent my other meditations. The Summe thereof is this. The Lord of heauen having made this great World as it were a large Volume, made afterwards an Epitome of it, and that was Man. All things elſe, Tertul adverſ. Marcion. l. 2. p. 149. ſaith Tertullian, he created at the firſt, imperiali verbo, by his word. He ſpake, ſaith the Pſalmiſt, and it was done, he commanded, and it ſtood faſt, Pſal. 33,9. But as for Mā he made him, familiari manu, with his fingers ends, he beſtowed (as it were) much more paines in cōtriuing, and making him. Concerning the reſt of the Creatures made, Let there be light, Gen 1.3. ſaith he, and there was light, V. 7. Let there be a firmament, and it was ſo. V. 9. Let the waters bee gathered into one place, and let the dry land appeare, and there was both Earth and Sea. V. 14. Let there bee lights in the firmament of the heaven, & there was both Sunne and Moone, and Starres. V. 20. Let the waters bring forth in abundance every
creeping thing that hath life, and there was both Fiſh and feathered Fowle. Gen. 1.24. Let the Earth bring forth the liuing thing according to his kind, & there were preſently Beaſts, and Catle: But when he came to make MAN, hee ſaid not let there be Man, as he ſaid of all the reſt, which had beene as ſufficient for the making of him, but firſt, V. 26. Let vs make Man: and then, In our image according to our likeneſſe: & then, Let them rule over the Fiſh of the Sea, and over the Fowle of the Heaven, and over the Beaſts, and over all the Earth, and over every thing that creepeth, and mooueth on the earth: and then hee made the Man of the Gen. 2.7. duſt of the ground, and then breathed in his face breath of life: & then of the V. 22. Rib of Man hee made a Woman to beare him company, for as much as it was not good that the Man ſhould be himſelfe V. 18. alone. And here with Tertul adverſ. Marcion. l. 2. p. 149. Tertullian, let vs conſider ere we goe any farther, the many goodneſſes of God towards Man. The Goodneſſe of God made him firſt of all, of the duſt of the Earth: the Goodneſſe of God breathed life into him: the Goodneſſe of God gaue him dominion over all the Beaſts of the Field: the Goodneſſe of God afforded him ſuch delights beſides, that though he were Lord of all the world, yet his abode ſhould be in Paradiſe the beautie of the world: the Goodneſſe of God provided for him an Helper too, NE QVID NON BONI: ſaith Tertullian, being himſelfe a married man, leaſt any good thing might be wanting to him: the Goodneſſe of God gaue him a Law too, that man himſelfe might only be ſubiect to that God, who had made a little before, all things ſubiect vnto man: the Goodneſſe of God foretold him the perill that would enſue if hee brake that Law, vnwilling doubtleſſe, ſaith Tertullian, that ever hee ſhould breake it, who foretold him ſo truely the puniſhment before. Thus was Man full of wiſdome, and perfect in beautie, as Ezec. 28.12. ſpeakes the Prophet. He was in Eden the Garden of God, every pretious Stone was in his Garment, I meane his Soule. The Ruby, the Topaz, the Diamond, the Chryſolite, the Onix, the Iasper, the Saphier, the Emrod, and the Carbuncle:
he was the annointed Cherub; And yet for all this what became of Man at length? Man, Pſ. 49.20. ſaith the Pſalmiſt, being in honour hath no vnderſtanding, but is cōpared to the Beaſts that periſh. Nay more then by way of compariſon too. Thoſe things are compared to other, that in no wiſe are the ſame, but the condition of the Children of Men, and the condition of Beaſts, are (as the Prophet tels vs) the ſelfe ſame. As the one dieth ſo dieth the other Eccles 3.19. ſaith he, for they haue all one breath, and there is no excellency of Man aboue the Beaſt, for all is vanitie. All goe to one place, and all was of the duſt, & all ſhall returne to the duſt. And thus hath Adam plunged vs all into a Gulph of miſeries, inſomuch that all and every of vs may now ſay with 2. Eſd. 7.48. Eſdras, O Adam, what haſt thou done? for in that thou haſt ſinned, thou art not fallen alone, but the fall alſo redoundeth vnto vs that come of thee. By Man came Death.

But what? is there no Balme at Gilead? Is there no Phyſitian there? may not this Health of ours, this Sinne, this Fall, this Death, be healed, or recovered? Son of man, Ezec. 37.4 ſaith the Lord to Ezechiel, can theſe bones liue? To whom whē Ezechiel anſwered, O Lord God, thou knoweſt: Propheſie, ſaith the Lord, vpon theſe bones, and ſay vnto them, O yee dry bones, heare the word of the Lord. Thus ſaith the Lord God vnto theſe bones, Behold I will cauſe breath to enter into you, and yee ſhall liue. And I will lay ſinews vpon you, & make fleſh grow vpon you, and cover you with skinne, & put breath in you, that yee may liue, and yee ſhall knowe that I am the Lord. The Lord ſpake it, and performed as much, there was a V. 7. noyſe, and a ſhaking, and the Bones came together, bone to his bone, the Sinews and the Fleſh grew vpon them, the Skin covered them, & they did liue. And even as they did, ſo ſhall we, not a Bone of ours ſhall be miſſing, Sinews and Fleſh ſhall grow vpon vs, the Skin ſhall cover vs, and we ſhall ſtand vpon our Feet an exceeding great Army. I, & that ſo certainely as if it now were done already, For ſince by Man came Death, by Man came alſo, marke Beloved,
came alſo, not commeth, or ſhall come, but by Man came alſo the Reſurrection of the dead. For as Adams Fleſh was the POISON that infected all, and every of vs: ſo our Saviours Fleſh is the Treacle that ſhal quickē vs al, & every one. He was the Firſt-borne of the Dead, he was the Firſt-fruits of them that ſlept, ſo that we alſo ſhall riſe againe, we ſhall reviue as he did. Our Bodies, as 1. Cor. 15.42 ſpeakes the Apoſtle, are ſowen in corruption, but they are raiſed in incorruption: they are ſowne in diſhonour, & they are raiſed in glory: they are ſowen in weaknes, and they are raiſed in power: they are ſowen naturall Bodies, and they are raiſed spirituall Bodies. Thou ſoweſt not Ver. 37. ſaith the ſame Apoſtle, as it is in our laſt Tranſlation, that Body that ſhall be, but bare graine, it may chaunce of wheat, or of ſome other graine, but God giveth it a Body as it hath pleaſed him, and to every ſeed his owne Body. Excellent are the words of Tertullian herevpon: The Grane of corne,
Scritur ſolum modò granum ſine folliculi veſte, ſine fundamento ſp • cae, ſinc munimento ariſtae, ſine ſuperbia culmi. Exurgit autem copia foeneratū, compagine aedificatum, ordine ſtructum, cultu munitum & vſquequa
que veſtitum. Haec ſunt ei corpus à Deo aliud, in quod non abolitione, ſed ampliatione mutatur. Tertul. de Reſurre. Carn. p. 57. ſaith he, is ſowen without an huske, or without an eare, or beard of an eare, or without anie ſtem or ſtalke; but it riſeth againe in much more plenty, well cowched together, in due order, fairely decked, and trimmed, and cloſed in on every ſide. And this is the Body God giues it, not in that it is aboliſhed, but increaſed more at large. And ſuch a change by way of proportion ſhal be in our Bodies, and as we haue 1. Cor. 15 49 borne the image of the Earthly, ſo ſhall wee beare the image of the Heavenly. Now whereas there may ſeeme more likelyhood of our Saviors Body riſing againe, then may poſſibly be of Ours, foraſmuch as he roſe againe the third day, our Bodies are not like to riſe againe manie hundreds of yeeres after their Burial (no more then theirs that haue beene buried ſo many ſeverall Ages gone and paſt) that Aug. Epiſt. 49. p. 125. ſaith St Auſten, is al one: for that both vnto humane ability as they are impoſſible alike, ſo both againe to Heavenly Power are light, and eaſie to be perfourmed. For as the Sight of our Eie,
Aug. Epiſt. 49. p. 125. ſaith he, reacheth as ſoone to things a farre of, as it doth to things nigh at hand, and it is not longer in ſeeing a Mile of, then in ſeeing things that are
hard by: even ſo the Apoſtle ſaith he, enforming vs that the Reſurrection ſhall be perfourmed in the twinckling of an eie, 1. Cor. 15 52 it is as eaſie for Gods Omnipotencie to raiſe vp Carkaſes already dead many thouſands of yeeres agoe, as thoſe that dyed but three daies ſince. Nor ſhal it be preiudicial herevnto ſaith the ſame St Auſten in an other place, though a man be burnt to aſhes, or torne with Dogs. Omnia
Aug. in Pſal. 62 p. 438. ſaith he, quae diſcerpuntur, & in favillas quaſdam putreſcunt, integra Deo ſunt. All things whatſoever haue by any manner of meanes beene diſſolved, or turned into aſhes, they are ſafe, and ſound vnto God. And thus much of the Words as they lie in order in my Text, nowe as touching ſuch Inſtructions as the ſame ſhall afforde vnto vs. But now is Christ riſen from the dead, and was made the firſt fruits of them that ſlept. For ſince by man came Death, by man came alſo the Reſurrection of the dead.

Firſt and formoſt then from theſe words: But now is Chriſt riſen from the dead, the Inſtruction I gather is, that wee alwaies beare in minde our Saviours Victory over Death. Remember 2. Tim. 2.8. ſaith the Apoſtle St Paul among his many Memorandums vnto Timothy, that Ieſus Chriſt made of the ſeed of David, was raiſed againe from the dead. If Timothy Pauls 1. Tim. 1.2. naturall Sonne in the Faith, a 1. Tim 6.11. man of God, one in whom was 2. Tim. 1.5. Faith vnfained, that 2 Tim. 3 10. fully knew the Apoſtles Doctrine, and the 2. Tim 3 15. Scriptures of a Childe, & (if the Tranſlation of the Poſtſcript of St Pauls ſecond Epiſtle vnto him, deceiue vs not) the Firſt 2. Tim 4 22. Biſhop of the Church of Epheſus: if Timothy, I ſay, had ſuch need to haue this Memento given vnto him, that Chriſt was raiſed againe from the dead, how ſhould we be remembred of it, and notwithſtanding our learning of it heretofore, how is it likely we may forget it. Fluitat humana Memoria
Aug. de Conſenſ. Evang. l. 3. c. 13. p. 352. ſaith St Auſten, nec in cuiuſquam poteſtate est, quid & quando veniat in mentem. The memory of man, goes often a wool-gathering, nor is it in any mans power whatſoever to ſaie aforehand, he will remember ſuch a thing, and at ſuch a
time. The moſt obnoxious to Faults of Forgetfulnes are commonly Old men, and yet Nec vero quē quam Senum audivi oblitum quo loco theſaurum obruiſſet. Tul. de Senect. ſaith Cato, I for my part haue never heard of an Old man that ever forgot where he hid his Gold. Doubtleſſe Beloved, there is in this point a golden Treaſure, and though perhaps we ſhoulde never forget where we had hid it in times paſt, namely, in our Heartes, yet ſuch is the ſubtilty of Sathan dayly ſeeking to circumvent vs, & to become Maiſter of this Prize, that as Euclio in the Poet had Nunc ibo vt viſam, ſune ita aurum vt condidi. Plaut. Aulul. Act. 1. ſc. Exi • inquam. ſtill a minde to his Pot of Gold for feare of falſe fingring, ſo, and more then ſo it behoveth vs to be ſtill having a care whether this our Treaſure be there or no. Concerning the worth of this Treaſure, St Paul wil tel vs, no man better: I, Philip. 3.8. ſaith he, count all things to be loſſe, and iudge them to be dung, that I might win Chriſt, and might be found in him, that is, not having mine owne righteouſneſſe, which is of the Law, but that which is through the faith of Chriſt, even the righteouſneſſe which is of God through faith, that I may know him, and the vertue of his Reſurrection, and the fellowſhip of his afflictions, and be made conformable vnto his death. And this that we alſo may the better doe, let vs call to minde firſt and formoſt, how our Saviour himſelfe by his owne power did raiſe himſelfe to Life againe. I, Ioh. 10 17 ſaith he, lay downe my life, that I might take it againe. No man taketh it from me, but I lay it downe of my ſelfe: I haue power to lay it downe, and haue power to take it againe. Nor is it preiudiciall herevnto that this his Raiſing againe is attributed Rom. 4. • 4. ſometimes to the FATHER, Rom. 8.11. ſometimes to the HOLY GHOST, ſeeing the Holy Ghoſt, the Father, and Himſelf are all one: the glory equal, the maieſty coeternall. And howſoever the Father is Almighty, the Sonne Almighty: & the Holy Ghoſt Almighty: yet as Athanaſius
Athanaſius Creed. tels vs, they are not three Almighties but one Almighty.
Secondly, let vs cal to mind how hee aroſe againe with an Earthquake. There was Mat. 28.2. ſaith St Mathew, a great Earthquake: and this great Earthquake no doubt was a Preamble 〈…〉

〈…〉
•… dy, that yee ſhould obey it in the luſts thereof. Nether giue ye your Members, as weapons of vnrighteouſneſſe vnto ſinne: but giue your ſelues vnto God, as they that are aliue from the dead, and giue your Members, as weapons of Righteouſneſſe vnto God. And againe to the Epheſ. 5.14. Epheſians, Awake thou that ſleepeſt, and ſtand vp from the dead, and Chriſt ſhall giue thee light. What? and haſt thou not thy part then in this Firſt Reſurrection? Doſt thou not find, and feele in thy ſelfe, the kingdome of God in thee yet begun? Art thou now as prone to all evill, as ever in all thy life before? as ready to rap out an oath, to drink & to be drunkē, nor to reverence or God, or Man, but to follow thine owne luſt, to abandon thy ſelfe to thy owne pleaſure? Feare and tremble: there is not a Second, without a Firſt: if ſo bee thou beginneſt not in this life with this firſt Reſurrection thus ſpoken of, there muſt concurre a many Miracles to make thee partaker of the Second. It is true concerning the Theefe, Subito in ictu oculi de Cruce in Coelum tranſiliuit: hee made, Aug. de Temp Ser. 130 p. 634 ſaith S. Auſten, but a skip from the Croſſe he hanged vpon into Heauen: but that of S. Auſten is as true againe, & he hath it in more places then Aug. de Verb. Dom. Ser. 16. p. 49. & Ser. 59. p. 1512 & Hom. 11. p. 299. one: God hath promiſed, I grant, forgiueneſſe of ſinnes, when ever thou ſhalt repent, but if ſo bee thou repent not to day before to morrow, hee hath no where made promiſe to thee, that thou ſhalt liue till to morrow. I ſuppoſe, Sen de Tranquil. vitae l. 1. c. 1 ſaith Seneca, that a many might haue attained vnto Wiſdome, had they not had a ſelfe-opinion that they had attained vnto it already: & many by much likelyhood, might haue beene Saints in the kingdome of Heaven, had they not made themſelues afore hand too too ſure and ſecure thereof. True it is, wee hold a CERTAINTIE, but not a SECVRITIE of Salvation: Certus ſum, Rom. 8.38. ſaith the Apoſtle S. Paul, I am perſwaded that neither Death, nor Life, nor Angels, nor Principalities, nor Powers, nor Things preſent, nor Things to come, nor Height, nor Depth, nor any other Creature ſhall be able to ſeparate vs frō the loue of God, who Epheſ. 2.12. wills the Philippians notwithſtanding,
Chriſtians as good as were the Romans, to make an end of their owne Salvation with Feare, and Trembling. But thus much of the Second Inſtruction.

The Third, & Laſt Inſtruction I am to make, is from the laſt words of my Text: For ſince by Man came Death, by Man came alſo the Reſurrection of the Dead: & the Inſtruction I gather is this: that ſince the Reſurrection of the Dead hath come by Man, the Seed of the Woman, nor Man, nor Woman ought at all to feare Death. Not that I would haue Death deſpiſed altogether, ſince it came in firſt by Sinne: and it is the Puniſhment of Sinne, and wholy to deſpiſe Death, is an Argument, Gualter in Ioh. 12. Hom. 118. Vid. B. Bilſons Survey of Chriſts Sufferings. p. 150. ſaith a learned Writer, of a Mind ſcant religious. It is an vngracious Child that deſpiſeth the Puniſhment of his Father, and that Servant that ſets but light by his Maſters Correctiō, is without all doubt a lewd Servant. Howbeit here, Beloved, as it is exceeding hard for the beſt of vs al to keepe a Meane: ſo are there none almoſt, but when Death approacheth in very deed, betake themſelues to the worſe Extreame, and are too too much frighted with it. Behold, Iob. 4 3. ſaith Elephaz vnto Iob, thou haſt taught many, and haſt ſtrengthned the wearie hands. Thy wordes haue confirmed him that was falling, and thou haſt ſtrengthned the weake knees. But now it is come vpon thee and thou art grieved, it toucheth thee, & thou art troubled. Right ſo, Beloved, in this caſe. How many Hundreds are there that haue at their fingers ends in another mans caſe, an heape of ſeverall Sentences againſt the Feare of Death, as Senec. Epiſt. ſ. 17. ep. 103. Dies iſte quem tanquam extremum reformidas, aeterni natalis eſt. And againe, Senec. Epiſt. l. 7. ep. 55. In hoc, niſi fallor, erramus, quòd Mortem iudicamus ſequi, quū illa & praeceſſerit, & ſecutura ſit. Quicquid ante nos fuit, Mors eſt.
Senec Epiſt. l. 1. ep. 1. Quicquid aetatis retro eſt, Mors tenet. And againe, Senec. de Cō ſolat. ad Polyb. c 28. In hoc tam procelloſo, & in omnes tempeſtates expoſito Mari navigantibus, nullus portus niſi Mortis est. Sir, be of good courage, this very Day, which you feare may bee your laſt in this world, may proue your Birth-day of Eternity. It is but
an errour of ours that we ſuppoſe wee ſhall but now die, we intruth died long agoe, for all our Life paſt what hath it beene but a kind of Death? To thoſe that ſayle in this troubleſome and tempeſtuous Sea of the world there is no Port, or Haven, but Death: and yet notwithſtanding al this, let it be a mans owne caſe, and ſee Death come towards himſelfe, and then, as the ſame Seneca ſpeakes, Tergiverſatur, tremit, plorat: either hee hath a Aeſop. Fab.
Burthen for Death to help him vp withall, or elſe he is too Pſ. 102 24. Young, and not old enough, or he hath Wife, & Childrē, that muſt be provided for, or the Dan. 5.6. Ioints of his loynes are looſed, & his knees ſmite one againſt the other, or he puts 2. King. 20 3 finger in the eye. It fareth with ſuch an one in this caſe, as it did with the Hart in the Fable, which Sr. Thomas Moore relates in theſe words: There was, Sr Thomas Moore Comfort in Tribulat l. 3. c. 24 Oper. Angl. p. 1253. ſaith hee, a great old Hart that had fled from a little Bitch which had made ſuit after him, & chaſed him ſo lōg that ſhhe had loſt him, & as he hoped, more then halfe given him over. By occaſion whereof hauing then ſome time to talke, and meeting with another of his Fellowes, he fell in deliberation with him, what were beſt for him to doe, whether to runne on ſtill, and fly farther from her, or turne againe, and fight with her. Wherevnto the tother Hart adviſed him to fly no farther, leaſt the Bitch might happen to find him againe, at ſuch time as he ſhould with the labour of farther flying, be fallē out of breath, & thereby all out of ſtrength too: and ſo ſhould he be kild, lying where he could not ſtir him. Whereas if he would turne and fight, he were in no perill at al.
