For the Man with whom ſhe hunteth, is more thē a Myle behind her, and ſhe is but a little Body ſcant halfe ſo much as thou, and thy Hornes may thruſt her through, before ſhee can touch thy Fleſh by more then ten times her tooth length. By my truth, quoth the Tother Hart, I like thy counſaile well, & me thinketh that the thing is even ſoothly as you ſay. But I feare when I heare once that vrchin Bitch barke, I ſhall fall to my feet, and forget altogether. But yet, and you will go back with me, then me thinke wee ſhall bee ſtrong enough againſt
that one Bitch betweene vs both, wherevnto the tother Hart agreed, and ſo they both appointed them thereon. But even as they were about to buſk them forward to it, the Bitch had found the foot againe, and on ſhe came gerning toward the place, whō as ſoon as the Harts heard, they to go both twaine apace. Death, Beloved, a great way of, it is an eaſie matter to dare it, the veryeſt Coward that is, may bee valiant ſo farre forth, but when we ſhall ſee him come ſtaulking towardes vs, and ſingling vs out from a many Thouſands, and aiming his Dart only at vs, then to oppoſe our ſelues againſt him, and to ſtand valiantly vpon our Guard, and yet contentedly to ſay vnto Him to, Virg. Aeneid. l. 6. Death, doe thy office, thou art the Miniſter of Iuſtice:
Hieron. vita Hilarion.
Hoc opus, hic labor eſt, that were a point of Manhood indeed,
— Pauci quos aequus amavit
Iuppiter, aut ardens evexit ad aethera Virtus,
Dijs geniti▪ potuere.

Few there are that can ſo doe, and old Hilarion indeed did ſo: Egredere ſaith he, quid times? egredere anima mea, quid dubitas? Septuaginta propè annis ſerviſti Chriſto, & mortem times? Goe out, my Soule, goe out, ſaith he, what is it thou art afraid of? Theſe threeſcore and ten yeeres well neere, haſt thou ſerved thy Lord Chriſt, and art thou now afraid to die? And with that he gaue vp the Ghoſt. The truth is, DEATH in it ſelfe is, as Ariſtotle ſpeaketh, Ariſt. Ethic. l. 3. 6.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of Things Terrible, the moſt TERRIBLE, • , Rex Terrorum, as Bildad Iob. 18.14. Tremell. ſpeaketh, The King of Feare: but ſince the WORD was made FLESH, and dwelt amongſt vs: ſince the Sentence againſt the firſt Adam was reverſed by the Second: ſince by Death he deſtroyed Death, that is, he tooke out the Sting of it, and the third day roſe againe, why ſhould Death be fearefull to vs, and to ſpeake in Iam ex quo Verbum Car • factum eſt, & habitavit in nobis: ex quo primi Adae datam ſententiam, Adam noviſſimus ſoluit, ex quo noſtrum mortem ſua morte deſtruxit, & ab In feris die tertia Dominus reſurrexit, iam non eſt terribilis Mors fidelibus: non timetur occaſus, quia oriens venit ex alto Aug. de Conſolat. mor. •… or, Ser. 1. c. 1. Saint Auſtens phraſe, Why ſhould we feare the Sunneſet of Death, ſeeing the Day spring from an high ſhall viſite vs againe. What is it ſaith the ſame Father that God hath given vs by his only begotten Sonne, if ſo bee we 〈…〉

div.head: THE COMMING OF THE HOLY GHOST.

p.hi: Now in the lſt great day of the Feaſt, Ieſus ſtood and cryed laying, If any man thirſt let him come vnto me, and drinke. Hee that beleeueth in me, as ſaith the Scripture, out of his belly ſhall flowe rivers of water of life. This ſpake hee of the Spirit, which they that beleeued in him ſhould receiue: For the Holy Ghoſt was not yet giuen, becauſe that Ieſus was not yet glorified.

div.p:
AS Gods extraordinary preſence, Mr Hooker Eccleſ. Pol l. 5. §. 69. p. 192. ſaith a Reverend Writer, hath hallowed, and ſanctified certaine Places, ſo they are his extraordinary Workes, that haue truely and worthely advanced certain Times. In regard whereof the Son of Syrach to a Queſtion that might bee demaunded, why one Day excells another, ſeeing the light of every of thē comes from that Sunne aboue in the Firmament, anſwereth immediatly in theſe Ecclus 33.8. words: The knowledge of the Lord hath parted them aſunder, and he hath by them dispoſed the times, and ſolem Feaſts. Some of them hath he choſen, & ſanctified, & ſome of thē hath he put among the dayes to nomber. The times which he hath choſen, and ſanctified, that is, ſanctified to himſelfe,
and commaunded the Iewes to obſerue, were ordinarily the Saboth, extraordinarily the ſolem Feaſts, and Solemnities of the Yeere. The Saboth was every ſeuenth day: the ſolemne Feaſts, & yearly Solemnities, were ſpecially three: The Feaſt of Vnleauened Bread which was their Feaſt of Eaſter: the Feaſt of Harveſt, or of their firſt Fruits, which was their Whitſontide, and the Feaſt of Gathering fruites in the end of the Yeare, which was the Feaſt of Tabernacles. Three time: Exod. 23 14. ſaith the Lord in Exodus, thou ſhalt keepe a feaſt vnto me in the yeere. Thou ſhalt keep the Feaſt of vnleauened bread: the Feaſt alſo of the Harueſt of the firſt Fruits of thy labours which thou hast ſowne in the field: & the Feaſt of gathering fruits in the end of the yeere, when thou hast gathered in thy labours out of the field. Now Who they were, and How they were, to come vnto theſe Feaſts, Moſes declareth to vs as in this very place of Exodus, ſo Deut. 16.16. Three times in the yeere, ſaith Moſes, ſhall all the Males appeare before the Lord thy God in the place which he ſhall chooſe: in the Feaſt of the vnleauened bread, & in the Feaſt of the weekes, and in the Feaſt of the Tabernacles, and they ſhall not appeare before the Lord empty. Meaning their Males Exod 30.14. Vid Caluin in Exod. 23 16. from twenty yeere old and aboue, not that Females came not to, but they were not compeld to come. And whereas it might be thought it ſhould be dangerous to their Land to haue the People go in ſuch ſort all of them at once, his Exod 3 • .24. promiſe was that in the mean time their Land ſhold be ſecured from all invaſion. Their Feaſt of Eaſter was in remēbrance of their deliuerance out of Egypt, & it was cald the Feast of the Paſſouer, in reguard that whē the Lord paſt through the Land of Egipt, he ſmote all the firſt borne in the Land and both Man and Beaſt, but paſſed ouer the Iſraelites, Exod. 12.13. Their Feaſt of Harueſt called Whitſontide was kept fifty daies after Eaſter, partly in tokē that the Law was giuen fifty daies after their deliuerance, partly in remēbrance that they were to bring their firſt Fruits of the Land into Gods houſe, that ſo the reſt of their Fruits
might be holy to, Rom. 11.16. Their Feaſt of Tabernacles was in remembrāce of their forty yeeres travaile through the wilderneſſe, when as they roamed vp and downe with out houſe, without home, hungry, and thirſty, their ſoules fainted in them, Pſ. 107.5. Our Saviour Chriſt that came to keep the Law, & to obſerue it every tittle, that it might be truly ſaid of him by the voyce of God himſelfe which Pilate Luc. 23.14. ſaid by his owne experience, & by the experience of Herod to, I haue found no fault in this mā, did in no wiſe neglect theſe Feaſts being ſo great a parcell of the Law, & therefore he himſelfe not only went to euery of them, but St Iohn in this his Goſpell relateth vnto vs that he went. That he was at the Feaſt of Eaſter, he ſpecifieth vnto vs in his Second, Third, & Fourth Chapters. That he was at the Feaſt of Pentecoſt, in his Fift, & Sixt Chapters. That he was at the Feaſt of Tabernacles, in this Seauenth Chapter we haue in hand, as alſo in the Eight, Ninth, Tenth, & Eleuēth Chapters. The Feaſt here ſpecified then, being the Feaſt of Tabernacles, and our Saviour being at this Feaſt, the next thing to be conſidered is his manner of Behaviour there.

His manner of Behaviour, is in the words I haue read vnto you: wherein for our better proceeding I ſhall obſerue vnto you theſe poynts: Firſt, the Subſtance of a certaine Sermon made by our Saviour at that time: Secondly, our Saviours Behaviour, and manner in making it: Thirdly, the Evangeliſt St Iohn his Noats therevpon. The Subſtance of Sermō made is compriſed in theſe words: If any man thirſt let him come vnto me, and drink. He that beleeueth in me as ſaith the Scripture, out of his belly ſhall flowe Riuers of water of life. His Manner of making it in theſe, Now in the laſt & great day of the Feaſt Ieſus stood & cried. The Evangeliſt his Noats therevpon, in theſe, This ſpake hee of the Spirit which they that beleeued in him ſhould receiue, for the Holy Ghoſt was not yet giuen, becauſe that Ieſus was not yet glorified. In the Subſtāce of the Sermon here made, I ſhal obſerue vnto you theſe Points: Firſt, an Invitation
of our Saviours, Let him come vnto me: Secondly, Who they are that are inuited, If any man thirſt: Thirdly, what it is they are inuited to, namely vnto Riuers of water of Life: If any man thirſt let him come vnto me and drink. He that beleeueth in me as ſaith the Scripture, out of his belly ſhall flowe Riuers of water of life. Firſt of the Invitation, Let him come vnto me.

He that by the Apoſtle St Paul giues inſtruction vnto Biſhops, that they ſhold be 1 Tim. 3.2. Tit. 1 8. HOSPITALES, Harberous and good Houſkeepers, giuing themſelues to Hoſpitality euen in things cōcerning the Body: he being himſelfe the cheife 1 Pet. 2.21. Shepheard, and Biſhop of our Soules, giues himſelfe euen now adaies 1 Pet. 5.4. being at Gods right hand, to noe leſſe Hospitality, in things concerning the Spirit. Hence it is that the Apoſtle St Paul in his Epiſtle to the Epheſians, Epheſ. 4.8. acquaints vs with his benevolences, and how Grace is giuen to every of vs according to the meaſure of the gift of Chriſt, & out of the threeſcore and eight Pſalme proueth manifeſtly vnto vs, that when he aſcended vp on high, he led Captivity captiue, and gaue Gifts vnto men. Howbeit thoſe kinds of Gifts there ſpecified, were for the work of the Miniſtery, & for the edification of the Body of Chriſt and therefore is it Epheſ. 4.11. ſaid immediatly, that he gaue ſome to be Apostles, and ſome Prophets, and ſome Evangeliſts, and ſome Paſtors, and Teachers: now their are Gifts more generall then all theſe, whereof not the Paſtors, and Teachers only, and Evangeliſts, and Prophets, and Apoſtles, are capable, but all of what condition, and ſtate ſoeuer. Soe that as Abrahās Hoſpitality, & his Nephew Lots, was Gen. 18.2. Gen. 19.1. ſpecially obſerued herein, that when as Strangers arriued, they ran to meete them, and curteouſly inuited them to their Howſes: Strangers, I ſay, vnknowne vnto them, not Familiars only, not Frinds: right ſo our Saviours Hoſpitality, his curteous inuitation is herein ſeene, in that it is generall, not particular, nor to Frinds only, but to Strāgers, evē to ſuch as are without Chriſt, aliants from the common wealth of Iſraell,
and Straungers from the Couenants of promiſe, Eph. 2.12. If any man thirſt let him come vnto me, and drink.

Or, be it, he here ſpake only to the Iſralites who came vnto this Feaſt, and as he Mat. 15.24 ſpeakes himſelfe elſwhere, I am not ſent, but vnto the loſt ſheepe of the houſe of Iſrael: and as he willed his Apoſtles an other Mat. 10.5. time, Goe not into the way of the Gentiles, and into the Cityes of the Samaritans enter ye not. But go rather to the loſt Sheep of the houſe of Iſraell: yet ſince the partition Wall is now broken between Iew and Gentile, and the Vaile of the Temple is rent, and whatſoeuer things are written aforetime, are written for our Rom. 15.4. learning, that we through patience, and comfort of the Scriptures might haue hope, what was ſaid vnto the Iews here, was ſaid vnto vs all, of what Nation, Tribe, or Kinred ſoeuer, If any Man thirſt let him cōe vnto me. It is an excellent Aug. de Verb. Dom. Ser. 16. p. 49. ſaying of St Auſtens, Distribuite tempora, & concordat Scriptura: Diſtinguiſh the times, & the Scriptures accord exceeding well. Our Saviour, who when time was, would not his Apoſtles ſhould goe into the way of the Gentiles, Mat. 10.5. after his Reſurrection from the Dead, bad them goe, & teach all Nations, Mat. 28.19. If any Man thirſt, let him come vnto me.

The word ME here in this place, Let him come vnto me, puts vs in mind as Who it is to whom we ſhould come, ſo alſo of his Name here, and by conſequence of his Nature. Who Prov. 30.4. ſaith Sol • mon, hath aſcended vp to heauen, & deſcended? who hath gathered the winde in his fiſt? Who hath bound the waters in a garment? Who hath eſtabliſhed all the ends of the world? What is his Name, and what is his Sonnes Name if thou canſt tell? As if hee had ſaid thou canſt not poſſibly name the Man that ever hath, or ſhall be able to doe theſe things. And true it is, the Man we cannot, but yet we can name that God, and Man, who may be ſaid to aſcend vp to heaven, and deſcend, in regard of his vniverſal providēce, Pſal. 113.5; and to haue gathered the winde in his fiſt, for he bringeth it out of his treaſures, Pſal. 135.7; and to bind
the waters in a garment, for he gathereth them together as it were vpon an heape, and layeth them vp as in a Wardrobe, Pſal. 33.7. and to eſtabliſh the ends of the world, for he hath placed the Sand for the bounds of the Sea by the perpetuall decree that it cannot paſſe it, Ier. 5.22. I, & we can name him, as St Ierome
Hieron. Tom. 3. Epiſt. ad Marcell.
1 El.
2 Elohim.
3 Elohe.
4 Sebaoth.
5 Gnelion.
6 Aſher eheie.
7 Adonai.
8 Iah.
9 Iehova.
10 Shaddai.
obſerues, by Tenne ſeverall Names. And as concerning his Sonnes Name, what that Name is, we need not goe farre to finde it, the Evangeliſt St Iohn ſets it here downe in the very Forefront of this my Text: Now in the laſt and great day of the Feaſt, Ieſus ſtood and cryed. IESVS.

I haue had occaſion Our Saviours Reſurr. Serm. 3 p. 61. heretofore to ſpeake of his other Name, the Name of CHRIST, whiCh I told you did ſignifie as much as Annointed, for becauſe he was annointed to be our Prophet, Prieſt, & Prince, & he was annointed with the Holy Ghoſt; & with Power, Act. 10.38. This name Ieſus is of an higher ſtraine for it ſignifies a Saviour, and therefore the Angel vnto Ioſeph, Mat. 1.21. Thou ſhalt call his Name Ieſus, for he ſhal ſaue his people from their ſinnes. So St Paul, He humbled himſelfe, Phil. 2.8. ſaith he, & became obedient vnto the death, even the death of the Croſſe. Wherefore God hath alſo highly exalted him, and given him a Name aboue every name. That at the Name of Ieſus ſhould every knee bow, both of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things vnder the earth, and that every tongue ſhould confeſſe that Ieſus Chriſt is the Lord, vnto the glory of God the Father. And St Peter in the Acts having profeſſed that hee healed a Cripple by the Name of Ieſus Chriſt of Nazareth: This is the Stone Act. 4.11. ſaith he, caſt aſide of you Builders, which is become the head of the Corner. Neither is there Salvation in any other: for among men there is given no other Name vnder heavē, wherby we muſt be ſaved. Oſiander was of opinion that this name Ieſus came not of Iaſhang the Hebrew word, which ſignifies to Saue, but of Iehova the Name of God, by putting in, Shin, the Hebrew letter, and al to ſignifie, ſaith he, Mans nature ioyned to the God-head. Howbeit ſince
Illyricus hath Vid. Illyrie. Clavem Ser. p. 622. refuted this his conceipt with diverſe and ſundry Reaſons, and for becauſe it is ſomewhat finer then common Eares can well conceiue, I wil not trouble you with it at this time, I had rather now relate vnto you what St Bernard hath of this Name. The Name of IESVS

Labi • ur qu • s in •… ime •… , currit inſuper ad laqucum mortis deſperando? nonne ſi invoc • t Nomen Vitae, confeſtim • eſpirabit ad vitam?
Huc t •… Electuarium habes ó Anima mea, recoditum in vaſ • ule vocabuli huius quod eſt Ieſus, ſalut ſerū certè, quoa
que nulli vaquam peſti tuae inventatur inefficax. Bernard ſuper Cant. Ser. 15. p 132. Col. 3. ſaith St Bernard, is not Brightnes only, but Nouriſhment to. As often as thou remembreſt it, art thou not as often comforted with it? What is it that in ſuch ſort makes the minde of him that thinketh on it ſo far and well liking? What doth ſo reſtore our Senſes, ſtrengthen our Ʋertues, quicken and refreſh our good Behaviour cheriſh and nouriſh our chaſt Affections? Al Food of the Soule is as dry as a kix, if it be not moiſtned with this Oyle. It is vnſavory, if it be not ſeaſoned with this Salt. If ſo bee thou vvrite vnto mee, all thy vvriting ſeemes harſh, vnleſſe I reade in the Forefront, the Name of Ieſus. If thou diſpute or conferre with me, it ſeemes all nothing worth, vnleſſe I heare the ſound of the Name of Ieſus. The name of Ieſus, is hony in the mouth, melody in the eare, ioy in the heart. I, and it is medicine to. Is any of vs ſad? Let this Name Ieſus come into our hearts, and paſſe from thence vnto our mouthes, and behold at the very riſing of the light of that Name, all Clowdes are diſpelled, faire Weather comes againe. Is any man falne into ſome notorious Crime, & would afterwards through despaire goe and make avvay himſelfe? if ſo bee hee can but call vpon this Name of Life: ſhal he not preſently enioy Life? His concluſion there is: O my Soule, thou haſt this Electuary cloſed vp, as it were in the Box of this Name Ieſus, doubtleſſe exceeding wholeſome & of ſufficient force & ſtrength to expell any Plague that may poſſibly ſurprize thee. You ſee
who it is to whom we ſhould come, & indeed as St Peter Ioh. 6.68. ſpake, to whom ſhould wee elſe goe? Eſpecially ſeeing he himſelfe, and none but he, invites vs ſo kindly. Where we are to marke, Beloved, his Phraſe of Speech that he vſeth alſo in this caſe. For he ſaith not, wil he, nil he, come he ſhall, but, Let him come, as it were remitting it to his owne will whether he come, or not. For Will from all Co-action wee Libertatem voluntatis non neceſſitas, ſed vis & coactio tollit. Whitak. in Durae • m. l. 5. p 383. graunt is Free: and yet we abhorre Freewill, as alſo thoſe peeviſh Paradoxes about it, which our Oſorius de Relig. in Gualt. Haddon. Angl Adverſaries are pleaſed to lay to our charge. Wee graunt that God workes not in vs as he doth vpon Stocks and Stones that haue no endeavour of themſelues, no motion at all, but as they are mooued by an other, noe we Foxius cont. Oſor. l. 2. p. 119 ſay with Ambroſ. de vocat. Gent. l. 1. c. 3. p. 6. St Ambroſe, Homo à Diabolo cum ſpoliaretur, non voluntate, ſed voluntatis ſanitate privatus eſt: And againe, A Diabolo iudicium voluntatis depravatum eſt, non ablatum. The iudgement of the Will is corrupted indeede, but not vtterly taken away: the Divell did not wholy bereaue man of his Will, but of the ſoundneſſe and integrity of it. Eligant are the words of St. Auſten herevpon, Let them not
Aug. de Correp. & Grat. c. 2. ſaith St Auſten, deceiue themſelues which ſay, to what purpoſe are we taught and commaunded to eſchew evill, and to doe good; If ſo be we cannot doe it, but as God doth work the ſame in vs even to wil, and to work? Nay rather let them vnderſtand, if they be the Children of God, that they are made pliable by Gods Spirit, to doe the things that ought to be done, and when they haue haue done ſo, to yeeld thankes to him by whome they were made ſo to doe. For they are made pliable becauſe they ſhould doe ſomething, not becauſe they ſhould doe nothing, thus St Auſten. But thus much of the Invitation, Let him come vnto me: now of the Parties invited, If any man thirſt.

Firſt for that Man here is only ſpecified, wee are not ſo to take it as if Women were excluded. This name Man in holy Scriptures
Clem Alex. Paedag. l. 1. c. 4. ſaith Clemens Alexandrinus, is commō to Men, and Women to. Father Latimer on a tyme when Dr
Weſton diſputed with him and aſked him where he found that a Woman ſhould receiue the Sacrament? I finde it ſaith he in the eleauenth Chapter to the Corinthians, where the words being thus, Probet ſeipſū homo: he aſked the Doctour againe what Gender Homo was? whereunto when it was replyed, that howſoeuer in Latine it were the common Gender, yet in Greeke it was 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and in the Latine, Seipſum, What then quoth Father Latimer, I trowe when the Woman touched our Saviour he ſpake not in the Feminine, but in the Maſculine Gender, Quis tetigit me? And Scio quòd aliquis me tetigit. The trewth is, that in Chriſt Ieſus there is nor Male nor Female, Gal 3.21. nor is there a Woman that truſteth in God, but is to haue an Hidden Man of the heart, 1 Pet. 3.4. A Poynt which for one Poſtſtellus obſerued not as he ſhould haue done, grew (they Vid. Geſn. Bibl. per Ioſiam Simlerum. ſay) to that Phrenſy, that he ſtuck not to mayntayne that Women as yet were not redeemd. I confes our Aduerſaryes the Papiſts caſt not this Mans Head in our Diſh, but by that you may be ſure hee was nor Lutherā, nor Calviniſt, nor Puritan, nor Proteſtant. Ieſuits Catech. makes him one Ieſuits Catech. lib. 1 c. 10. I feare me hee was a IESVITE. No marvell though our Engliſh Women be now adaies ſo enamored with them

A ſecond Point to bee obſerued here, is in that it is here ſaid: If any man thirſt: that is, High & Low, Rich & Poore, one with another, from the Exod. 11.5. Firſt borne of Pharaoh that ſitteth on his Throne, vnto the Firſt borne of the Maydſervant that is at the Mill. Harken, my beloued Brethren, Iam. 2.5. ſaith St Iames, Hath not God choſen the poore of this world that they ſhould be Rich in faith, and heyres of the kingdome which he promiſed to them that loue him? Yes it is even ſo, & that of S. Auſten is no leſſe remarkable for vs that are Schollers, Aug. Confeſſ, l 8. c. 8. Surgunt indocti, & coelum rapiunt, & nos cum, doctrinis noſtris ſine corde eccè vbi volutamur in carne & ſanguine? I need not engliſh it

A third Point to be obſerued, is that after ſuch a Feaſt as was the Feaſt of Tabernacles, wherein they dranke no
doubt more then vſually, (and it was lawfull for them ſo to doe, Nehem. 8.12.) our Saviour ſhould vſe at that time ſuch a ſpeech as this, If any man thirſt. Doubtleſſe it was to put them in mind, as what the true Thirſt was indeed, ſo what the true Quenching was. The true Thirſt indeed, is the Trouble and Terrour of Conſcience wrought by the feeling and ſenſe of Sinne, and of the wrath of God for the ſame, which therefore is tearmed Thirſt for becauſe it is ſo like to Thirſt. Hunger, as it is a deſire of that which is hot and moiſt: ſo Thirſt is a deſire of that which is both moiſt and cold. So grievous, and painefull to them that haue it, that though Death it ſelfe approacheth towardes them, and is ready to ſeaze vpon them once for al, yet wil they more complaine of that, then of any other Torment elſe. Extreame no doubt were the Agonies of our Saviour on the Croſſe, the Paines he ſuffered moſt exceſſiue, & yet as if they had al bin nothing to the Thirſt he did indure, he cōplaind not of thē a whit, of the other, he ſeem'd to doe, Sitio, ſaith he, I thirſt, Ioh. 19.28. Siſera in the Book of Iudges though he had had the loſſe of a foughtē Field, & ſaw almoſt no likelyhood, but that he ſhould looſe alſo his own life, yet was Sorrow with him ſo dry, as he reſpected not los of Life ſo much, that which he thē reſpected moſt, was the quenching of his thirſt, Giue me, ſaith hee, a little water to drinke, for I am thirsty, Iudg. 4.19. Famous was that murmuring of the Iſraelites againſt Moſes by reaſon of their Thirſt, Exod. 17.3. Wherefore haſt thou thus brought vs out of Egypt to kil vs, & our Children, & our Cattell with thirſt. And Sampſon, when he had ſlaine ſo many with the Iawbone of an Aſſe, he was ſore a thirſt, ſaith the Scripture, & calling on the Lord, Thou haſt given Iudg. 15.18. ſaith he, this great deliverance into the hand of thy Servant, and now ſhall I die for thirſt, and fall into the hands of the vncircumciſed? So it is, it is even ſo, nothing in ſuch a caſe more vnſupportable then Thirſt, and therefore Diana in the Ovid. Met. l. 6. Poet,
Hauſtus aquae mihi nectar erit, vitam
que fatebor
Accepiſſe ſimul,vitam dederitis in vndis.
She would eſteeme of a draught of water, as if they had given her an other Life. And is it not thus with a craſed Conſcience? are not the pangs of a troubled Cōſcience as grievous to be borne? The Spirit of a man Prov. 18.1. ſaith king Solomon, will ſuſtaine his infirmity: but a wounded Spirit who can beare it? Even as if he had ſaid, not one among a thouſand, witneſſe as good as ever were. David, the Prophet David, how did he ſing when time was, no man aliue a ſweeter noate, Pſ. 103.8. The Lord is full of compaſſion & mercy, long ſuffering, and of great goodneſſe. He will not alwaies be chyding, neither keepeth he his anger for ever. He hath not dealt with vs after our ſinnes, nether rewarded vs according to our wickednes. For looke how high the Heauen is in compariſon of the Earth, ſo great is his Mercy alſo, toward them that feare him. Looke how wide alſo the Eaſt is frō the Weſt, ſo far hath he ſet our Sinnes from vs. Yea like as a Father pittyeth his owne children, even ſo is the Lord mercifull to them that feare him. For he knoweth whereof we be made, he remembreth that we are but duſt. And againe in an other Pſ. 108 3. Pſalme, I will giue thankes vnto thee, O Lord, among the People, I wil ſing praiſes vnto thee among the Nations, for thy mercy is greater then the Heavens, and thy truth reacheth vnto the clowdes. And yet againe in an Pſ 145.8. other, The Lord is gracious and mercifull, long ſuffering, and of great goodnes. The Lord is loving vnto every man, and his mercy is over all his works. Yet let vs viſite him againe at ſome other time, and how ſhall we finde him all a mort? What paſſions? What penſiuenes? What bitterneſſe of Soule? Pſ. 77. • . Will the Lord abſent himſelfe for ever, and wil he be no more intreated? Is his mercie cleane gone for ever, and is his promiſe come vtterly to an end for evermore? Hath God forgotten to be gracious, & will he ſhut vp his loving kindnes in diſpleaſure? And againe in an other Pſ. 102.3. Pſalme, My daies are conſumed away like ſmoake, and my bones are burnt vp as it were a firebrand. My heart
is ſmitten downe, and withered like graſſe, ſo that I forget to eate my bread. For the voice of my groaning, my bones vvill ſcaree cleaue to my fleſh. I am become like a Pelicane in the wilderneſſe, & like an Owle that is in the deſert. I haue watched, & am even as it were a Sparrow, that ſitteth alone vpō the houſe top. Nay, he ſpake with the leaſt it ſeemes whē he ſpake of Groaning, his words in an other place are much more paſſionate, I am brought Pſal. 38.6. ſaith he, into ſo great trouble and miſery, that I go mourning all the day long. For my loynes are filled with a ſoare diſeaſe, and there is no whole part in my body. I am feeble and ſore ſmitten, I haue roared for the verie verie diſquietnes of my heart.

By this then that hath beene ſpoken, we may now gather who they are that are invited by our Saviour. Firſt, Men, and Women both, either Sex may be welcome. Secondly, Rich and Poore, and the Poore as welcome as the Rich. Thirdly, ſuch as are truely thirſty whether Men, or Women, or Rich, or Poore. I ſay, Truely Thirſty, that is, who are burthened with their Sinnes, & ſee nothing before their eyes but Death and Deſperation, and would ful faine be eaſed of them, and relie on our Saviour to that purpoſe. It is with our Saviour in ſuch a caſe, as it is with a full Mr Fentons Perfume againſt the Plague, p. B. 3. b.
Breaſt, which even aketh for deſire to giue the Milk which it hath, and welcome is the Child that can moſt hū gerly ſucke the ſame. We haue ſeene the Parties invited: the Feaſt is now to be ſerued in. Let him come vnto me and drinke. He that beleeueth in me, as ſaith the Scripture, out of his Belly ſhall flow Rivers of water of Life.

It is a world to ſee, how the whole World in theſe daies is given to Drinke, and how Senecaes Words are now verified, Sen. de Beneſ l. 1. c. 10. Habebitur aliquando Ebrietati honor, & plurimùm meri cepiſſe, virtus erit. The day ſhall come wherein Drunkenneſſe ſhall be had in high eſteeme, and it ſhall be accounted a point of Manhood to bee able to quaffe, and to carowſe. It was not many yeares agoe that our Nation much abhorred it in the beſt of our Friends the Hollanders,
inſomuch that Generall Hiſtory of the Netherlands tranſlated into Engliſh by M. Ed. Grimſtone. In a Diſcourſe of Adviſe to the Earle of Leiceſter there, p. 939. advice was giuen to his Excellency that then was Governour, by one (it ſhould ſeeme) that wiſht vs well, that the Engliſh ſhould endeavour to beare with thē for a fault that was ſo engrafted into them by nature, howſoever they Themſelues did deteſt it. Were that Wel-willer of ours now aliue, he might recal againe that Paſſage, ſo are the Times changed ſince, and we the Engliſh changed with them. Nor ſhould there need ſo much complaint in this kind, were Drunkenneſſe now adaies, but as it was in the Apoſtle S. Pauls time. Drunkenneſſe, in the Apoſtle S. Pauls time, it was but a Night-crow, & plaid (it ſeemes) leaſt in ſight, & therefore himſelfe to the Theſſalonians: They that ſleepe 1. Theſſ. 5.7. ſaith he, ſleepe in the night, & they that are drunken, are drunkē in the night. It riſeth now adaies with the Larke, and S. Peter ſhould he reaſon now, as once he did when time was: Act. 2.15. Theſe are not drunken as yee ſuppoſe, ſince it is but the third houre of the day (that is, Nine a clock before Noone) he ſhould haue more adoe to make his Reaſon ſound, then hee had to make the Creeple ſound, Act. 3.7. Nor doe I wrong Drunkenneſſe awhit, to ſay it riſeth with the Larke, ſeeing of Drunkards it may be ſaid what Tertullian Tertul. de. Cib. Iudaic p. 656. ſaith of the like in his daies, Quales iſtos Sol in occaſu reliquit, quos iam marcidos vino Oriens aſpicit: True it is, ſome of them ſee not, or Sun-riſing, or Sun-ſetting, but yet there are others of them that doe, if at the leaſt they may be ſaid to ſee, whom the Sunne ſees rather in that pickle: or rather HEE whoſe Eyes are Ecclus, 23 19. tenne thouſand times brighter, then the Sunne. Good God! that ſo baſe a Vice as this, ſo beaſtly, ſo beggerly (for you know our Engliſh Proverb, As drunk as a Beggar) ſhould dare to appeare in our Horizon, the Beauty of our Land, and that which is more in a Schollers habite, and that which is moſt, it ſhould take Degrees too. What? we to make our BODIES (thoſe glorious Temples of the Holy Ghoſt) but ſo many Barrells to hold Beere in? We to ſtriue to bee Tantò Nequiores, as Aug. de Verb Apoſtol. Ser. 4. p. 179. Quae gloria eſt, capere mulium? Cum penes te palma fuerit, & propinationes tuas ſtrati ſomno ac vomitantes recuſaverint, cum ſuperſtes toti Convivio fueris, cum omnes vic • ris virtute magnifica, ac nemo tam vini capax fuerit, vinceris à D • lia. Senec. Epiſt. l. 12. ep. 84. ſpeakes S. Auſten, quantò ſub poculo
Invictiores: the more conquering our Pots, the more conquered by Sinne? We to carry our ſelues more prophanely then ever Eſaw did, who ſold his Birth-right (& it was but a worldly Birth-right) for neceſſary Food, and Suſtenance, we our heavenly Birth-right, and that moſt vnneceſſarily, and all for a draught of Drinke? For what doe they elſe, Beloued, what doe they elſe doe, who drinke ſo roundly, and carowſe ſo profoundly, but ſpend their Birth right, and Patrimonies vpon the Spicket here in this world, and (which is the conſequence of ſuch drinking) ſleeping againe as ſoundly, giue that Roaring Lyon opportunitie, hee that walketh about (as S. Peter 1. Pet. 5.8. ſpeaketh) ſeeking whom he may devoure, giue that Roaring Lyon (I ſay) opportunity, to take them napping, and ſo to devoure them much more eaſily, then poſſibly otherwiſe he could haue done. Tull Offic l. 1 Vid, Ovid. Met l 4. & yet Strabo of that Fountaine, Salmacis fons neſcio quā obrem calumniatus, tanquā emolliens eos qui inde bibant Strabo l. 14. Salmacida Spolia ſine ſanguine & ſudore. Sure I am the Divell hath them already by the Throat, and when the Wolfe hath once the Sheepe at ſuch diſadvantage, you knowe what followeth. But to let theſe Tospots goe, or becauſe commonly they cannot well goe, to ſpeake in the Prophet Ier. 25.27. Ieremies phraſe, To let them drinke, and be drū ken, and ſpew, and fall, and riſe no more, becauſe of the ſword which the Lord will ſend among them: Let vs, Beloued, repaire to our Saviour, and ſeeing wee are invited to drinke with him, let vs ſee what it is to drinke with our Saviour Chriſt Ieſus, and what the Ingredients are of that Drinke. If any man thirſt, let him come vnto me, and drinke.

To drinke with our Saviour Chriſt, is no doubt to Beleeue in him, as himſelfe here expoundeth himſelfe in the words immediately following. He, ſaith our Saviour, that beleeveth in me, as ſaith the Scripture, out of his Belly ſhall flow Rivers of water of Life. Wel: & what is it then, to Beleeue in him? To Beleeue in our Saviour Chriſt, is Firſt, to know him: Secondly, to acknowledge him: Thirdly, to put our truſt, & confidence in him. We then know him, when we know him a Saviour: we then acknowledge him, when
wee acknowledge him our Saviour: we then put our truſt, & confidence in him, when we put our confidence in him in that reſpect, Except Ioh. 8.24. ſaith our Saviour, yee beleeue, that I am he, yee ſhall die in your Sinnes. And againe in an other Mark. 15.14 place, He that ſhall beleeue, and be baptized, ſhal be ſaved: but he that will not beleeue, ſhall be damned. You ſee Beloved, the conſequence then, both of Beliefe, and Vnbeliefe. And concerning the conſequence of Beliefe, it is that which is in this place ſpecified vnto vs in theſe words, that out of his Belly ſhal flow Rivers of water of Life, meaning no doubt life Eternall; Everlaſting, and Endleſſe life, which Everlaſting life what it is, if ſo be wee would faine know, wee may in ſome ſort take a ſcantling by this Life of ours we now enioy. Skin for skin Iob. 2.4. ſaith Sathan, & al that ever a man hath will he giue for his life. And therein I muſt needes ſay, as great a Lyar as Sathan is, hee belies Man never a whit. Amatur & qualiſcun
que . Vita iſta
Aug. de Temp. Ser. 113. p. 607. ſaith St Auſten, & ipſam qualemcun
que aerumnoſam, miſeram, finire homines timent, & paveſcunt. Bee this Life of ours never ſo meane ſaith he, yet no man aliue but loues it, and as miſerable, wretched, and painefull as it is, every man is loath to leaue it. And hence ſaith he, may wee rightly conſider, how we are to eſteeme of Life Everlaſting, for if this miſerable & wretched Life, and which of neceſſity muſt one day ende, is ſo much loved, and liked of vs, how is that other Life to be beloved, which ſhall never haue an end. Now as there are in the Booke of God a many divers and ſundry Attributes that are annexed to this Life, as firſt there is the Tree of Life, Rev. 2.7. thē, there is the Crown of Life, Rev. 2.10. then, there is the Booke of Life, Rev. 3.5. then, there is the Spirit of Life, Rev. 11.11. ſo is there nothing there ſo oftentimes mentioned, as is the Water, or Fountaine of Life: as Firſt, in this place, Ioh. 7.38. thē, in the Prophet Ieremy, Ier. 2.13. then, in the Prophet Zachary, Zach. 14.8. then, in the Revelation, and oftentimes there, as Rev. 7.17. Rev. 21.6. Rev. 22.17. And this is the Water indeede that can
moſt truely quench our thirſt. Whoſoever Ioh. 4.13. ſaith our Saviour, drinketh of this water (he meant the water of Iacobs Well, of the ſelfe ſame nature, and ſubſtance that everie other water is) whoſoever drinketh of this water, ſhall thirſt againe: but whoſoever drinketh of the water that I ſhall giue him ſhall never be more a thirſt: but the water that I ſhal giue him ſhall be in him a well of water, ſpringing vp into everlaſting Life. And thus much of our Saviours Sermon.

The next thing to bee conſidered, is as I tould you his Manner in making it, which is expreſſed in theſe words, Now in the laſt and great day of the Feaſt Ieſus ſtood & cryed: wherein I thought to haue obſerved theſe points: Firſt the Time he made it in: namely in the laſt and great day of the Feaſt: Secondly, his Geſture of Body, Ieſus ſtood: Thirdly, his Manner of ſpeaking, Ieſus stood & cryed. In the Firſt I had thought to haue obſerved that it was the Eight day, and as they beganne the Feaſt with ſuch godly Exerciſes, how they alſo ended it with the ſame. In the Second, how though our Saviour did vſually ſit & teach as the cuſtome was in thoſe times, yet here to his greater paine, how hee ſtood, and taught, according to that of St Auſten, Cum labore, ſtatis & auditis, ſed nos cum maiore ſtamus, et loquimur. You Aug. in Evan. Ioan. Tract. 19. ſaith St Auſten ſtand to heare vs preaching and I graunt it is a paine vnto you, but yet it is a greater paine for vs to ſtand and ſpeake. I had thought beſides to haue obſerved, that he both ſate and ſtood teaching, who is now ſaid both to ſtand, and ſet at Gods right hand. In the Third, I had thought to haue obſerued that notwithſtanding that of Eſay, Hee ſhould not cry, nor lift vp, nor cauſe his voice to be heard in the Street, Eſay, 42.2, yet how that was no preiudice to his crying, and lifting vp, & cauſing his voice to bee heard in the Temple: the Prophet in that place commending him, as a mild, and gentle Creature, the Evangeliſt in this, as a moſt excellent & earneſt Teacher. I had thought (I ſay) to haue obſerved all this: but the time haſtning as it doth, I alſo will haſten with it,
and come to the third Point I propoſed, the Evangeliſt his Noates vpon this Sermon, and thoſe I told you were in theſe words: This ſpake he of the Spirit which they that beleeved in him ſhould receiue. For the Holy Ghoſt was not yet giuen, becauſe that Ieſus was not yet glorified. The Noats are two: Firſt, and formoſt, the true meaning of our Saviours words in this place: Secondly, the Reaſon the Evangeliſt giues that that indeed was his meaning. Of either in their order, and Firſt of our Saviours meaning: This spake hee of the Spirit, which they that beleeved in him ſhoulde receiue.

That our Saviour in this place ſpake of the Spirit, that is, of the Holy Ghoſt, when he ſpake of Rivers of water of Life, doth intimate vnto vs the ſpeciall correſpondence betweene thoſe Rivers, and the Spirit. The holy Scriptures
Chryſoſt. in Evang. Ioan. Hom. 31. ſaith St Chryſoſtome, tearme the Grace of the holy Ghoſt ſomtimes, Fier, ſometimes, Water, to giue vs therby to vnderſtand, not his Subſtance, but his Working. For the Spirit ſaith he, conſiſteth not of different Subſtances (ſuch as Fier, and Water are) ſeeing he is inviſible, and only of one kind. The holy Ghoſt ſaith St Chryſoſtome, is called Fier, to ſignifie the ſhining of the Graces of God in vs, and the purging, and eating out of the droſſe of our Sins. And the ſame holy Ghoſt againe is called, Water, to ſignifie the waſhing, & cooling of vs. For as by Water ſaith hee, an Orchard is continually kept greene, and hath her Trees in due ſeaſon ſtill laden with fruit: ſo the holy Ghoſt dispoſeth our Orchards, even the Souls that are within vs, that no care and griefe of hart may at any time distract vs, no wyles, & traps of Sathā deceiue vs, but by vertue therof we may quēch his fiery darts whēſoeuer he throwes them at vs. Now the Holy Ghoſt is likened to Water, in three reſpects: Firſt, for that as the property of water is to cleanſe, and purifie the Body from ſuch filth and fowlenes as would otherwiſe cleaue vnto it, and therefore Diogenes of a water that was not all of the cleereſt, Qui hîc ſe lavant
Diog Laevt. de vil. & mor. Philoſ. l. 6. in Diog. ſaith he, vbi lavantur? They that waſh themſelues
in this water, where doe they waſh themſelues? Even ſo the Holy Ghoſt doeth ſpiritually waſh away our Sinnes, which are the Filth and Foulenes of our Soules, & wherewith as with menſtruous Clowts our Nature is defiled. Secōdly, for that as the wearied Travailer is ready to faint for want of water, and ſcantly able to go on forwards, and therefore one in the Virg. Eclo. 5. Poet,
Tale tuum Carmen nobis divine Poetae,
Quale ſopor feſſis in gramine, quale per aeſtum
Dulcis aquae ſaliente ſitim reſtinguere rivo:
and Hagar in the Gen. 21.16. Scriptures when the water of her Bottle was ſpent, caſt her Child vnder a Tree, and ſhee ſate downe her ſelfe over againſt him, and lift vp her voice & wept, ſo if we haue not this Spirit in vs, if we feele not the comfort of it, we fynde a continuall Fier in our Conſciences, we frye in our owne Fat. Thirdly, nothing ſo neceſſary as Fier, & Water, we can by no meanes be without them, and therefore among the Auncients, whom they condemned to Banniſhment, they forbad them Fier, & Water: ſo, nothing ſo neceſſary for vs, as this Fier, and Water, of the Spirit, & therfore our Saviour to Nicodemus, Ioh. 3 5. Verily, Verily, I ſay vnto thee, except a man be borne of Water, and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the Kingdome of God. And thus much of our Saviours meaning: now of the Reaſon the Evangeliſt giues, that our Saviours meaning thus was, and it is in the laſt words of my Text: For the Holy Ghoſt was not yet given, becauſe that Ieſus was not yet glorified.

Our Saviour as for our ſakes he came downe vnto vs from his Father, ſo the time was ſhortly to come, when hee ſhould returne againe vnto his Father. This Newes as it was exceeding dolefull to the eares of the Apoſtles, who could haue wiſhed to haue had him ſtil, their affection vnto him was ſo great: ſo to comfort them again for that his departure, being to leaue them Orphans in the world, he oftentimes promiſed to ſend vnto them the Holy
Ghoſt to be their Comfort. The Firſt & formoſt Promiſe in this kind made, is in the Goſpel of St Matthew, where our Saviour foretelling them that they ſhould bee delivered vp to Councels, and ſcourged in the Synagogues, and brought before Governours & Kings for his Names ſake, Take no thought Mat. 10.19. ſaith he, how, or what yee ſhall ſpeake, for it ſhall be given you in that hower, what yee ſhall ſay. For it is not yee that speake, but the Spirit of your Father which speaketh in you. So likewiſe at an other time, I, Ioh. 14.16. ſaith our Saviour, will pray the Father, and he ſhall giue you an other Comforter that he may abide with you for ever, even the Spirit of truth. And expreſſing a little after who this other Comforter ſhould be, The Comforter Ver. 26. ſaith he, which is the Holy Ghoſt, whō the Father will ſend in my Name, he ſhall teach you all things, & bring all things to your remembrance which I haue told you. So likewiſe at a third time, But when the Comforter Ioh. 15 26. ſaith he, ſhall come, whome I will ſend vnto you from the Father, even the Spirit of truth which proceedeth of the Father, he ſhall teſtifie of me. And againe in a fourth place, It is expedient for you Ioh. 16.7. ſaith our Saviour, that I goe away: for if I go not away the Comforter will not come vnto you, but if I depart, I will ſend him vnto you. And being now ready to aſcend into Heaven, & to take his leaue of the World concerning his corporall preſence, When hee had gathered Act. 1.4. ſaith St Luke, his Diſciples togither, he commanded them that they ſhould not depart from Ieruſalem, but to wait for the promiſe of the Father, which ſaid he, yee haue heard of me. For Iohn indeed baptized with water, but ye ſhal be baptized with the Holy Ghoſt within theſe few daies. And as he promiſed the ſame at that time, ſo ſhortly after fell it out. And when the day of Pentecoſi Act. 2. • . ſaith St Luke, was come, they were all with one accord in one place, and ſuddenly there came a ſound from heaven, as of a ruſhing and mightie Winde, and it filled all the houſe where they ſate. And there appeared vnto them cloven Tongues like Fier, and it ſate vpon each of them. And they were al filled with the Holy Ghoſt,
and began to ſpeake with other tongues as the Spirit gaue thē vtterance. And this it is, the memory wherof we celebrate this day. The Holy Ghost was then given them, and our Saviour before had beene glorified, ſo that when our Saviour ſpake theſe words, the Holy Ghoſt was not then given, becauſe that then he was not Spiritum noluit dare niſi cum eſſet glorificatus, vt in ſuo corpore oſtenderet vitam quam modo non habemus, ſed in Reſurrectione ſperamus. Aug. in Evang. Ioan. Tract. 32. p. 177. glorified.

No? will ſome man ſay, was not the Holy Ghoſt then given? Spake not the Patriarchs, and Moſes, & the Prophets by the Holy Ghoſt? Is it not expreſly ſaid of David, Mark. 12.36, that David spake by the Holy Ghost? Was it not foretold of our Savior Chriſt that he ſhould baptize with the Holy Ghoſt, Mat. 3.11? though Ieſus himſelfe baptized not, Iohn 4.2. Did he not long before this time breath vpon his Diſciples, and ſaid vnto them his owne ſelfe, Receiue the holy Ghoſt, Ioh. 20.22? It is true Beloved, ſo hee did, & the Holy Ghoſt I graunt was given before, to the Patriarches, and to the Prophets, and to Moſes, and to David, and to the Diſciples, & to many others, but it was not given in that meaſure that it was given now at this time. God at this time gaue ſo good a meaſure of the Holy Ghoſt vnto his Apoſtles, ſo preſſed downe, and ſhaken togither, running over into their boſomes, as Luk. 6.38. ſpeakes our Saviour in an other caſe, that ſome mocked, and Act 2.13. ſaid, they were full of new wine. Ridebant
Aug. de Temp. Ser. 186. p. 721. ſaith St Auſten, & aliquid verum dicebant. They mocked ſaith he, and yet for al that, ſomewhat was true of what they ſaid, for indeed they were as Veſſels fild with new wine. You heard ſaith he, in this daies Goſpell, that No man puts new Wine into olde Veſſels, a carnall man perceiveth not the things that are ſpirituall. They were full of new Wine, & the new Wine venting out, the Tongues of all Nations were immediatly ſet a float. I, but the Apoſtles having before received the Holy Ghoſt, to what end was this aboundance? I anſwere with the Aug. de Temp. Ser. 185. p. 719. ſame St Auſten: They had indeede Faith before, but the constancie of Faith they had not. Ʋ Ʋell they might haue preached Chriſt, but as yet to die for
Chriſt, that they hardly coulde. Inſomuch that before the comming of the Holy Ghoſt, not one of them all that had the Crowne of Martyrdome. Before the comming of the Holy Ghoſt about the time of our Saviours Paſſion, ſome of his Diſciples betooke themſelues to their heeles, ſome ſo terrified with a ſilly gyrle that they flatly denied their Lord & Maſter: but after the comming of the Holy Ghoſt, and that they were confirmed by that good Spirit, howſoever they were impriſoned, and had whipping cheere for their labour, yet they reioyced that they were counted worthy to ſuffer rebuke for Chriſt his Name. He feared not afterwards, Rome,
Leo in Nat. Petri & Paul Ser. 1. ſaith Leo, the Lady of the World, who in the houſe of Caiphas the High Prieſt was afraid of a ſilly Wench. And thus much of our Saviours Sermon here, his Manner in making it, and the Evangeliſt his Notes therevpon. I ſhould now come with my owne Notes, and gather out of the ſeverall Premiſſes, ſeverall Inſtructions, and Obſervations: but for wee are ſome of vs here preſent to participate of theſe Myſteries, the BLESSED SACRAMENT here before vs, a word or two to that purpoſe, and then God willing an end.

There was a Time and ſome now preſent may remember it very well, when theſe Creatures of Bread, and, Wine were ſo dignified, I, deified, in Church Aſſemblies, that he was counted then no Chriſtian, that would not ſay to the Bread, and Wine, at leaſt wiſe to a Wafer, that which ſome ſaid in the Prophet Ieremies time to a Tree, & to a Stone, Thou art my Father, thou haſt begotten me, Ier. 2.27. They that ſaw the ſame then in thoſe daies, haue liued now to ſee the caſe ſo altered, that it is almoſt now at another Extreame, and theſe Elements of Bread, and Wine, are ſo vilified, I, nullified, among a many, that he is accounted now no Chriſtian neither, or at the leaſt wiſe a Popiſh Chriſtian, that will not ſpeake as contemptuouſly of that Bread, and Wine, vpon the Table, after the wordes of Conſecration, as King Ezechias did of the Braſen Serpent when hee
cald it Nehuſhtan, a peece of Braſſe, 2. King. 18.14. That wee, Beloued, may the better beare our ſelues betweene theſe two Extreames, and take an even courſe in the middle way, not to high for the (Popiſh) Pye, nor to low for the carrion Crow, it will not be amiſſe to harken to HER who hath more then Motherly authoritie over vs, and by whoſe breeding and bringing vp, we are what we are, evē Epheſ. 2 19. Citizens with the Saints, and of the Houſhold of God. She then Catechiſing vs at the firſt: What, Communion Booke in the Catech. ſaith She, is the outward part, or Signe of the Lords Supper? And Shee teacheth vs to anſwere, Bread, and Wine, which the Lord hath commanded to be receaued. And when Shee asketh vs againe, What is the inward part, or thing ſignified? Shee teacheth vs againe to anſwere: The Body and Blood of Chriſt, which are verily, and indeed, taken and receaued of the Faithfull in the Lords Supper. In her Art. 28. Articles She ſpeaketh thus: To ſuch as rightly, worthily, and with faith receaue (the Supper of the Lord▪) the Bread which we breake is a partaking of the Body of Chriſt, & likewiſe the Cup of Bleſſing, is a partaking of the Bloud of Christ. And againe, The Body of Chriſt is giuen, taken, and eaten in the Supper, only after an heauenly, & ſpirituall manner. In her Apology of the Church of England, c. 13. Diviſ. 1. Apologie thus: The Bread and Wine are the holy, and heavenly Myſteries of the Body, and Blood of Christ, and by them Chriſt himſelfe, being the true Bread of eternall Life, is ſo preſently giuen vnto vs, as that by Faith we verily receaue his Body, and his Bloud. All commeth to this reckning: THEY WHICH WORTHELY RECEAVE THIS SACRAMENT, RECEAVE THE VERY BODIE AND BLOVD OF CHRIST: For the better manifeſting whereof, let vs Firſt of all ſee what it is to receaue worthely. Secondly, how the very Body and Bloud of Chriſt is receaued.

What it is to receaue worthely, the Apoſtle S. Paul wil inſtruct vs, in his firſt Epiſtle to the Corinthians, who whē he had there ſaid: Whoſoever ſhall eate this Bread, & drinke the cup of the Lord vnworthely, ſhall bee guiltie of the Bodie
and Blood of the Lord, immediatly 1. Cor. 11.28 annexeth therevnto, Let a man therefore examine himſelfe, and ſo let him eate of this Bread, & drinke of this Cup. So that the way (you ſee) to be a worthie Receauer is to examine a Mans owne ſelfe before he preſume to come and taſt of theſe myſteries. Let a Man, ſaith the Apoſtle: that is Man, or Woman, it mattereth not whether Sex, ſince Gal. 3.28. both are one in Chriſt Ieſus. Let a Man; that is, hee muſt: not as it is in my Text, If any man thirſt let him come, remitting it to his owne wil, whether come he would or no (as I told you) but, Let him, that is, he ought, there is a Neceſſitie laid vpon him, & woe vnto him if he doth it not, as 1. Cor. 9.19 ſpeakes the Apoſtle in another caſe. Examine; that is, from point to point, ſeeking one by one, as did the Eccleſ 7.29. Preacher to find the count. Himſelfe; not another, no, that was Peters fault to bee inquiſitiue after others. Lord, Ioh. 21.21. ſaith Peter, what ſhall this man do? What, ſaith our Saviour, is that to thee? follow thou me.
Ole quid ad te Martial. Epig, l. 7. epig. 9. Petre quid ad te? Peter what hadſt thou to doe, whether Iohn ſhould liue or die? If I will, ſaith our Saviour, that hee tary till I come, what is that to thee? Follow thou mee. Let a mā therfore examine himſelfe. For indeed to ſay the truth, every of vs in this caſe, is a Iuſtice of Peace, and Quorum too. It is that which the Prophet David ſaith, Pſ. 4.4, Stand in awe, and ſinne not: commune with your owne heart, and in your chamber, and be ſtill. And ſhewing vnto vs his owne example, I powre out my heart by my ſelfe, ſaith he, Pſ. 42.4. and Pſal. 77.6, I call to remembrance my ſong, ſaith he, and in the night I commune with mine owne heart, & ſearch out my spirits. Commune wee then with our owne Hearts, or in our Chambers, or vpon our Beds, ſearch wee out our owne Spirits, let vs powre out our Hearts by our ſelues. Nor let vs doe it Noli ſuperficiem compal • pare Aug. de Temp. Ser. 214. p. 761. ſuperficially, but diſcuſſe wee our owne Diſcute conſcientiam tuam, aſcende Tribunal mentis tue, noli tibi parcere Aug. in Pſ. 101 p. 784. Conſciences, let vs ſet our ſelues downe vpon the iudgement ſeat of our owne Hearts, and in no wiſe bee partiall to our ſelues. Examine we our EYES, our EARES, our HANDS, our TONGVES, our FEET, and cauſe we all, and
every of them, to giue account of their Stewardſhip. No Man here, be he never ſo meane, no Woman whatſoever, but hath ever about them this Retinue. What? are they all of them out of frame? is there none of them good, no not one? Then haſt thou Ioh. 19.10. Pilats Powre over them, either to crucifie, or to looſe thē: that is, if they prooue themſelues to be Sinnes of Infirmitie only, then to chaſten them and let them looſe, as hee would haue done by our Saviour, Ioh. 19.12. If Sinnes of Iniquitie & greater Conſequence, if great and grieuous Crymes, vaſtantia Conſcientiam, as Aug. de Civ. De. l. 11. c. 12. ſpeakes S. Auſten, deſtroying & waſting our very Conſcience, let vs, or, mortifie them, as ſpeakes the Apoſtle, Coloſſ. 3.5. or, as our Saviour giues vs counſaile, let vs cut off their chiefeſt inſtruments, and caſt them away from vs, Mat. 5.30. Eyes muſt out, and Hands muſt off, I, Cor ipſum revellendum, to ſpeake in Senecaes
Senec. Epiſt. l. 7. ep. 52. phraſe, wee muſt out with Heart and all, & pray with the Create in me a cleane heart, o God; and renew a right Spirit within mee, Pſ. 51.10. Our laſt Tranſlat. Prophet David to create a New one in vs. And thus much of the firſt Point what it is to receaue worthely.

How the very Body and Blood of Chriſt is now at this time to bee receaued, conſidering our Senſes tell vs that what we receaue is Bread, and Wine; we muſt of neceſſity haue in this caſe the Help of FAITH to direct vs, or wee ſhall riſe againe as wee came, if not depart from hence a great deale worſe. Now what Faith is able to do, we need goe no farther then to thoſe words of our Saviour Chriſt, who ſpeaking of Faith vnto his Apoſtles: Verily I ſay vnto you, Mat. 17.20. ſaith hee, if yee haue Faith as much as is a graine of muſtard ſeed, ye ſhal ſay vnto this Mountaine remooue hence to yonder place, and it ſhall remooue, and nothing ſhall bee impoſſible vnto you. And to ſhew that they ſhould bee as potent as well by Sea, as by Land: If yee had faith, Luk. 17.6. ſaith he, as much as is a graine of muſtard-ſeed, and ſhould ſay vnto this Mulbery tree, Plucke thy ſelfe vp by the roots, and plant thy ſelfe in the Sea, it ſhould even obey you. Of the Muſtard-ſeed hee had told them Mat. 13.31. before, that it was the leaſt of all
Seeds: and yet Faith but of that ſmall quantitie, what workes of qualitie brings it forth? Nay what doth it not bring forth, ſince as the Apoſtle Heb. 11.3. ſpeakes to the Hebrews: It ſubdueth kingdomes, workes righteouſneſſe, obtaines the promiſes, ſtops the mouthes of Lyons, quencheth the violence of fire, makes vs to eſcape the edge of the ſword, of weake makes vs ſtrong, makes vs valiant in battaile, and turnes to flight the Armies of the Aliants. And doth Faith, Beloued, all this, Really and Truely: & doe our Adverſaries the Papiſts ſtill ſcoffe at vs when we ſay we eate as truly, and really, the Body of our Saviour here by Faith, and by Faith drinke his Bloud?

Why, but thou wilt ſay, If this bee all, what need then this Bread and Wine? This, without theſe may well bee done: we may every day feed of our Saviours Body, and of his Bloud in this ſort. It is true, Beloued, ſo we may, and ſo wee doe: howbeit, as S. Ierom Hieron. Palino. ſpeakes in another caſe, Habet neſcio quid latentis
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
viva vox: & in aures Diſcipuli de Autoris ore tranfuſa fortius ſonat: The voice of a Speaker is much more forcible to the eares of him that heares, then when the Hearer reads it himſelfe: right ſo may we ſay in this caſe, wee are much more mooued by an heavenly Force, when we See, & Receaue, theſe very Elements, then when as otherwiſe they are out of ſight. Beſides that our Saviour Chriſt ſince he hath beene pleaſed to vſe theſe Meanes to the purpoſe of enioying him, and hath commanded vs to doe as himſelfe did, vntil his next comming againe, duty requireth at our hands that we in no wiſe neglect him, nor what in this eaſe hee hath enioyned vs, eſpecially in a matter of ſuch moment. Naaman no doubt might haue beene healed of the Leproſie he had, had he never waſhed in Iordan, would the Prophet Eliſha but haue ſpoken the word: but when that other word was once gone out: 2. Kin. 5.10. Goe and waſh thee in Iordan ſeaven times, and thy Fleſh ſhall come againe vnto thee, and thou ſhalt be cleanſed, was it for Naaman to diſpute whe •…

〈…〉
•… tecoſt commonly called Whitſontide, were the only two Times of old wherein Baptiſme was adminiſtred. Hence it was that whereas other Holy Dayes haue all ſome reference to our Saviour Chriſt, and haue accordingly their M. Hooker Eccleſiaſt. Pol. l. 5. §. 70. p. 195. Names; as Firſt, the Annuntiation of his Birth by Angelical Embaſſage, commonly called our Lady Day. Secondly, his bleſſed Nativitie it ſelfe, commonly called Chriſtmas, (though there are that will not ſo ſpeake, for feare of I wot not what feare, happily that the Pſalmiſt Pſ. 53.6. ſpeakes of, They were afraid where no feare was, ſure I am, where none is) Thirdly, the miniſtery of his Legall Circumciſion commonly called, Newyeerſday: Fourthly, the teſtification of his true Incarnation by the Purification of Her which brought him into the world, commonly called Candlemas day: Fiftly, his Reſurrection: Sixtly, his Aſcention: Seaventhly, the admirable ſending downe of his Spirit, commonly called Whitſunday, and (which conſequently enſued) the notice of that incomprehenſible Trinitie thereby giuen to the Church of God, commonly called Trinitie Sunday: Eightly, his Glorification in his Saints which had the honour to ſuffer for his ſake before they had age and abilitie to knowe him; commonly called St Innocents day; in St Stephen that did knowe him; in thoſe Sages of the Eaſt that came to adore him, commonly called the Epiphany, or the Twelfe Day; in Iohn the Baptiſt; in the Apoſtles; his Glorification in the Angels, as in Michael, and in all thoſe happy Saints that are already poſſeſſed of heaven: whereas I ſay theſe Holydaies, haue all of them reference to our Saviour, and haue accordingly their names: To Morrow, and the Next Day after, to bee annexed to this Feaſt, & the Firſt Two Dayes in Whitſonweeke, haue no proper and peculiar Names giuen vnto them, but are annexed to This Feaſt, as alſo to the Other, by reaſon of Baptiſme then adminiſtred, and vſuall at thoſe two times.

Of Baptiſme then at this time, and for our better proceeding therein may you be pleaſed to reviſe the wordes
againe, even now read vnto you. Knowe yee not that all we which haue beene baptiſed into Ieſus Chriſt, haue beene baptiſed into his Death? we are buried then with him by Baptiſme into his Death, that like as Chriſt was raiſed vp from the dead, by the glory of the Father, ſo wee alſo ſhould walke in newneſſe of life.

In which wordes, I obſerue and note vnto you two principall Points. Firſt, a Propoſition: Secondly, a Conſequence therevpon. The Propoſition is here ſet downe by way of interrogation, and it is in effect this: All wee which haue beene baptiſed into Ieſus Chriſt, haue beene baptiſed into his death. The Conſequence in that which followeth: We are buried then with him by Baptiſme into his Death, that like as Chriſt was raiſed vp from the dead, by the glory of the Father, ſo we alſo ſhould walke in newneſſe of life. The Propoſition is here ſet downe by way of interrogation, for that it is a Truth that may by no meanes bee denyed. The Oratour will tell vs ſo much, Interrogamus etiam,
Quintil. Inſtit. l 9. c. 2. ſaith hee, quod negari non poſſit: VVee ſometimes aske in ſuch ſort, as wee know that the Anſwerer cannot poſſibly denie it. Thus our Saviour to his Apoſtles, when I ſent you Luk. 22.35. ſaith he, without Bag, and Scrip, and Shooes, lacked yee any thing? Wel hee knew they wanted not, and they themſelues indeed confeſt as much. And againe, to thoſe two Diſciples going vnto Emaus, Cleophas and the other (St Ambroſe cals him Ambr. Ser. 1. p. 275. & Apol. David. p. 399. Amaon, or Serm. 71. p. 365. Amaus) O Fooles Luk. 24.25. ſaith he, and ſlow of heart to beleeue all that the Prophets haue spoken, ought not Chriſt to haue ſuffered theſe things, and to enter into his glory? Thus this our Apoſtle alſo in an other place, ſpeaking of the other Sacrament, The Cup of Bleſſing which we bleſſe 1. Cor. 10.16. ſaith he, is it not the Cō munion of the Bloud of Chriſt? The Bread which we breake, is it not the Communion of the Body of Chriſt? Doubtleſſe it was ſpoken more ſignificantly, then if he had ſaid which indeed he meant: The Cup of Bleſſing which we bleſſe, and the Bread which we breake, are the Communion of the
Bloud, and of the Body of Chriſt. So likewiſe here in this place: Know yee not that all we which haue been baptized into Ieſus Chriſt, haue beene baptiſed into his Death? It is, as if he had ſaid: This is a true 1. Tim. 1.15 ſaying, & by all meanes worthy to be received: I 1. Cor. 10 15 ſpeake as vnto them which haue vnderſtāding, iudge yee what I ſay: If there 2. Ioh. 1.10. come any vnto you, & bring not this Doctrine, namely, That All we which haue beene baptized into Ieſus Chriſt, haue beene baptized into his Death, receiue him not to houſe, neither bid him God ſpeed.

Having thus reſolved theſe words, I hold it now fit I ſhew vnto you, Firſt, what Baptiſme is: Secondly, what it is to be baptized into Ieſus Chriſt: Thirdly, what it is to bee baptized into his Death. Theſe three Points thus handled, the Propoſition will be evident, being this (as I ſaid) in effect: All we which haue beene baptized into Ieſus Chriſt haue beene baptized into his Death. Firſt then what Baptiſme is: Know yee not that all we which haue beene baptized into Ieſus Chriſt, haue beene baptized into his Death?

Baptiſme is a Greeke word, and ſignifieth a Bathing, or a Waſhing, & ſo is vſed both by the Heathen Writers, and by the Evangeliſts themſelues. I ſhall not need now at this time to produce the Heathen to this purpoſe. As touching the Evangeliſts, St Marke may ſtand for al, who ſpeaking of the Iewes and Phariſees, When they come Mark. 7.4. ſaith he, from the Market,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , except they waſh they eate not, & many other things there be, which they haue taken vpon them to obſerue, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the waſhings of Cups, and Pots, Braſen Veſſels, & of Tables. So the Vulgar doth read it to, Niſi baptiſentur, non comedunt: and Baptiſmata Calicum, & Vrceorum, & Aeramentorum, & Lectorum, which the Rhemiſts interpret thus: And from the Market, vnleſſe they bee waſhed, they eate not: and many other things there be that were delivered vnto thē to obſerue, the waſhings of Cups, and Cruſes, and of Braſen Veſſels, and Beds. Where by the way, Beloved, it may be wondred that our Rhemiſts treading ſo oftentimes the
ſelfe ſame Steps that the Vulgar doth (their Fathers of Trent ſuppoſing the Muſes, nay that God himſelfe ſpake in that goodly Dialect, and not as Quint. Inſtit. l. 10. c. 1. Varro would haue thought, in Plautus his, had they ever ſpoken Latine) it may be wondred I ſay, they trāſlated it not, The Baptiſmes of Braſen Veſſels, doubtleſſe it would haue chimed wondrous well with Baptiſing of their Vid. D. Willets Synopſ. p. 493. Edit. 1600 P. Martyris Loc. Com. Claſſ. 4. Loc. 9. Durant. de Rit. Eccle. l. 1. c. 22. § 6. p. 177. Even Tom of Chriſtchurch was chriſtned to, but D. Treſham it ſeemeth tooke him for a Wench, of whom D. Hūfrey ſaith: Quā ille (Treſhamus) vt ad Miſſam clarè vocaret, ante paucos dies reparatam, novo nomine donavit, & Mariā baptizavit. Humfred. Vit. Iuelli. p. 81. Bels. But to returne vnto my purpoſe.

Baptiſme ſignifying a Bathing, or a Waſhing of the Fleſh, it is not vnknown to thē that are converſant in holy Writ, that there were in the time of the Law diverſe & ſundry kindes of Waſhings. All which for that they were Shadowes of Chriſt to come, and Appurtenances to the Sacrifices for Sinne, and Tranſgreſſion, and the often Repeating thereof, declaring their Imperfection; hence it was that when Chriſt was come, in liew & ſteed of them, there ſhould come with him an other kinde of Waſhing never to be reiterated againe, to wit a Sacrament of that Waſhing, that is but once, & done for ever. And therefore Aug. in Evan. Ioan. Tract. 11. p. 68. St Auſten, Quomodo Vterus non poteſt repeti, ſic nec Baptiſmus: And againe in an other Aug. in Evan. Ioan. Tract. 12. p. 72. place, Sicut ad Nativitatem carnalem valent muliebria Viſcera ad ſemel pariendum: ſic ad Nativitatem ſpiritalem valent Viſcera Eccleſiae vt ſemel quiſ
que baptiſetur. Nor can a man be Borne twiſe, nor twiſe Baptiſed. And as in reſpect of carnall Nativity the Mothers Wombe is of force to bring forth once, and but once: ſo the Womb of the Church in reſpect of ſpirituall Nativity. And thus much of the Name of Baptiſme, go we now to the Nature of it.

Concerning Baptiſme, our Mother the Church hath Booke of Articles, Art. 27. taught vs to ſpeake in this wiſe: Baptiſme is not only a ſigne of Profeſſion, and marke of difference, whereby Chriſtian Men are diſcerned from others that be not chriſtned: but it is alſo a ſigne of Regeneration, or New Birth, whereby as by an Inſtrument, they that receiue Baptiſme rightly, are grafted into the Church; the promiſes of the forgiueneſſe of
Sinne, and of our adoption to be the Sonnes of God, by the Holy Ghost, are viſibly ſigned and ſealed; Faith is confirmed, & Grace increaſed by vertue of Prayer vnto God. Baptiſme then ſuch a Sacrament, what doth it elſe but ſigne vnto vs, that we are as certainely waſhed from our Sinnes by the Bloud of Ieſus Chriſt, as our Bodies are certainely waſhed, or ſprinckled with Water. So Tertullian, Abluitur caro
Tert. de Carnis Reſurrect. ſaith he, vt Anima emaculetur. The Fleſh is waſhed, that the Soule may be cleanſed: and St Auſten to this purpoſe, From whence
Aug. in Evan. Ioan. Tract. 80. p. 303. ſaith he, hath this Water ſo great a vertue, that it but toucheth the Body, and waſheth the Soule, but by reaſon of the Word, not in that it is spoken, but beleeved. And hence it is that Tertullian cals Chriſtians, FISHES. Wilde Beaſts
Tertull. de Baptiſmo p 597 ſaith he, and Vypers, and Aspes, and Cockatrices, they are in loue with dry places, and thoſe that are waterleſſe: but let vs little Fiſhes according to our great
Secundum
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
noſtrum Ieſum Chriſtum. Alluding to thoſe Acroſticke Verſes of Sibil wherof St. Auſten De Civ. Dei. l. 18. c. 23 Fiſhes example Ieſus Christ, be borne in water. Nec aliter quàm in aqua permanendo ſalui ſumus. Neither out of that Element can we poſſibly be in ſafety. He alludeth by all likelyhood to that of our Mark. 16.16 Saviour: He that ſhall beleeue, and be baptized, ſhall be ſaved: but he that will not beleeue, ſhall be damned: And againe to Ioh. 3.5. Nicodemus: Verely, verely, I ſay vnto thee, except that a man be borne of Water, and of the Spirit, he can not enter into the kingdome of God. And hence it is, that we are taught by the Apoſtle St Paule Epheſ. 5.26. that by the waſhing of Water through the Word, God doth ſāctifie & cleanſe his Church: that we are Heb. 10.22. ſprinkled in our hearts frō an evil conſcience, & waſhed in our Bodies with pure water, not that the Baptiſme which ſaveth vs is (as Legal Purifications were) a cleanſing of the Fleſh from outward impurity, but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , 1. Pet. 3.21. Vid Mr Hooker Eccleſ. Pol. l. 5. § 63. p 152. as S. Peter ſpeaketh, an interrogatiue triall of a good Conſcience toward God. Nor is this Sanctifying, and Cleanſing of vs, in regard only of the Time preſent, but in regard of the Time that is paſt alſo, as alſo of the Time to come: according to which three Times the Scripture ſo ſpeakes of Baptiſme as if it intimated ſo much, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
He hath ſaved vs, Tit. 3.5. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , That now ſaveth vs, 1. Pet. 3.21. And 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , He ſhalbe ſaved, Marc. 16.16. Nor is this Sanctifying, and Clenſing in part, but in whole. And therefore, He,
Chryſ in 1. Cor. 15. Ho •… , 40. ſaith S. Chryſoſtom, that is baptiſed, hath his Soule more pure, then the Beames of the Sunne it ſelfe, even as pure as when it was created at the firſt. And as the workman, ſaith hee, by melting Iron, or Gold, doth make it pure, & new: ſo the Holy Ghoſt in Baptiſme, as it were in a Furnace, doth poliſh the Soule, & forme it anew, and by conſuming ſinne, makes it more purely bright-ſome then any Gold whatſoever. Which yet is not ſo to bee taken, as if we were not every day to be more & more purified, and cleanſed more and more, Iam vos mundi eſtis,
Aug. in Evan. Ioan Tract. 80. p. 303. ſaith S. Auſten, mundi ſcilicet, at
que mūdandi, You are now ſaith he, Cleane; Cleane, and to be Cleanſed: For had they not beene Cleane, ſaith hee, they could not haue brought forth fruit at all, and yet every Branch that beareth fruit, the Husbandman Ioh. 15.2. purgeth it, that it may bring forth more fruit.

And here, Beloued, let vs conſider a while, Firſt, the great Goodneſſe of our God that vſeth this very Element ſo greatly now adaies vnto our Good. For if ſo be we bee remembred, this is the Element wherein his Wrath was once declared, when as hee Gen. 7.17. drowned with it the whole World. It was as Moſes Rod when as it was Exod. 4.3. turned into a Serpent. It was as S. Paul before his Converſion, Act. 9.1. making havock of a World of men. I, as Ananias ſpake of St Paul, but not a Saint then: Ver. 13. Lord, I haue heard by many of this man, how much evill he hath done to thy Saints at Ieruſalem: right ſo, Beloued, may we ſay, Lord we haue heard by many of this Element how much evill it hath done, and is it poſſible it ſhould now be ſo great a Bleſſing vnto Man? But what cannot he worke that commands 2 Cor. 4.6. Light out of Darkneſſe: & what will he not worke for our ſakes, who can Pſal 66.5. turne the Sea it ſelfe, into dry Land.

Secondly, let vs call to mind what baſe meanes the Lord
imployeth in ſo honourable a worke as this is. For what is more common and vſuall then Water, and what of leſſe eſteeme, eſpecially then common Water.
— Ovid. Met. l. 6. Vſus communis Aquarum eſt:
Nec Solem proprium Natura, nec Aera fecit,
Nec tenues Vndas.
None are Lords Proprietaries of Water, Sunne, and Ayre. True it is, in want thereof nothing more made of, but where there is great plentie, nothing againe ſo little eſteemed. And yet ſee, Beloued, even in this, the good Pleaſure, and Purpoſe of God, who hath 1. Cor. 1.27 choſen the Fooliſh things of the world, to confound the Wiſe, and the Weake things of the world, to confound the Mighty things, and Ʋile things of the World, and things which are deſpiſed hath God choſen, and things which are not, to bring to naught things that are, that no Fleſh ſhould reioyce in his preſence. Thus the Midianites overthrowne by Gedeon, what was the Cauſe inſtrumentall, but as it were a Barly Loafe, even Lamps in one hand, & Trumpets in the other, Iudg. 7.20? Sampſons weapon that he ſlew ſo many withall, what was it but an Aſſes iawbone, Iudg. 15.16? With the Iaw of an Aſſe, ſaith he, are heapes vpon heapes: with the Iaw of an Aſſe haue I ſlaine a thouſand men. Goe wee to the other Sacrament, & is the Subſtance of it any more then a Morſell of Bread, and a Draught of Wine? And yet hath it pleaſed our Saviour to ſay, This is my Body, This is my Bloud, Mat. 26.26. But now to proceed onwards.

You haue ſeene, Beloued, what Baptiſme is, the Name, and the Nature of it: in the next place we are to ſee, what it is to be baptized into Ieſus Chriſt: Knowe yee not that all we which haue beene baptized into Ieſus Christ, haue beene baptized into his death?

To be baptiſed into Ieſus Chriſt, is to profeſſe our ſelues to hold of him, to addict our ſelues, Bodies, and Soules to the honour of his Name, Communion Booke in Publique Baptiſme. to confeſſe the Faith of Chriſt crucified, and manfully to fight vnder his Banner, againſt
Sinne, the World, and the Divell, & to continue his Faithfull Souldiers, and Servants, vnto our liues ends. Doubtleſſe there is no other Name wherevnto we are, or ought at all, to be baptiſed. And therefore the Apoſtle S. Paul: Is Chriſt, ſaith he, divided? was Paul crucified for you? 1. Cor. 1.13 either were yee baptiſed into the Name of Paul? No doubtleſſe, & therefore all thoſe whom S. Paul himſelfe did beget to Chriſt, or any other of the Apoſtles, Non Paulianos,
Aug. in Pſ 44 p. 281. ſaith S, Auſten, aut Petrianos, ſed Chriſtianos nominaverunt: They named them not Paulians of Paul, or Petrians of Peter, but Chriſtians, of our Saviour Chriſt. And this is that Iam 2 7. Worthy Name after which we be now named. This it was that begā at Antioch, for Act. 11.26. there the Diſciples were firſt of all called CHRISTIANS, & this it is that ever ſince hath laſted in the World, and ſo ſhall it ever doe, as long as the World ſhall laſt. Nor is it a Name only, but diverſe and ſundry Prerogatiues, which wee all of vs haue by reaſon of BAPTISME. St. Chryſoſtome Chry. Tom. 5. Hom. ad Neophit. reckons them to bee theſe. Firſt, in that wee are Gal. 5,1. Free: Secondly, in that we are 1. Cor. 6.11 Sanctified: Thirdly, in that we are Ibid. Iuſtified: Fourthly, in that we are Ioh. 1.12. Sonnes: Fiftly, in that we are Rom. 8.17. Heires: Sixtly, in that wee are Rom. 8.29. Brethren with Chriſt: Seaventhly, in that wee are Rom. 8.17. Coheires with him: Eightly, in that we are his 1. Cor. 6.15 Members: Ninthly, in that we are the 1. Cor. 3.16. Temples of God: Tenthly, and laſtly, in that wee are the Epheſ. 5.18.
Ʋeſſels of the Holy Ghoſt. All this will the better appeare if ſo bee wee call to minde thoſe ſeverall ſtyles of Honour giuen to Baptiſme by the ancient Fathers. Dioniſius, hee Dioniſ. Eccl. Hierarch. c. 2. calls it, the Mother of adoption:
Baſil. Hom. 13 S. Baſil, the Grace of adoption:
Clem. Alex. Poed. l. 1. c. 6. Clemens Alexandrinus, Medicamentum Poeonium, A Soveraigne Salue: Chryſoſt in Hom ad Bapt. S. Chryſoſtome, Ʋitae huius Purgatorium: The purging place, or Furnace of this Life: Ambr. de Sac. l. 1. c. 14. S. Ambroſe; Paſcha Chriſtianorum, The Chriſtian mans Eaſter, or Reſurrection: Gregory Nazianzen, he heapes together a number of Appellations, and all (as hee thinkes) too little too. Baptiſme,
Naz in Sanct Baptiſm. ſaith S. Gregory, is the Beau •…
〈…〉

〈…〉
Faithfull to be baptized into the Death of Chriſt, is as much to ſay, as that by the Death of Chriſt, Sinne in them did die, and was vtterly aboliſhed. So that we may now ſpeake of our Soules, and Bodies in Baptiſme, as doth the Apoſtle St Paul of 1. Cor. 15.24. Bodies in the Reſurrection of the Dead: They are ſowne in corruption, & they are raiſed in incorruption. They are ſowne in diſhonour, and they are raiſed in glory. They are ſowne in weaknes, & they are raiſed in power. They are ſowne as Naturall, and they are rayſed Spirituall: for they are both of them ſealed with the Holy Spirit of Promiſe, Eph. 1.13. And therefore St Auſten, Sed tu Domine miſericordiſſime
Aug Confeſſ. l. 9. c. 2. p. 107. ſaith he, nonne & hoc Peccatum cum caeteris horrendis & funereis in Aqua Sancta ignoviſti, & remiſiſti mihi? But, oh moſt mercifull Lord, ſaith St Auſten, haſt not thou forgiven, and remitted vnto me this Sinne, and all other my horrible and deadly Sinnes beſides, in that ſacred Water of Holy Baptiſme? Hee knew no doubt hee was forgiven them, and therefore in an other place: Quid retribuam Domino
Aug Confeſſ. l. 2 c. 7. p. 57. ſaith he, quòd recolit haec Memoria mea, & Anima mea non metuit inde? What ſhall I render to the Lord, that theſe my Sinnes paſt, thus come oftentimes to minde, and yet my Soule feares them not. Now as St Auſten, ſo wee: we haue committed like Sinnes; we haue offended the ſame Lord; Our Memory recals them often to minde, and yet for all that, we feare them not. Why? For that there is No condemnatiō to them that are in Chriſt Ieſus, Rom. 8.1. We haue ſeene what Baptiſme is: what it is to be Baptiſed into Chriſt: what into his Death. And ſo much of the Propoſition. Come we now vnto the Conſequence, which I told you was in theſe words: We are buried thē with him by Baptiſme into his Death, that like as Chriſt was raiſed vp frō the dead, by the glory of the Father, ſo we alſo ſhould walke in newneſſe of life.

The Conſequence of our Saviours Death, was our Saviours Reſurrection. and the Conſequence of our Death to Sinne, is our Buriall to Sinne, and Newneſſe of Life. First
concerning Buriall, it was not enough (you know) in our Creed to beleeue of our Saviour Chriſt, that he was Mortuus, Dead; but that he was Sepultus to, Dead and Buried; partly, for that the truth and certainety of his Death might be the better confirm'd vnto vs: partly to make way to his Reſurrection that followed after, for by no meanes could he haue beene ſaid to haue riſen againe, if ſo be he had not beene firſt buried. Now the truth is our Saviour Chriſt ſaw all that while no Act. 2.27. Corruption. It could not bee ſaid of him, as of Ioh. 11.39. Lazarus, that had beene dead fowre daies: but of every Body elſe may it well bee ſaide, how that continually by little and little they moulder away. I will not here with Salomon bid you goe to the Prov. 6 6. Piſmire for example, or with the Prophet Eſay. 1.3. Eſay to the Oxe, and the Aſſe, or with our Saviour himſelfe to the Mat. 6.26. Fowles of Heaven: but go we to the greateſt Prince, to the greateſt Potentate that is, and may we not ſay of him, after hee hath enhabited his Toomb a while, what the Poet Ovid. Meta. l. 12. ſaid of that great Achilles,
Iam cinis eſt: & de tam magno reſtat Achille
Neſcio quid,
ſo we:
Iam cinis eſt: & de tam magno Principe reſtat
Neſcio quid, parvam quod non bene compleat Vrnam?
He is now but Earth and Aſhes, and nothing at all remaining of him, ſaue only a little Modicum, ſcarce an Handful to ſpeake of? Indeed the Body when it goes to the Earth, hath then its whole and entire Proportion, every Part, & Parcell of it, but come we ſome few Yeeres after, perhaps few Moneths, and what ſhall we finde of that Proportion, but forſooth a Bone or two, a little Haire vntrimmed, and a Skull where was a world of Thoughtes, but now are Pſal. 146.3. periſhed. Right ſo it is, or ought to be, with every baptized Chriſtian, when once he is by Baptiſme dead to Sin: he is to be Buried with our Saviour Chriſt, but not to ſee no Corruption, but as other dead Bodies doe, to moulder
every day to Sinne more and more, even as a dead Corps continually waſteth in the Graue, that it may bee ſaid of him as ſpeakes this our Apoſtle immediately before my Rom. 6.2. Text: How ſhall he that is dead to Sin, nay Dead and Buried to it, liue yet therein? And thus much as touching Buriall.

As touching Newneſſe of Life, there is nothing ſo often ſpoken of, throughout the whole Scriptures, as Newneſſe is. It is an Adiunct to moſt things there. We there ſhall read of A New Ier. 31.31. Covenant; A New Rev. 3.12. Ieruſalem; A New Pſal. 33.3. Song; A New Rev. 21.1. Heaven, and a New Earth; New Mark. 2.21. Cloath; New Ver 22. Wine. We ſhal there read of A New Ioh. 3.3. Birth; A New 2. Cor. 5.17. Creature; A New Ezec. 11.19 Heart; A New 1. Cor. 5.7. Lump; New Mark. 16.17. Tongues, and what not? Behold, ſaith the Apoſtle St Paule, all things are become New, 2. Cor. 5.17.
