So may we ſay of this Bread, and ſo may wee ſay of that, whoſever eateth of that Bread, ſhall afterwardes hunger againe, but whoſever eateth of this Bread which our Saviour ſhall giue vnto him (he himſelfe is the Giuer, and he is the Gift too) ſhall never be hungry more, but the Bread that hee ſhall giue him, ſhall bee in him a World of Bread, ſtrengthning both Body and Soule to a Life perpetuall
and everlaſting. Secondly, is Bread good for Medicine? Hath it ſuch an infinite nomber of medicinable Faculties? Doth it mollifie Impoſtumes? Aſſwage Hardnes? Is it of force againſt Rhewmes, and ſo forth? Even ſo our Saviour Chriſt: Firſt, he Mat. 11.29. cures Prides Impoſtume, that which makes vs ſwel ſo much, & thinke ſo mainely of our ſelues, and ſo meanely of our Brethren. Secondly, he cures in vs Hardnes of Heart, that which makes vs ſo vn • enſible of Repentance, & to walke on ſtill, both Daies, & Moneths, and Yeeres in our wickednes. He is the moſt cunning Anatomiſt that ever was, he can take the Ezec. 11.19 Stony Heart out of our Bodies, and place inſteed thereof, a Heart of Fleſh. Thirdly, hee cures our Sinnefull Rhewmes, I meane that perpetuall Flux of Sinne which laſteth in every of vs, as long as this Life doeth laſt. So that when this 1. Cor. 15.54 Corruptible hath put on Incorruption, and this Mortall hath put on Immortality, then ſhall bee brought to paſſe, the ſaying that is written, Death is ſwallowed vp into Victory. O Death, where is thy ſting? O Graue, where is thy Ʋictory? Fourthly, he cures our Bruiſed Places by reaſon of Stripes, and Blowes, ſuch as is likely the Apoſtle St Paul had, when as the 2. Cor. 12.7. Meſſenger of Sathan did buffet him. Laſtly, he cures our Diſlocations, I meane our Mē bers out of ioint, be it an Arme, or an Hand, or a Leg, in not perfourming ſuch Chriſtian offices as every of them ought, or ſhould performed. The Arme in ſtrengthning the Widow, the Orphan, and the Poore, and defending them from wrong. The Hand in giving of them ſuſtenance, and reaching out Almes vnto them. The Legs in comming to Divine Service, & to al ſuch Chriſtian Exerciſes as are vſually perfourmed at the Church. Nay he doth more then all this. Bread cannot reviue the Dead againe: when once a Man is dead, farewell the Medicine of Bread, and a many times before to. Howbeit our Saviour, what he is able to doe in this kinde, and what indeed he doth every day, and how it pleaſeth him to make the Sacrament,
an Earneſt of the ſame, you haue already heard before, nor is it neceſſary now at this time, to make rehearſal of it againe. What hath bin ſaid concerning Meat; may be verified concerning Drinke to, and how our Saviours Bloud is Drinke, and how his Bloud is Drinke indeed, namely, that it hath both the ſeverall Properties that Drinke hath, and a great preheminence aboue it. But I wil end this whole Point with thoſe excellent words of Muſculus. Let vs
Muſc in. Ioh. 6. ſaith he, by the commendation which our Saviour giues to his Fleſh, and to his Bloud, be ſtirred vp to ſeek not the Meate which periſheth, and therefore not the true Meate, but that which remaineth for ever, and is Meate indeed, that feeds vs vnto Life everlaſting. Let dayly experience teach vs now at the length the frailty of worldly things, and let vs remember, that whether we haue them, or haue them not, there is no Truth in them, but only in thoſe heavēly and eternall things we haue by Chriſt. Are we moved with WORLDLIE IOIE? Let vs preſently thinke with our ſelues that that is not true Ioie. Are wee on the other ſide troubled with SORROW? Let it preſently come vnto our mindes, that that that is not true Affliction? Are we delighted with the SWEETNES and VARIETIE of DISHES? Let the faithfull Soule ſay, The Fleſh of Chriſt is Meate indeed, the Bloud of Chriſt is Drinke indeed. Doe GLORIOVS BVILDINGS delight vs? Let vs remember there are in our Fathers Houſe many glorious Manſions indeed, and everlaſting Tabernacles. Doe the VINES deceiue our expectation in not yeelding vs our wonted Fruit? Let vs ſay that Chriſt is the true Ʋine, that never doth deceiue vs, ſo that we continue to abide in him. Laſtly, are we ſummoned hence, and called out of this LIFE? Let vs ſay with Faith vnfained, Chriſt is Life indeed, even the true and everlaſting Life.

And thus, Beloved, haue you heard of the Neceſſity of eating our Saviours Fleſh, and drinking of his Bloud. You haue heard of the Profit, and Commodity of it. You haue
heard the Reaſon as of the Neceſſity, ſo of the Profit, and Commodity to. What remaineth but now at this time, & every time hereafter when as the Sacrament ſhall be adminiſtred, we every of vs endeavour (I meane ſuch as are of lawfull That is, of ſixteene yeeres. The Canons & Conſtitutions Eccleſiaſt. Can. 112. age) to experiment what hath beene ſpoken: even to ſee with our Eies, to looke vpon, and our Hands to handle, that which hitherto hath beene but heard of. And I nothing doubt but a Many at this time will indeed preſent thēſelues to the Receiving of theſe Myſteries, but where Beloved, are ſo Many of vs, or but Halfe of halfe ſo many, when the Sacrament at other times is adminiſtred? Are wee not all of vs ſo few at thoſe times, that to ſpeake in the Eſay. 10.19. Prophet Eſayes Phraſe, even a Childe may tell vs? Is this the Fruit of ſo much Preaching as hath been, and is in our daies? Or as the Aramites 1. King. 20.28. ſaid of old, The Lord is the God of the Mountaines, and not God of the Valleys: ſo our God, is he the God of Eaſter, and not of the other Feſtivals to? Dare wee offer this wrong vnto him, & neglect his holy Teſtament, and nothing feare what may in few Howres hang over our Heads for the ſame? Our Adverſaries the Papiſts, when ever they ſpeake of our Communion, they ſpend Cart-loads of Revilings, & Railings vpon it. They tearme it, Rhem. in 1. Cor. 10.21. A prophane and deteſtable Table. A Table and Cup of Divels, wherein the Divell they ſay, is properly ſerved, and Chriſts Honour (no leſſe then by the Altars of Ieroboam, or any prophane Superſtitious Rites of Gētility) defiled. It is, ſay they, Idolatry, or Sacrilegious Superſtition.
Rhem. in Ioh. 5.20. Calvins Supper, and the Sacrament of Ceres, and Bacchus. Briſtow he Briſtowes Motiues. Motiue. 7. cals it, A Wicked, and a Diveliſh Communion. Biſhop D. Biſh. ſecond Part. of the Reform. of a Cath. Vid. D. Abbots againſt him, Part. 3. p. 363. tearmes it, A cold Breakefaſt of a Morſell of Bread, & Sup of Wine. Harding ſtyles it, D Hard againſt the Apol. Part. 2. Vid. B Iewels Defenſe of the Apol. p. 281. A ſchiſmaticall, mutable, and polluted Communion. Hard. Ib. Vid. B. Iewel p. 328. A new deviſed toy. Hard. Ib. Vid. B. Iewel. p. 321. A peece of Bakers bread, and a Cup of Wine. Hard. Artic. 24. Vid. B. Iewels Defence of the Art. p. 629. A bare peece of Bread not worth a point ſaith hee,
Hard. Againſt the Apol. Part. 2. Vid. B. Iewels Defence of the Apol. p. 320. A leane & carrien Banquet. One Briſtowes Motiues Mot. 7. tels vs of One of his Fellowes that being once at it, ſaw a fowle Blacke Dog to take it evermore at the Miniſters hands, ſtill as he offered it vnto the Communicants. Alas Beloved, how eaſily might all this be retorted vpon their Waſer-Cake, but we can beare it at their hands: Let them aloane Mat. 15.14. ſaith our Saviour, they be the Blind Leaders of the Blind: & he ſpake it of thē, at leaſtwiſe of their Cōſorts that ſaid himſelfe had a Divel to, nay that they Mat. 15.14. knew he had a Divell: but when in ſuch a Sunſhine of the Goſpel amongſt vs, after fifty yeares Preaching and vpwards, the Children of the Marriage Chamber thē ſelues come ſo ſeldome to this Sacrament as that a Many of them could be contented (it ſeemes) to repaire vnto them yeerely, no Contemptum ſolum non vult cibus ille. Aug. Epiſt. 118. That meat can in no wiſe away with contēpt That is, either dayly to be received with out regard, or to be ſtill refuſed vpon pretence of vnworthines, B. Bilſons Difference betweene Chriſt. Sub. Part. 4. p. 536. not Once, that it is that ſtrikes deeper to the very hearts of vs your Miniſters, nay of Religion it ſelfe, then Thouſands of theſe Reproaches brewed firſt by Sathā himſelfe, and broached by theſe Miſcreants. Wherefore as the Apoſtle to the Philip. 2 1. Philippians: If there be any conſolation in Chriſt, if any comfort of Loue, if any fellowſhip of the Spirit, if any compaſſion, and mercy: right ſo ſay I, If any of all theſe, or all of any of theſe, be in any of you, or in you all, If whatſoever elſe be praiſe worthy, and pleaſing vnto God, amend this One Fault of Receiuing but Once a yeere, eſpecially You that be Maiſters, and Mistreſſes of Families, and bereaue not your ſelue, of ſo many Probo ſicut frequentem verbi auditienem, ſic etiam frequentationem C •… D • nicae: quai cum Spiritus Sanctus ſemper ſit efficax in Miniſterio, Elect • inde ſemper magis ac magis, in pietate proſiciunt, & eorum ſalus promovetur. Zanch. in Epiſt ad Epheſ. c. 3. §. 36. I approoue as the often hearing of the Word preached, ſo, often receiving the Sacrament: for ſeeing the Spirit is alwaies effectuall in the Miniſtry, the Elect doubtleſſe doe alwaies profit more and more thereby, and their ſalvation is more ſet forward. Quiſquis frater Dominicis non intereſt Sacramentis, neceſſariò apud Deum Caſtrorism deſerior eſt divinorum. Ambroſ. Ser. 1. p. 275. Bleſſings as often Communicating may yeeld vnto you. Remember what the Councel of Agatha ſaid, They which doe not communicate thrice a yeere let them not be counted Catholiques, or in the nomber of Catholique People. Nor meant it Romane
Catholiques, but good true Catholiques indeed. Remember what the Apoſtle ſaith, As oft as ye drinke it. And againe, As often as yee ſhall eate this Bread, and drinke this Cup. Remember what St Chryſoſtome ſaith: Art thou not worthy to communicate, then art thou not worthy to be preſent at publique Praier. Remember what St Ambroſe ſaith, If ſo be it be daily Food, why doſt thou take it but once a yeere. Remember what St Ambroſe, and St Auſten, both ſay, He that is not worthy to receiue it everie day, is not worthie to receive it once a yeere. Or if Everie Daie be now to often, and not correſpondent to our Times, as it was to the Times they lived in, in regard that Then was a time of Perſecution, and they looked every day to Die, & therefore would they haue this Viaticum, this Voiage-Proviſion with thē, yet remember what our own CHVRCH ſaith, Every Pariſhioner ſhal communicate at the leaſt three times in the yeere, of which Eaſter ſhal be one. Shee is our MOTHER, and ſhee commaundes vs, and ſhee commaundes vs but what is reaſon, and therefore as St Auſten, Aug. in Pſ. 88 p. 682. Quid tibi prodeſt non offenſus Pater, qui offenſam vindicat Matrem, what will it availe thee though thou offend not thy Father, if ſo be thou offend thy Mother, for whoſe ſake hee will puniſh thee no leſſe then for his owne: ſo let vs not thinke Beloved, that all is well ſeeing God himſelfe hath not put this Commaundement in Scripture: true it is, hee no where ſaith the ſelfeſame Syllables, or Words: but he oftentimes ſaith vnto vs, that we ſhould in any hand obey our Mothers, and if the Mothers of our Bodies, how much more our Mother the CHVRCH. 2. Tim. 2.7. Conſider what I ſay, & the Lord giue you vnderſtanding in all things.
div.closer: The ſame Lord ſo bleſſe vs, and the Seed that hath been ſowen, &c.

p.hi:
Da veniam Scriptis, quorum non Gloria nobis Cauſa, ſed Vtilitas, Officium
que ſuit.

div.p:
VVHen at the Feaſt of Pentecost Whit-Sonday. may. 23. 1613. laſt paſt (a Time never hereafter to be forgotten of you) the Lord of Heaven was willing to admit you the firſt time to his Table: it pleaſed his Divine Maieſtie to put it before in your Parents hearts to haue you prepared by me your Paſtor for your better Carriage at that time. I eſteeming it the beſt courſe to begin with the Principles of Religion, made choice of M. Dr Nowels Catechiſme, beſt A catechiſme, or Inſtitution of Chriſtian Religion to be learned of all Youth next after the litle Catechiſme, appointed in the Booke of Common Praier, being an Abridgement of the longeſt Catechiſme, & allowed by the Biſhops of our Land in the yeare 1572. approued of in our Church. Three Parts whereof when we had pervſed, & were come at laſt vnto the Fourth, namely to his handling of the Sacraments, which was the firſt in our intention: after he had told vs that Chriſt ordained but two Sacraments, Baptiſme, and The Supper, he afterwards defind a Sacrament, and told vs what it was: namely, An outward teſtifying of Gods good will, and bountifulneſſe towards vs through Chriſt, by a viſible Signe, repreſēting an inviſible & spirituall grace, by which the Promiſes of God, touching the forgiueneſſe of Sinnes, and eternall Salvation giuen through Chriſt, are as it were ſealed, & the truth of them is more certainely confirmed in our hearts. Secondly, hee ſhewed vnto vs how a Sacrament conſiſted of two Parts, namely, of the Outward Element, or Creature, being a viſible Signe, as alſo of a Grace inviſible. Thirdly, comming to intreat of the SVPPER of the LORD, hee ſhewed vs the order of it out of the Evangeliſts, St Mathew, Marke, and Luke, and out of the Apoſtle St Paul. Fourthly, hee ſhewed vs the Parts of it, which were of two Sorts, the One, earthly, and ſenſible, Bread and Wine: the Other, heavenly, and remooued from all the Senſes, namely, The Body, and Bloud of Chriſt, giuen, taken, eaten, and drunken of the Faithfull, after an heavenly, and ſpirituall manner, but yet verily, and indeed, Fiftly, and Laſtly, hee ſhewed vnto vs what our Dutie was to doe, that we might, come rightly to this Supper, namely, to examine our Selues, which conſiſted in foure Points: Firſt, to repent vs of our Sinnes: Secondly, to ſtay our ſelues, and reſt in a ſure hope of Gods
mercy through Chriſt with a thankfull remembrance of our Redemption purchaſed by his Death: Thirdly, to purpoſe with our ſelues to lead for ever after a godly life: Fourthly, & Laſtly, to beare brotherly loue to our Neighbours, that is, to all Men whatſoever, eſpecially if they be Chriſtians, as we our ſelues are. Thus farre Hee, and thus farre We.

And this might ſeeme ſufficient either for Knowledge, or Practiſe, to the common Sort of Gods People, that come to this Table. Howbeit for I would haue YOV to ſurpaſſe the common Sort, who, or come but ſeldome to this Repaſt, or commonly goe as they come, I haue here ſelected for you diverſe Paſſages out of ſome of our Beſt Writers, as well to hearten you to often comming, as alſo to better your Meditations when ever you come, & goe. Neither meddle I here in this Point, with the diverſe and ſundry Controverſies betwixt the Papiſts and Our ſelues, that perhaps, as it hath done too too much in theſe our daies with a many that come ſo ſeldome, would but dead your Devotion, only with theſe few FRAGMENTS as you ſhall improue your owne Proviſion laid vp formerly in ſtore, ſo ſhall you ſtop the Mouthes of them who vſually giue out, that we hold the BREAD and WINE, to be but bare, and naked Signes.

The Lord of Heaven bleſſe them to you, and as he hath made me vnto Your ſelfe, 1. Cor. 3.6. both a Paul, and an Apollos, that is a Planter, and a Waterer both, a Planter, in that already done, a Waterer in that I now doe: ſo giue Hee the Increaſe himſelfe, that hauing here in this World made you often his Gueſt at this Table, Hee may bring you to the TABLE CELESTIALL, there to ſit (as Mat. 8.11. ſpeakes our Saviour) with Abraham, Iſaac, and Iacob, in the Kingdome of Heaven.

p.q:
〈…〉
•… dued the Waters of the Poole called Betheſda with ſupernaturall vertue to heale, was not ſeene of anie, yet the Time of the Angels Preſence knowne by the troubled motions of the Waters themſelues. The Apoſtles by fiery Tongues which they ſaw, were admoniſhed when the Spirit, which they could not behold, was vpon them. In like manner it is with vs. Christ, and his holy Spirit with al their bleſſed effects, though entring into the Soule of man we are not able to apprehend or expreſſe how, doe notwithſtanding giue notice of the times when they vſe to make their acceſſe, becauſe it pleaſeth Almighty God to communicate by ſenſible meanes thoſe Bleſſings which are incomprehenſible. Mr Hooker. Eccleſ. Pol. l. 1. §. 57. p. 127.

p.label: Calvin 1.
p.q: Sacraments are that thing to vs of God which Meſſengers of ioyful things, or Earneſts in confirming of Bargaines are vnto Men: which doe not of themſelues giue any Grace, but doe tell and ſhew vs, and (as they be Earnests and Tokens) doe ratifie vnto vs thoſe things that are given by the Liberality of God. Calvin. Instit. l. 4 c. 14. §. 17.

p.label: Calvin. 2.
p.q:
Why are not vncoyned and coyned Silver both of one value, ſith they are both one Mettall? Even becauſe the one of them hath nothing but Nature: but when it is ſtamped with a common Marke, then is it made Mony, and receiveth a new Valuation. And ſhall not God bee able to marke his Creatures with his Word, that they may be made Sacraments, which formerly were naked Elements?
Calvin Inſtit. l. 4. c. 14. §. 18.

p.label: Calvin. 3.
p.q: Let this remaine certaine, that there is no other office of the Sacraments then of the Word of God: which is to offer and ſet forth Christ vnto vs, and in him the Treaſures of heavenly Grace: but they availe or profit nothing, but being received by Faith: even as Wine, or Oile, or any other Liquor, though you poure it on largely, yet it will runne beſide, & periſh, vnleſſe the Veſſels mouth be open to receiue it, and the Veſſel though it be wet round about on the outſide, ſhal nevertheleſſe remaine empty, and void within. Calvin Inſtit. l. 4. c. 14 §. 17.

p.label: Calvin. 4.
p.q: Sacraments doe both bring moſt cleere Promiſes, and haue this peculiar more then the VVord, that they liuely repreſent them to vs, as it were painted out in a Table. Calvin Inſtit. l. 4. c. 14. §. 5.

p.label: B. Iuel.
p.q:
We allow the Sacraments of the Church, that is to ſay, certaine holy Signes, and Ceremonies, which Chriſt would we ſhould vſe, that by them hee might ſet before our eies the myſteries of our Salvation, & might more ſtrongly confirme the Faith, which we haue in his Bloud, and might ſeale his Grace in our hearts. And theſe Sacraments together with Tertullian, Origen, Ambroſe, Auguſtine, Ierome, Chryſoſtom, Baſil, Dionyſius, and other Catholique Fathers, wee doe call Figures, Signes, Markes, Badges, Prints, Copies, Fourmes, Seales, Signets, Similitudes, Patterns, Repreſentations, Remembrances, and Memories. And we make no doubt, togither with the ſame Doctours to ſay, that theſe be certaine Viſible Words, Seales of Righteouſnes, and Tokens of Grace.
B. Iuel Apol. c. 10. Diviſ. 1.

p.label: Calvin. 5.
p.q:
St Paul when hee ſpeaketh to the Faithfull, ſo entreateth
of Sacraments, that he includeth the communion of Chriſt in them, and when he ſaith, All yee that are baptiſed haue put on Chriſt. Againe, VVe are all one Body, and one Spirit, which are baptized in Chriſt. But when he ſpeaketh of the wrongfull vſe of Sacraments, he giveth no more to it, then to cold, and void Figures. Calvin. Inſtit. l. 4. c. 14. §. 7.

p.label: B. Bilſon.
p.q: Sacraments of their owne nature, and by their firſt and chiefeſt erection, are Viſible Signes of inviſible Graces; ſo that if they be no Signes, they be no Sacraments: and though the Signes muſt be diligently diſtinguiſhed from the Things, yet for good cauſes in teaching & writing, do the Signes beare the Names of the Things themſelues, whoſe Signes they are. B. Bilſon. True Difference betweene Chriſtian Subiection and Vnchristian Rebellion. Part. 4. p. 561.

div.head: Of the Sacrament of the Supper in particular.

p.label: Mr Hooker
p.q:
IT is on all ſides plainely confeſt: Firſt, that this Sacrament is a true, & a reall participation of Chriſt, who thereby imparteth himſelfe even his whole intire Perſon as a myſtical Head vnto every Soule that receiveth him, and that every ſuch Receiver doth thereby incorporate or vnite himſelfe vnto Chriſt as a myſtical Member of him, yea of them alſo whom he acknowledgeth to be his owne. Secondly, that to whom the Perſon of Chriſt is thus communicated, to them he giveth by the ſame Sacrament his holie Spirit to ſanctifie them, as it ſanctifieth him which is
their Head. Thirdly, that what merit, force, or vertue ſoever there is in his ſacrificed Body, and Bloud, wee freely, fully, and wholy haue it by this Sacrament. Fourthly, that the effect thereof in vs, is a reall Tranſmutation of our Soules, and Bodies, from Sinne to Righteouſneſſe, from Death, & Corruption, to Immortalitie, and Life. Fiftly, that becauſe the Sacrament being of it ſelfe but a corruptible, and earthly Creature, muſt needs bee thought an vnlikely inſtrument to worke ſo admirable effects in man, wee are therefore to reſt our ſelues altogether vpon the ſtrength of his glorious Power who is able, and will bring to paſſe, that the Bread and Cup which hee giueth vs, ſhalbe truely the Thing he promiſeth. Mr Hooker. Eccleſ. Pol. l. 5. §. 67. p. 177.

p.label: Mr Hooker
p.q: Wee grant that theſe holy Myſteries receaued in due manner doe inſtrumentally both make vs partakers of the Grace of that Body, & Bloud, which were giuen for the Life of the World, and beſides alſo impart vnto vs even in true, and reall, though Myſticall maner, the very Perſon of our Lord himſelfe whole, perfit, and intire. Mr Hooker. Eccleſiaſt. Pol. l. 5. §. 67. pag. 177.

p.label: Mr Hooker
p.q: The very letter of the word of Chriſt giueth plain ſecuritie that theſe Myſteries doe as Nayles faſten vs to [our Saviours] very Croſſe, that by them we draw out as touching efficacie, force, and vertue, even the Bloud of his goared Side, in the Wounds of our Redeemer we there dip our Tongues, we are died red both within, and without, our Hunger is ſatisfied, and our Thirſt for ever quenched, they are things wonderful which 〈…〉

〈…〉
•… ming downe into earth, hee hath made a way for vs to goe vp into heaven: that putting vpon him our Mortality, he hath giuen vs his Immortalitie: that taking on him our Weakneſſe, he hath ſtrengthned vs with his Power: that taking our Poverty to himſelfe, he hath conveied his Riches to vs: that taking to him the weight of our Vnrighteouſneſſe wherewith wee were oppreſſed, he hath cloathed vs with his Righteouſneſſe. Of all theſe things we haue ſo full a witneſſing in this Sacrament, that wee muſt certainely determine that Chriſt is truely giuen vs, as if Chriſt himſelfe were ſet preſent before our eyes, and handled with our hands. Calvin. Inſtit. l. 4. c. 17. §. 2. & 3.

p.label: Calvin. 4.
p.q: This rule is alway to be holden of the Godly, that ſo oft as they ſee the Signes ordained of the Lord, they certainely thinke, and perſwade themſelues, that the Truth of the thing ſignified is there preſent. For to what purpoſe ſhould the Lord deliuer to thee into thy hand the Signe of his Body, but to aſſure thee of the true partaking of it? If it bee true that a viſible Signe is giuen vs to ſeale the Gift of an inviſible thing when we receaue the Signe of the Body, let vs no leſſ certainely beleeue that the Body it ſelfe alſo is giuen vs. Calvin. Instit. l. 4. c. 17. §. 10.

p.label: Calvin. 5.
p.q:
They giue me no ſatisfaction at all, who acknowledging that we haue ſome Communiō with Chriſt, yet when they endeavour to expreſſe it, make vs partakers only of the Spirit, without making any mention of Fleſh, and Bloud. As though all thoſe ſpeeches were ſpoken to no purpoſe that his Fleſh is verily Meate, that his Bloud is verely Drinke, that none hath
life but hee that eateth the Fleſh, and drinketh that Bloud, and ſuch other ſayings that belong to the ſame end. Calvin. Instit. l. 4. c. 17. § 7.

p.label: Calvin. 6.
p.q: That moſt neere Fellowſhip whereby wee are coupled with his Fleſh, hee hath yet ſet out with a more glorious Title, when he ſaid that we are Members of his Body, and are of his Bones, and of his Fleſh. At the laſt to declare it to be a matter greater thē al Words, he concludeth his ſaying with an exclamation, This is ſaith he, a great Secret, Epheſ. 5.30. Therefore it ſhould be a point of extreame Madnes, to acknowledge no Communion of the Faithfull with the Fleſh and Bloud of the Lord, which the Apoſtle declareth to be ſo great, that hee had rather wonder at it then expreſſe it. Calvin. Inſtit. l. 4. c. 17. §. 9.

p.label: Sadeel. 1.
p.q: We vſe the word SPIRITVALLY, not that Spiritually ſhould ſignifie that vnto vs which is but fained, & only conſiſteth in opinion: or that which is only inviſible: or that thereby we would convert the Body and Bloud of Chriſt into a Spirit: but we vſe the word Spiritually to ſignifie therby that the Eating of the Fleſh of Chriſt, and the Drinking of his Bloud, is effected by the worke, and operation of the holy Spirit, as alſo that this Miſterie is received by that Faith which the Spirit himſelfe, or the Holy Ghost, doth ingender in our hearts. In a word we therefore vſe this word Spiritually, for becauſe this moſt excellent Food appertained to our ſpirituall, and eternall Life. Sadeel. De Spirit. manducat. Corp. Chriſti. c. 1. p. 218.

p.label: Sadeel. 2.
p.q: By the Name of FAITH in this Miſtery wee vnderſtand not that Faith which is only Hiſtoricall: but that which 〈…〉

〈…〉 we be found the Temples of the Holy Ghoſt, then to iudge, whether we haue had ſuch regard every one to our Building, that the Spirit which dwelleth in vs hath no way beene vexed, moleſted, and grieved. Or if it haue, as no doubt ſometimes it hath by Incredulity, ſometimes by breach of Charity, ſometimes by want of Zeale, ſometimes by Spots of Life, even in the beſt and moſt perfect amongſt vs (for who can ſay, His heart is cleane!) O then to fly vnto God by vnfained Repentance, to fall downe before him in the Humility of our Soules, begging of him whatſoever is needfull to repaire our decaies, before we fall into that deſolation, whereof the Prophet ſpeaketh, ſaying, Thy breach is great like the Sea, who can heale thee, Lament. 2.13. Receiving the Sacrament of the Supper of the Lord after this ſort (you that are Spiritual, iudge what I ſpeake) is not all other Wine like the Water of Marah, being compared to the CVP which we bleſſe? Is not Manna like to Gall, and our BREAD like to Manna? Is there not a Taſt, a Taſt of Chriſt Ieſus in the heart of him that eateth? Doth not hee which drinketh, behold plainely in this Cup, that his Soule is bathed in the Bloud of the Lamb? Mr Hooker. Second Sermon vpon part of St Iude, pag. 38, 39, 40.

p.label: B. Bilſon.
p.q:
God forbid we ſhould deny that the Fleſh & Bloud of Chriſt, are truely preſent, and truly receaued of the Faithfull at the Lords Table. It is the Doctrine that we teach others, and comfort our ſelues with. Wee never doubted but the Truth was preſent with the Signe, and the Spirit with the Sacrament, as Cyprian ſaith: we knowe there could not follow an Operation,
as ſpeakes S. Ambroſe, if there went not a Preſence before. Let the Papiſts ſet aſide their carnall imaginations of Chriſt covered with Accidents, & his Fleſh chammed betweene their teeth, and ſay what they will either of his Inviſible Preſence by Power, & Grace, or of the ſpirituall & effectuall Participation of his Fleſh and Bloud offered, and receaued of the Faithfull by this Sacrament, for the quickning and preſeruing of their Soules and Bodies to eternall life, we ioyne with them: no words ſhall diſpleaſe vs, that any way declare the truth, or force of this Myſterie. B. Bilſon. True Difference betweene Christian Subiect. and vnchriſt. Rebel. Part. 4. p. 631.

p.label: B. Bilſon.
p.q: Since the ſubſtance of the Creatures is not changed, the Signes could not iuſtly beare the Names of the things themſelues, except the vertue, power, and effect of Chriſts Fleſh, and Bloud were annexed to them, and vnited with them after a ſecret & vnſpeakable manner by the working of the holy Ghoſt, in ſuch ſort that whoſoever receaueth the Signe, is vndoubtedly partaker of the Grace offered vnto all, but inioyed onely by thoſe that with Faith and Repentance clenſe the inward Man from that corruption of Fleſh, and Spirit which Chriſt abhorreth. B. Bilſon. True Difference betweene Chriſtian Subiect. & vnchriſt. Rebel. Part. 4. p. 601.

p.label: B. Bilſon.
p.q:
God is wonderfull in this, and all other his Sacraments, not by caſting away Subſtances, & leauing Accidents, but by working that in our hearts by the mighty Power of his Spirit aboue Nature, which the viſible Signes import to our Senſes. B. Bilſon. True
difference betweene Chriſtian Subiect. & vnchriſt. Rebel. Part. 4. p. 668.

p.label: Calvin. 9.
p.q: Wee ſay that Chriſt as well with the outward Signe, as with his Spirit deſcendeth to vs, that hee may truely quicken our Soules with the Subſtance of his Fleſh and of his Bloud. In theſe few wordes hee that perceaueth not to be contained many Myracles, is more then ſenſeleſſe, foraſmuch as there is nothing more beſide Nature, then that Soules ſhould borrow ſpirituall, and heavenly life of the Fleſh which tooke her beginning of the Earth, and which was ſubiect to Death. Nothing is more incredible, then that things diſtant and a ſunder by the whole ſpace of Heauen & Earth, ſhould in ſo great diſtance of Places not onely be conioyned, but alſo vnited, that Souls may receaue Food of the Fleſh of Chriſt. Calvin. Inſtit. l. 4. c. 17. §. 24.

p.label: D. Nowel.
p.q: Chriſt by theſe wordes THIS IS MY BODY, meant that his Body was that ſpirituall Food, & Bread of Life Everlaſting, to vs, being the Members of his Myſticall Body, which the Bread (that is, the bodily Food) is to our naturall Bodies, to the maintaining of them in this temporall life. Yea, & Christs Body is ſo much the truer Bread, and Food, by how much life Everlaſting paſſeth this life preſent. D. Nowel. Confutation of Mr Dormans Diſproofe. p. 165. b.

p.label: Calvin. 10.
p.q:
I exhort the Readers, that they doe not reſtraine the ſenſe of their minde within theſe too narrowe Bounds: but endeavour to riſe vp much higher, then they can by my guiding. For I my ſelfe ſo oft as I ſpeake of this thing, when I haue travailed to ſay all
thinke that I haue yet ſaid but little in reſpect of the Worthineſſe thereof. And although the Minde can doe more in thinking, then the Tongue in expreſſing: yet with greatneſſe of the thing, the Mind alſo is ſurmounted, and overwhelmed. Finally therefore, nothing remaineth, but that I muſt breake forth into admiration of that Mystery, which neither the Mind can ſuffice to thinke of, nor the Tongue to expreſſe. Calvin. Inſtit. l. 4. c. 17. §. 7.

div.head: A Prayer to bee ſaid by vs in our private Cloſſets the ſame Morning we intend to receaue the holy Cōmunion, tranſlated out of French, by a Religious, and Vertuous LADY, at her being in France, in the yeere of our Lord God, 1606.
div.p:
MY God, my Creator, and my Redeemer, JESVS CHRIST, which haſt offered thy ſelfe to God thy Father a Sacrifice pure and immaculate to redeeme Mankind: giue mee grace by the vertue of thy pretious Bloud, the great Price of my Salvation, that this Day, & all the times that I ſhall preſent my ſelfe to thy holy Table, I may with a pure Heart, a ſpotleſſe Thought, and an ardent Zeale receaue this ſo high and ſacred a Benefit. I acknowledge my ſelfe vnworthy to approach vnto this high Myſtery for the infinite number of my great Miſdeeds, but make thou me worthy, ô Lord, I humbly beſeech thee, and giue me participation of thy admirable Vertues, with
the which being filled, I may in a good Conſcience come to thy moſt holy Communion, to the end that it may bee vnto mee Salvation and Life by thy infinite mercy. Heale my Infirmities, waſh my Vncleanenes, il-lighten my Blindnes, & grant, that with all Reverence, Repentance, Loue, Faith, Puritie, & Humilitie, I may be partaker of thy new & eternall Teſtament. Amen.

div.head: Another by way of Thankſgiuing to bee ſaid in like ſort. Taken out of the Practiſe of Pietie, Pag. 773. Edit. 1613. with ſome alteration of it by reaſon of the length there.
div.p:
VVHat ſhall I render vnto thee, O bleſſed Saviour, for all thy Bleſſings, which thou haſt ſo graciouſly beſtowed vpon my Soule? How can I ſufficiently thanke thee for them, when I am not able to expreſſe them? Whē as thou migheſt haue made me a bruit Beaſt, thou madſt mee after thine owne Image. When by Sinne I had loſt, both thine Image, and my ſelfe: thou didſt by thy Spirit renue in me thy Image againe, and redeeme my Soule by thy Bloud: & this Day haſt thou giuen vnto me the Seale and Pledge of my Redemption: nay thou haſt given Thy Selfe vnto mee, ô bleſſed Redeemer. Oh what an ineſtimable Treaſure of Riches, and overflowing Fountaine of Grace hath hee got, who hath gained thee? No man ever touched thee by Faith, but thou didſt heale him by Grace. For thou art
the Author of Salvation, the Remedy of all evills, the Medicine of the Sicke, the Life of the Quicke, & the Reſurrection of the Dead. Seemed it a ſmall matter vnto thee to appoint thy holy Angels to attend vpō ſo Vile & wretched a Creature as I am, but that thou wouldſt enter Thy Selfe into my Soule, there to preſerue, nouriſh, & cheriſh me vnto Life everlaſting! O Lord, what could I more deſire, or what couldſt thou more beſtow vpon me, then to giue me thy Body for Meate, thy Bloud for Drinke, and to lay downe thy Soule for the price of my Redemption? Thou, Lord, endureſt the Paine, and I doe reape the Profit: I received Pardon, and thou didſt beare the Puniſhment. Thy Teares were my Bath, thy Wounds, my Weale, & the Iniustice done to thee, ſatisfied for the Iudgement which was due to me. Thus by thy Birth thou art become my Brother, by thy Death my Ranſom, by thy Mercie my Reward, and by thy Sacrament my Nouriſhment. Now ſeeing it is thy free Grace, and meere Pleaſure, thus to enter, & dwel in my Heart, I would I had, oh God, ſo pure an Heart, as my Heart could wiſh to entertaine thee. And yet who is fit to entertaine thee? Or who though invited, would not chooſe with Mary Magdalen rather to kneele at thy Feete, Luk 7.38. then preſume to ſit with thee at thy Table? Howbeit though I want a pure Heart for thee to dwell in, yet weeping Eies ſhall never be wanting to waſh thy bleſſed Feete, as alſo to lament my hainous Sinnes. And ſeeing that now of thy meere Mercy thou haſt accounted mee (among others thy Choſen) worthy of this vnſpeakeable favour, and ſealed by thy Sacrament the
aſſuraunce of thy Law, and the forgiueneſſe of my Sinnes: O Lord confirme thy favour vnto thy Servant; and ſay of me as Iſaac did of Iacob, Gen. 27.33. I haue bleſſed him, therefore hee ſhalbe bleſsed. 2. Sam. 6.11. And ſeeing it pleaſed thee to bleſſe the Houſe of Obed Edom whil'ſt thy Arke remained in his Houſe: I doubt not but thou wilt much more bleſſe my Soule, and my Body, and all that doth belong vnto me, now that it hath pleaſed thy Maieſty of thine owne good wil to enter vnder my Roofe, & to endeavour there to dwell for ever, and ever. Bleſſe me therefore O Lord, that my Sinnes may wholy be remitted by thy Bloud, my Conſcience ſanctified by thy Spirit, my Minde enlightned by thy Truth, my Heart guided by thy Spirit, and my Will in all things ſubdued to thy bleſſed Will, and Pleaſure. Bleſſe me with all Graces which I want, and increaſe in me thoſe thy Gifts which thou haſt alreadie beſtowed vpon me. Cant. 8.6. Set me as a Seale on thy Heart, and as a Signet vpon thine Arme: & graunt, O Lord, that as thou haſt this Day vouchſafed me this favour to ſit at thy Table, to receiue the Sacrament in thy Houſe of Grace: Luk 22.30. ſo I may hereafter through thy mercy be received to eate & drinke at thy Table in thy Kingdome of Glory, Mat. 8.11. there to ſit downe with Abraham, and Iſaac, and Iacob in the Kingdome of Heaven.

closer.hi: Praiſe, Honour, and Glory, and Power be vnto him that ſitteth vpon the Throne, and vnto the Lamb for evermore.

div.head: WHEREAS SOME MAY BEE DESIrous to ſee the Places in Latine, alleaged before out of Calvin, and Sadeel, and haue not themſelues the Bookes by them, I haue annexed them here, with ſuch Figures as the Engliſh had before, for the more eaſie, & better direction of each to other.

p.label: Calvin. 1.
p.q:
SAcramenta id ſunt nobis à Deo quod ab hominibus rerum laetarum Nuntij, vel Arrhae in Pactis ſanciendis: vtpote quae non à ſe quidem largiantur aliquid Gratiae, ſed renuntient & oſtendant, at
que (vt ſunt Arrhae & Teſſerae) rata apud nos faciant quae divina largitate nobis data ſunt.

p.label: Calvin. 2.
p.q: Cur rude ac ſignatū Argentum non ejuſdem ſunt pretij, quum idem prorſus ſit Metallum? Nempe quia illud nihil habet praeter Naturam: forma publica percuſſum, Nummus fit, & novam taxationē recipit. Et Deus ſuas Creaturas verbo ſuo ſignare non poterit, vt fiant Sacramenta, quae prius nuda erant Elementa?

p.label: Calvin. 3.
p.q: Fixum maneat, non eſſe alias Sacramentorum quàm Verbi Dei Partes: quae ſunt offerre nobis ac proponere Chriſtum, & in eo coeleſtis Gratiae Theſauros: nihil autem conferunt aut proſunt niſi FIDE accepta. Non ſecus ac Vinum, vel Oleum, vel alius liquor quamlibet largè infundas, effluet tamē ac peribit niſi aperto Vaſis ore: Vas autem ipſum vndique perfuſum, inane nihilominus, ac vacuum manebit.

p.label: Calvin. 4.
p.q:
Sacramenta, & Promiſſiones afferunt clariſſimas:
& hoc habens prae Verbo peculiare, quòd eas veluti in Tabula depictas nobis and vivum repreſentant.

p.label: Calvin. 5.
p.q:
Paulus dum apud Fideles verba facit, ſic de Sacramentis diſſerit vt in illis Chriſti communionem includat. Vt quum dicit, Quicun
que baptizati estis, Chriſtum induiſtis. Item, Vnum Corpus, & vnus Spiritus ſumus omnes qui in Christo baptizati ſumus. Quum verò de praepoſtero Sacramentorum vſu loquitur, nihilo plus illis tribuit, quàm frigidis & inanibus Figuris.

p.label: Calvin. 1.
p.q:
Quoniam Myſterium hoc arcanae Chriſti cum pijs vnionis natura incōprehenſibile eſt, figurā ejus & imaginem in ſignis viſibilibus exhibet ad modulū noſtrum aptiſſimis: imo velut datis Arrhis ac Teſseris tam certum nobis facit quàm ſi Oculis cerneretur: quia in craſſiſſimas quaſ
que Mentes haec tam familiaris ſimilitudo penetrat, non ſecus animas Chriſto paſci, quàm Panis & Vinum corporalem vitam ſuſtentant.

p.label: Calvin 2.
p.q:
Quum Panis nobis in Symbolum Corporis Chriſti datur, haec ſtatim concipienda eſt Similitudo: Vt Corporis noſtri Vitam Panis alit, ſuſtinet, tuetur: ita Corpus Chriſti vegetandae ac vivificandae Animae vnicum eſſe Cibum. Quum Vinum in Symbolum Sanguinis propoſitum intuemur: cogitandum quos corpori vſus Vinum afferat, ut eoſdem ſpiritualiter afferri nobis Chriſti Sanguine reputemus: ſunt autem f • vere, reficere, confirmare, exhilarare. Nam ſi ſatis perpendimus
quid nobis ſacroſancti huius Corporis traditio, quid Sanguinis effuſio profuerit: non obſcurè perſpiciemus, haec Panis & Vini Attributa, ſecundum eiuſmodi analogiam, optimè illis erga nos convenire dum nobis communicantur.

p.label: Calvin. 3.
p.q: Magnum fiduciae ac ſuavitatis Fructum ex hoc Sacramento colligere poſſunt piae Animae, quòd teſtimonium habet in vnum corpus nos cum Chriſto coaluiſſe, vt quicquid ipſius eſt, noſtrum vocare liceat. Hinc ſequitur vt nobis ſecurè ſpondere audeamus, Vitam Aeternam noſtram eſſe, cujus ipſe eſt Haeres: nec Regnum Coelorum quò jam ingreſſus eſt, poſſe magis nobis excidere, quàm ipſi: rurſum Peccatis noſtris non poſſe nos damnari, à quorum reatu nos abſolvit quùm ea ſibi imputari voluerit ac ſi ſua eſſent. Haec eſt mirifica commutatio, qua pro immenſa ſua benignitate nobiſcum vſus eſt: quòd Filius Hominis nobiſcum factus, nos ſecum Dei filios fecerit: quòd ſuo in terras deſcenſu, aſcenſum nobis in caelum ſtraverit: quòd accepta noſtra mortalitate, ſuam nobis immortalitatem contulerit: quòd ſuſcepta noſtra imbecillitate, ſuam in nobis virtutem confirmaverit: quòd noſtra in ſe recepta paupertate, ſuam ad nos opulentiam tranſtulerit: quòd recepta ad ſe, qua premebamur injuſtitiae noſtrae mole, ſua nos iuſtitia induerit. Horum omnium adeò ſolidam habemus teſtificationem in hoc Sacramento, vt certò ſtatuendum ſit, verè nobis exhiberi, non ſecus ac ſi CHRISTVS ipſe praeſens aſpectui noſtro objiceretur, ac manibus attrectaretur.

p.label: Calvin. 4.
p.q:
Omnino iſthaec pijs tenenda Regula eſt, vt quoties
Symbola vident à Domino inſtituta, illic rei ſignatae veritatem adeſſe certò cogitent, ac ſibi perſuadeant. Quorſum enim Corporis ſui Symbolum tibi Dominus in manum porrigat, niſi vt de vera ejus participatione te certiorem faciat? Quòd ſi verum eſt praeberi nobis Signum viſibile, ad obſignandam inviſibilis rei donationem: accepto Corporis Symbolo, non minus Corpus etiam ipſum nobis dari certò confidamus.

p.label: Calvin. 5.
p.q:
Ne
que mihi ſatisfaciunt qui nonnullam nobis eſſe cum Chriſto Communionem agnoſcētes, eam dum oſtendere volunt, nos Spiritus modò Participes faciunt, praeterrita Carnis & Sanguinis mentione. Quaſi verò illa omnia de nihilo dicta forent, Carnem eius verè eſſe Cibum, Sanguinem eius verè eſſe Potum: Non habere vitam, niſi qui Carnem illam manducaverit, & Sanguinem biberit: & quae eôdem pertinent.

p.label: Calvin. 6.
p.q: Arctiſſimam illam ſocietatem qua ejus Carni copulamur, ſplendidiore adhuc elogio illuſtravit quum dixit, Nos eſſe membra Corporis eius, ex oſsibus eius, & ex carne eius. Tandem vt rem omnibus verbis maiorem teſtetur, ſermonē exclamatione finit, Magnū (inquit) iſtud Arcanum. Extremae ergo dementiae fuerit, nullam agnoſcere cum Carne & Sanguine Domini Fidelium Cōmunionem: quam tantam eſſe declarat Apoſtolus, vt eam admirari, quàm explicare malit.

p.label: Sadeel. 1.
p.q:
Addimus Vocabulum, SPIRITVALITER, non quòd, Spiritualiter, idem ſit nobis, ac fictitium, & quod in ſola opinione conſiſtit: nec rurſùm id quod eſt tantùm inviſibile: nec etiam quòd Corpus & Sanguinē Chriſti in Spiritum convertere velimus: ſed ita loquimur, eò quòd Manducatio Carnis Chriſti, & Potus
Sanguinis ipſius efficitur operâ SPIRITVS SANCTI, & hoc Myſterium Fide percipitur, quam ipſe Spiritus in animis noſtris ingenerat: deni
que quia praeſtantiſſimū hoc Alimentum pertinet ad vitam ſpiritualem & aeternam.

p.label: Sadeel. 2.
p.q:
Nos in hoc Myſterio, nomine FIDEI, non intelligimus Fidem tantùm hiſtoricam: ſed eam quae amplectitur Promiſsiones Evangelicas in Chriſto, eaſ
que ſibi applicat ad Salutem: ipſum
que
Christum cum ſuis Beneficijs verè apprehendit.

p.label: Calvin. 7.
p.q: Si Solem conſpicimus Radijs in Terram emicantem, ad generandos, fovendos, vegetandos ejus Fructus, ſuam quodammodo Subſtantiam ad eam trajicere: cur inferior Spiritus Chriſti eſſet irradiatio, ad communionem Carnis & Sanguinis ejus in nos traducendam? Qua propter Scriptura, vbi de noſtra cum Chriſto Participatione loquitur, vim eius vniverſam and Spiritum refert. Pro multis tamen vnus locus ſufficiet. Paulus enim ad Romanos Capite octavo, Christum non aliter in nobis quàm per Spiritum ſuum habitare diſſerit: quo tamen illam de qua nunc ſermo eſt Carnis, & Sanguinis, Communionem non tollit, ſed ab vno Spiritu effici docet, vt totum Chriſtum poſſideamus, & habeamus in nobis manentem.

p.label: Calvin. 8.
p.q:
Praecipit Paulus vt probet ſeipſum Homo antequam de hoc Pane edat, aut bibat è Calice. Quo (vt ego quidem interpretor) voluit vnumquemque in ſe deſcendere, & ſecum reputare an interiore cordis fiducia in ſalutem à Chriſto partam recumbat: an oris confeſſione agnoſcat: deinde an ejus exemplo ſeſe Fratribus dare paratus ſit, ac ſe ijs communicare quibiſcum
Chriſtum communem habet: an vt ipſe à Chriſto cenſetur, ita viciſſim Fratres omnes pro Corporis ſui membris habeat: an eos inſtar membrorum ſuorum fovere, tueri, iuvare cupiat. Non quia haec tum Fidei, tum Charitatis Officia nunc perfecta in nobis eſſe poſſint: ſed quia huc nos contendere, & votis omnibus aſpirare oportet, vt inchoatam Fidē magis indies, ac magis augeamus.

p.label: Calvin. 9.
p.q: Dicimus Chriſtum tam externo Symbolo, quàm Spiritu ſuo ad nos deſcēdere, vt verè Subſtantia Carnis ſuae, & Sanguinis ſui animas noſtras vivificet. In his paucis verbis qui non ſentit multa ſubeſſe Miracula, pluſquam ſtupidus eſt: quando nihil magis praeter naturam, quàm vt vitam ſpiritualem & coeleſtem Animae mutuentur à Carne quae originem ſuam è terra accepit, & quae morti fuit ſubiecta. Nihil magis incredibile quàm res toto coeli & terrae ſpatio diſſitas ac remotas, in tanta locorum diſtantia non ſolùm conjungi, ſed vniri, vt alimentum percipiant Animae ex Carne Chriſti.

p.label: Calvin. 10.
p.q:
Lectores hortor, ne intra iſtos nimium anguſtos fines, Mentis ſenſum contineant: ſed multò altius aſſurgere cōtendant, quàm meo ductu poſſint. Nam ego ipſe quoties hac de re ſermo eſt, vbi omnia dicere conatus ſum, parùm adhuc mihi pro ejus dignitate dixiſſe videor. Quanquam autem cogitando Animus plus valet, quam Lingua exprimendo: rei tamen magnitudine ille quo
que vincitur & obruitur. Itaque nihil demùm reſtat niſi vt in eius Myſterij admirationem prorumpam, cui nec Mens planè cogitando, nec Lingua explicando par eſſe poteſt.

div.head: HVSBANDS AND VVIVES.
div.p:
THere are three ſeverall States, and Conditions of Men in the World, in the true Relation whereof, and reſpectiue Carriage on either ſide, the Benefit of Church, & Common-weale, doth much conſiſt: Man, and Wife: Parents, and Children: Maiſters, and Servants. If every Man ſhould loue his Wife, even as our Saviour loved the Church; Wiues againe even as the Church is in ſubiection vnto Chriſt, ſo they would be vnto their Husbands: if Parents would bring vp their Children in inſtruction, and information of the Lord, and bee not bitter vnto them; Children againe would obey their Parents: if Maiſters would doe to their Servants that which is iuſt and equall, knowing that they alſo haue a Maiſter in heaven; Servants againe would be obedient to their Maiſters in all things, not with eie-ſervice as men pleaſers, but in ſingleneſſe of heart fearing God: as we ſhould haue a Church and Commonwealth not to be paralleld againe in the whole world, ſo ſhould that double Vid. B. of Lincolnes Anſwere to a nameleſſe Cath. p. 79. Epiphonema of the Prophet David be truely verified of vs, Pſa. 144.15. Happy are the People that be in ſuch a caſe: yea bleſſed are the People which haue the Lord for their God. Or if ſo bee that be but the Worldlings inſultation of their owne iollity, as Parſons Diſcuſſion p. 185. Parſons endeavours to prooue: then that of the Prophet Moſes, Deut. 33.29, Bleſſed art thou O Iſrael: who
is like vnto thee, O People ſaved by the Lord, the ſhield of thy helpe, and which is the Sword of thy glory? Therfore thine Enemies ſhalbe in ſubiection to thee, and thou ſhalt tread vpon their high places.

Now as in Church, & Common-wealth, ſo were the like obſerved by the like, I meane by Man, and Wife, Parents and Children, Maiſters, and Servants in any one PARISH whatſoever which is a little Church, a little Common-wealth, what an orderly Pariſh ſhould that be? What a Heaven vpon Earth? The knowledge is not great that we haue here on Earth, concerning things that are done in Heaven, notwithſtanding thus much we may aſſure our ſelues that there is a Trinity in Vnity there, ONE that commandeth, Others that obey: God, he is there as a MAISTER, as a FATHER, as a HVSBAND: the bleſſed Angels, and Saints are there to, as his Servants, as his Children, as his Spowſe.

The conſideratiō hereof Right Worſhipfull, & dearely Beloved in our Savior Chriſt hath cauſed me at this time, after ſo many ſeverall Arguments already handled by me, as of our Saviours Nativity, of our Saviours Paſſiō, of our Saviours Reſurrectiō, of the Comming of the Holy Ghoſt, of both the Sacraments, to thinke now of ſome other Matters to be intreated of, for your farther good: and amongſt them, comming to minde theſe three Conditions, & States of Men, to purpoſe with my ſelfe to intreate hereafter of every of them. Firſt then of Man & Wife: hereafter if God will, of Parents, & Children, Maiſters, and Servants. The Text I haue choſen to this purpoſe is in the Foureteenth Chapter of the Proverbs of Salomon, the firſt verſe of that Chapter. The words be theſe;
A wiſe Woman buildeth her Houſe: but the Fooliſh deſtroyeth it with her owne Hands.
Where firſt of all let it not ſeeme ſtrange vnto you that
being to ſpeake of Man and Wife, I haue choſen ſuch a Text wherein the Woman only is ſpoken of: you ſhall ſee how as at the firſt God Gen. 2.22. framed Woman out of Man: ſo ere I haue done with this my Text, I ſhal frame Man here, out of Woman. For if a wiſe Woman build her Houſe, why not a wiſe Man: if a fooliſh Woman deſtroyeth it, why not a fooliſh Man. But of that more hereafter.

Concerning the handling of the words, I will firſt cōſider the Speaker: then the Words themſelues. The Speaker was king Salomon, and who amongſt vs all hath not often times heard of wiſe king Salomon? King Salomon 1. King. 10.23. ſaith the Scripture exceeded all the kings of the earth, both in Riches and Wiſedome. Nay Salomon the 1. King. 3.12. wiſest that ever was, the wiſeſt that ever was to be. The Queene of the South, Mat. 12.42. ſaith our Saviour, came from the vtmoſt parts of the Earth to hear the Wiſedome of Salomon. Shee heard it & admired it. Now if it behooveth vs when a Wiſe man ſpeaks to giue ſpeciall heed vnto him, Shall a wiſe man Iob. 15.2. ſaith Eliphaz, speake words of the Wind? ſhall he dispute with Words not comely, or with talke that is not profitable? How much leſſe when wiſe king Salomon ſpeakes ſo approved for his Wiſedome, I, & regiſtred in the Booke of God, by God himſelfe. Nor yet ſpeakes he here in this place by vertue of that Wiſedome ſo much, as by being the Spoakſ-man of the Holy Ghoſt, the Apoſtle 2. Pet. 1.21. St Peter inſtructing vs, that the Propheſie came not in old time by the will of man: but holy men of God spake as they were mooved by the Holy Ghoſt. So that the Spirit infuſing into him what here he teacheth vs by writing, wee may well ſay of him in this caſe as did Pharaohs Inchanters in an other, Exod. 8.19. Digitus Dei eſt hic: This is the Finger of God. God it is, that here ſpeakes, the Things here ſpoken are Gods words. And ſo I come to the Words themſelues, A wiſe Woman buildeth her Houſe, but the Fooliſh deſtroyeth it with her owne hands.

In which words we haue to note: Firſt, and formoſt, two Sorts of women, Wiſe and Fooliſh: Secondly, the difference
betweene them both here made in regard of their diverſe Actions, the One a Builder, the Other a Deſtroyer: Thirdly, the Manner of her deſtroying who is the Deſtroyer here, it is with her owne Hands. Of every of theſe in their ſeverall order, and Firſt of the two Sorts of Women, Wiſe, and Fooliſh: A wiſe Woman buildeth her Houſe, but the Fooliſh deſtroyeth it with her owne hands.

Firſt for the Name of Womā we ſhall learne in the Book of Geneſis why ſhee was called ſo at firſt. For when the Lord at firſt had made her out of one of Adams Ribs, and afterwards brought her vnto him againe, This now Gen. 2.23. ſaith he, is bone of my bones, and fleſh of my fleſh. Shee ſhalbe called Woman becauſe ſhee was taken out of Man. It is in the Originall
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Iſh and
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Iſha: ſo that as her ſelfe was taken out of Man: ſo was her Perer. in Gen. l. 4. c. 2. v. 23. Name alſo derived from the Name of Man. A kind of agnomination which neither the Engliſh, nor Latine, nor Greeke ſo well expreſſeth. Some like affinity there is in the Latine indeed betweene Vir, and Virago, and ſo the Vulgar tranſlates it, and Tremellius after him. Howbeit Tremellius
Hoc vocabulo vtendum fuit (quamvis non omnino praeſenti loco ſignificatione conveniat) vt conſpiceretur ex parte, Hebraeorum dictionum coniugatio. Tremel. in Gen. 2.23. confeſſeth in his Noat therevpon, that the Tearme Virago is not altogether ſo fit a word, as in very deed it is not. Others would haue it Ʋiriſſa: others, Vira, but theſe are fained Names, ſufficient it is for vs to know that ſhee had her Name from Man, even as if Were it not perhaps for ſome FEW, Women in time might be ſo tearmed. Manna ſhould ſignifie in Engliſh a Woman, and Adam ſhould haue ſaid to the vnderſtanding of vs Engliſh men, This now is bone of my bones, and fleſh of my Fleſh. Shee ſhalbe called MANNA, becauſe ſhe was taken out of Man. But Woman is the Name, and her Name and her ſelfe taken from Man at the firſt, it will be expedient for vs to conſider, how ſhee was not taken or created out of the Gen. 1.20. Waters as the Fowles, and Fiſhes were: nor out of the Ver 24. Earth as the Beaſts, and Cattell were: nor out of the Gen. 2 7. Duſt of the Ground as Adam himſelfe was: but out of the Ver. 21. Subſtance of Man himſelfe, out of his very Fleſh, and very Bone. And here it is not amiſſe to conſider the Manner of her being
made, partly, in reſpect of the word the holy Ghoſt doth vſe in the Original: partly, in reſpect of that part of man whereof ſhe was framed at the firſt. The word vſed in the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Originall doth ſignifie to Build, and Moſes by all likelihood would intimate by that word, that beautifull frame, and feature, that was to be principally in that Sex. What? to make them prowd thereof, as indeed too too many of them haue beene? No: God forbid, but that taking ſpecial knowledge of this their Perfection, they ſhould the rather be guided by the Zeale of Honor, & the Bridle of Shamefaſtneſſe, as one Buoni an Italian his Probl. of Bewty, Probl. 3. ſpeaketh, not to violate ſo vnſpeakable a Treaſure, being aſſured that ſo great a Grace was never giuen them from Heaven to defile with Luxurie, but rather to curb that heat of Concupiſcence, which in their weak Natures would otherwiſe gather ſtrength. Beſides, as the Poet Virg Aen. l. 5. ſaith,
Gratior & pulchro veniens in corpore Virtus:
Veniens .i. Proveniens, nē pe creſcēs. And yet Seneca hath it, Veniens è Corpore virtus. Sen. Ep. l. 9. ep. 1. but I may ſay of him, as hee of Virgil there, Errare mihi viſus eſt qui dixit, vnleſſe the Manuſcript it ſelfe, or the Printer were in fault.
Their Vertues ſhould bee more louely, appearing to the world in ſo louely Bodies, like as Saraes, and Rebeccaes, & Rachels, and Abigayles were, to the admiration of them that knewe them, and their perpetual praiſe in holy Writ.

Concerning that part of Man wherof ſhe was framed, it was (as I ſaid) of the Rib of Man. She was not made of the Foot of Man, that ſo He might thinke to make her his Slaue: nor was ſhe made of the Head of Man, that ſo Shee ſhould thinke to be his Maſter, but made ſhee was of that part which being ſo nigh to his very Heart, what did it intimate but that ever after, ſhe ſhould be his Companion, his Fellow, his Mate. And yet not ſo his Mate, or Fellowe either, as if ſhe ſhould not acknowledge Him her Superiour, nay vnleſſe ſhe acknowledge ſo much, there cannot bee betweene them any Parity at all. The very Heathens that never knewe what God in this caſe ſaid to Gen. 3.16, Eue, ſaw ſo much by the light of Nature, and therefore Martial one of their Poets,
Martial. Epig l. 8. ep. 12. Inferior Matrona ſuo ſit Priſce Marito,
Non
〈…〉

〈…〉 briefe it was thus: A many Gallants at the beſeeging of Ardea, being on a time merry among themſelues, fell every one of them amidſt their talke, in high commendation of his Wife. Wherevpon Collatinus, My Maſters, quoth he, what need many words, we may within few howres make a tryall how my LVCRETIA is farre beyond all yours, and as we find them
Hinc ſciri potuit haud vſquam alibi, quo ſtudio vitam ſuam te abſente exegerit, vbi de improviſo interventum eſt mulieri. Terent. Heaut. Act. 2. Sc. 3. vnawares, ſo let vs iudge of thē accordingly. Agreed ſaith one, agreed ſaith another, and with that they tooke horſe, & as late as it was, to Rome they went, where finding all the reſt of their Wiues goſſipping with one another, and with ſuch as themſelues were, Lucretia they found in the midſt of her Parlour among her Maidens hard at worke. It it as memorable which our Engliſh Story relateth of Queene Catherine the wife of King Henry the Eight, how when both the Cardinals were ſent vnto her about her Divorce, ſhee came out vnto them in her Chamber of Preſence with a Stow in Henry. 8. p. 916. Edit 1600. Skeyne of white thread about her Necke, hauing beene with her Maides at worke too. But to returne vnto my purpoſe.

From the Booke of Exodus, let vs come to the Book of the Proverbs we haue in hand, and from the Tenth Verſe to the Nine and twenteth of the One and thirty Chapter of that Booke, we ſhall find ſo many ſeveral Parcells of Wiſdome required in Women, as that wee ſhall not need to ſeeke elſewhere, for any farther Inſtruction in this kinde. I will briefly runne them over.

VVho, Prov. 31.10. ſaith Salomon, ſhall finde a vertuous VVoman? For Her Price is farre aboue the Pearles. Far aboue Rubies, ſaith our Laſt Tranſlation, but whether Rubies, or Pearles, both are very pretious. Pliny ſpeaking of Pearles, Principium,
Plin. Hiſt. Nat. l. 9. c. 35. ſaith hee, culmen
que omnium rerum pretij Margaritae tenent: The moſt ſoveraigne commoditie throughout the world, are Pearles. Gold is nothing in compariſon of thē. Plin. Ib.
Cleopatra the Queen of Egypt had two that were valued at Thirty Millions a peece, wherof ſhe drank vp one of thē after ſhe had ſteeped it in
vinegar. A Ruby,
Plin. Hiſt. Nat. l. 37. c. 6. ſaith the ſame Pliny, is a Gem, or pretious Stone of an ardent, & fiery colour. They haue their name in Greeke Cap. 7. ſaith he, of the likenes vnto
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Fire, & yet hath Fire no power at all over them. It was the Firſt of thoſe precious Stones that was in Aarons Exod. 28.17 Breſt-plate, and our laſt Tranſlation that renders it in the Text a Sardius, hath in the Margent a Ruby. So likewiſe the Prophet Ezechiel, Thou haſt beene in Eden Ezec. 28.13. ſaith he, the Garden of God, every pretious Stone was in thy Garment, the Ruby, the Topaz, & the Diamond, and ſo forth, where our laſt Tranſlation having Sardius againe in the Text, hath in the Margent againe a Ruby. So that a Vertuous Woman is like this Ruby, ſhe is like theſe precious Pearles, nay her Price is farre aboue them, of much more value, and eſtimation. Now where king Salomon
〈…〉
ſaith, Who ſhall finde a vertuous Woman? We muſt vnderſtand Difficultatem inveniendi, non impoſſibilitatem oportet intelligi. Aug. de Temp. Ser. 217. p. 765. ſaith St Auſten, the Difficulty, not the Impoſſibility of finding her: & king Salomon as hee ſpeaketh of womē, ſo ſome where he ſaith of Men to, Who can find a faithful man, Prov. 20.6. It followeth, Prov. 31.11. The hart of her Husband trusteth in her, and hee ſhall haue no need of ſpoile.

A right good Noat to begin withal, and which wel deſerues the firſt Rancke. Shee was made at firſt for Man, even to be an Help for him, Gen. 2.18, and his Triall of her hath been ſuch, as that he repoſeth now much confidence in her. Be her Husband what be may, he ſhal haue no need of Spoile. If a Magiſtrate, not of Bribes; if a Patron, not of Simony; if a Private man, not of Purloyning; if a Tradſman not of falſe Weights; if a Landlord not of extortion, and oppreſſion, and gryping of Tenants; her Huswyfry ſhalbe ſuch as that ſhe herſelf ſhalbe his Ecclus. 26.3 Treaſure. She will nether deſire to fare more daintily, or to attire her ſelf more ſumptuouſly, then may ſtand with her Huſbands State. It followeth: Prov. 31.12 Shee will doe him good, and not evill, all the daies of hir life.

As was the First Noat, ſo the Second, both concerning
her Husband, by whom we ſhal eaſily know the true temper of his Wife. Shee hath learnt in every thing to endeavour her Husbands profit, nor is it ſaid without good advice, that ſhee will doe him good, and not evill. Shee may yeeld him a many Solaces, and marre them all with one frowne: ſhee may yeeld him much good Milke, and daſh it downe againe with her heeles. The vertuous Matron wil not ſo, but continueth ever Conſtant, ſhee is as obedient and tractable after twenty yeeres triall, as at the day of her Marriage: Shee remembreth her promiſe made him, & that in the face of the whole Communiō Booke in Matrim. Church, of Obeying, Serving, Loving, Honouring, and Keeping him, in Sicknes, and in Health, and of Forſaking all other & Keeping her only vnto him, ſo long as they both ſhall liue. It followeth, Prov. 31.13 Shee ſeeketh Wooll, and Flax, and laboureth cheerely with her Hands.

VVooll, and Flax are the Fewell of Womens Huſwyfry. This vertuous Matron when ſhee muſt haue Cloath, ſhee runnes not alwaies to the Shop, or ſets her Husband vpon the Score, but beginnes with the firſt Elements, Wooll, and Flax. If ſo be ſhee haue them not at home, ſhee procures them by the Penny, and workes vpon them as cheerefully as ſhe earneſtly ſought them out. She ſits not ſtill vntil ſhe ſee them come into her lappe, and if ſhee haue them, ſo: if not, ſhe cares not: nay ſhee ſeekes them, and findes them out, ſhe knoweth the conſequence of Idlenes, namely that it bringeth much evill, Eccleſiaſtic. 33.26. It followeth, Prov. 31.14. She is like the Ships of Merchants: ſhe bringeth her Food from a farre.

That a Ship, and a Woman are like, is an ancient old ieſt in Plautus, and proſecuted by him at large. Nullae magis res duae
Plaut. Poen. Act. 1. Sc. Negotii. ſaith he, plus negotij habent. There are not two things againe in the world, about which there is ſo much adoe. But it is not in thoſe reſpects that our vertuous Matron here is compared with a Ship: nor is it with a Ship, in the ſingular, but with Ships in the plural number.
So our former Tranſlation, ſo our laſt, both intimating vnto vs, that ſhe is as a Navy, rather then a Ship, in regarde of the Wares, and Commodities that ſhe continually brings with her. The Merchant Mr Rob. Wilkinſ. Merch. Roya • p. D. ſaith a worthy Divine, is of all men the most laborious for his life, the moſt adventrous in his labour, the moſt peaceable vpon the Sea, the moſt profitable to the Land, yea the Merchant is the combination, and vnion of Land and Countries. By this we may conceiue what the Ships of Merchants are, & conſequently a good Wife, which yet wil appeare the better by that which followeth in the next verſe, Prov. 31.15. She riſeth while it is yet night, and giveth the Portion to her Houſhold, and the Ordinary to her Maidens.

Medio iam Noctis abactae Curriculo
Virg. Aeneid. l. 8. ſaith the Poet, expulerat Somnum, & ſo likewiſe She. She riſeth, as we ſay, with the Larke, nor is ſhe earely vp, and never the neere, her whole Houſhold findes the benefit of thoſe her early Pains. Some haue their Portion, ſome their Ordinary, whether it be Worke, or Victuals, or both. Both indeed belong to Servants, as well Wages, and Ʋictuals, as Worke, and if the Righteous man regard the Prov. 12.10. Life of his Beast, and indeed ought ſo to doe, how much more precious vnto thē ought their Servants to be, not now as Servants, but aboue Servants, even as Brethren, or Siſters beloved, both in the Fleſh, and in the Spirit, as the Apoſtle St Paul Philem. v. 16 ſpeaketh. It followeth, Prov. 31.16. She conſidereth a Field, and getteth it, and with the fruit of her hands, ſhee planteth a Vineyard.

She is both a Purchaſer, and a Planter, but ſhe is not a Supplanter. She is not as Iezabel was to Naboth. No, God forbid: that were a Iob. 31.11. Wickedneſſe, and Iniquity to bee condemned, as Iob ſpeaketh. Nor gets ſhee a Field firſt, and conſidereth it afterwards, like him in the Luk. 14.18. Goſpell that had bought a Farme, and afterwards went to ſee it, but ſhe firſt conſidereth, and then buyes it. Nor ſpends ſhe her money in Tyres, in Pearles, and Precious Stones, vpon which a many ſet ſo much Ad quae ardent, & inſaniunt ſtudia Matronarum Hieron. ad Demetriad. delight, but on
that which yeeldes her much more profit to the good of her Houſhold, ſo that all what ever ſhee doth, is with reference to them. It followeth: Prov. 31.17. She girdeth her loynes vvith ſtrength, and ſtrengtheneth her Armes.

To gird our Loynes in holy Scripture, ſignifieth moſt commonly a Readynes with all our might, to execute a Charge, or a Duty cōmitted vnto vs. It was the precept of our Saviour, Luk. 12.35. Let your Loynes be girded about, and your Lights burning. So the Apoſtle St Peter, 1. Pet. 1.13. Gird vp the loynes of your mind: be ſober, and truſt perfectly on the grace that is brought vnto you by the Revelation of Ieſus Chriſt. It was the Vid. Calvin in Iob. 12. Conc. 154. maner of that time, and of that Country alſo, to go in long Garments, & when they did ſet forth either to Battel, or to Iourney, they girded vp their Loynes to weild themſelues the better. So Eliſha to Gehazi, Gird thy loynes 2. King 4.29 ſaith he, and take my Staffe in thy hand, and goe thy way: if thou meete any, ſalute him not: and if any ſalute thee, anſwere him not, and lay my Staffe vpon the face of the Childe. So the Lord vnto Iob, Iob. 40.2. Gird vp now thy loynes like a man, I will demande of thee, and declare thou vnto me. So likewiſe our Matron here, ſhe girdeth her Garments about her Loyns that in her houſhold Affaires they prooue no hinderance to her. And foraſmuch as it is not enough, to Pſal. 34 13. eſchew evill, but to doe good alſo: ſhe not only taketh this courſe of Removing all impediments, but She ſtrengthneth her Armes, that is, ſhe is alwaies in action, never idle, according to that of St Ierome, Facito aliquid operis vt te ſemper Diabolus inveniat occupatum. Hieron. ad Ruſt. Bee alwaies a doing ſomewhat that the Divell when he comes to tempt thee, may finde thee ſtill imployed. And againe, Si tantis operū varietatibus fueris occupata, nunquam Dies tibi longi erunt. Hieron. ad Demetriad If thou ſhalt alwaies imploy thy ſelfe with ſuch variety of Workes, the Day will never prooue long, and tedious. Nor doth it indeed to this our Matron, nay it ſeemeth rather over-ſhort, & therfore to the lēgthning of it, ſhe is faine ſometimes to borrow of the Night, according to that which followeth: Prov. 31.18. She feeleth that her merchandiſe is good: her Candle is not put out by night.

The Day, and Night,
Chryſ. ad Pop. Antioch. Hom 9. ſaith St Chryſoſtom, are as it
were two Siſters dividing their Fathers inheritaunce betweene themſelues. And though our Saviour ſay in another ſence, The night commeth when no man can worke, Ioh. 9.4, yet there are that labour night and day, Ecclus. 38.27. So our Matron here in this place: and as I told you before of Lucretia, that ſhee was in the night time at worke with her Maids, right ſo this vertuous Matron here,
Virg. Aen. l. 8. Noctem addens operi, famulaſ
que ad lumina longo
Exercens penſo.
She borrowes of the Night ſome Houres to worke in, and before ſhe goes to Bed ſees her Maidens perfourme their Taske. The cauſe of this her induſtry, is for ſhee ſeeth her Marchandiſe good; She ſoweth not much, and brings in little; eats, but hath not enough; drinkes, but is not filled; cloathes her ſelfe, but is not warme; earneth wages, & puts the wages into a broken bag, as Ag. 1.6. ſpeakes the Prophet: but ſhe is as Gen. 39.3. Ioſeph rather, the Lord makes all that ſhe doth to proſper in her hand. It followeth: Prov. 31.19. Shee putteth her hands to the Wheele, and her hands handle the Spindle.

It was S. Ieroms counſaile to Laeta for bringing vp of her Daughter Paula a Damſell in thoſe daies of Noble Anceſtors: Let her learne,
Diſcat & laenam facere, tenere colum, ponere in gr • mio calathum, rotare fuſum, ſtamina pollice ducere. Hieron. ad Laetam de Inſtit. Filiae. ſaith he, to card Wooll, to hold the Diſtaffe, to haue the Worke-basket in her lap, to reele, and spin. And writing to Demetrias, Be you alwaies carding of wooll,
Habeto lanam ſemper in manibus, vel ſtaminis pollice fila deducito, vel ad torquenda ſubtegmina alveolis fuſa vertantur, aliorum
que neta aut in gl •
bum collige, aut texendo compone. Hieron. ad Demetriad. ſaith he, or be spinning, or weauing, or make your ſelfe Bottomes of that which other folke doe, or make them fit to be ſo made. So our Matron here in this place, She putteth her hands to the Wheele, & her hands handle the Spindle, meane workes a Body would thinke, eſpecially to bee remembred here in this place, and yet you here ſee how it pleaſeth God to ioyne it with Lands and Merchandiſe, accounting it nothing inferior to either of thoſe two in the performāce of our Duties, in regard of a true Vocation. It followeth: Prov. 31.20. She ſtretcheth out her hand to the Poore, and putteth forth her hands to the Needy.

Wee haue already ſeene her Induſtry, in theſe wordes
may we ſee her Faith, and Charitie. Shee relieth not in this caſe vpon her Husbands Bounty, and ſaith, that as for her, She is but vnder Covert Barne. No: ſhee is perſwaded that it ſhall in the latter day bee ſaid aſwell to VVomen, as to Men, Mat. 25.35. I was an hungred, and yee gaue mee meate, I thirſted, and yee gaue me drinke: I was a Stranger, and yee lodged me: I was naked, and yee cloathed me: I was ſicke, and yee viſited me: I was in priſon, and yee came vnto me. Wherein is apparāt, as I ſaid, her Faith to, for ſhe doth not in general tearms, Feed the Hungry, Lodge the Harbourleſſe, Refreſh the Needy, and Cloath the Naked, but ſhee reſtraineth all theſe to her very Faith ſhe hath of our Saviour, for Whoſe ſake, & for his Name, She doth, what ever She doth in this kinde. And ſo our Saviour accepts it too. In a word ſhe is ſuch an one as S. Ierom ſpeaks of, Aurum vſ
que ad annuli ſignaeculum repudians, & magis in ventribus Egenorum, quàm in marſupiis recondens. Hier. ad Principiam. So little enamoured with Gold, as that ſhe refuſeth to weare any Rings vpon her Fingers, and thinks her Gold laid vp better in poore mens Bellies, then in her Bags. She gi •… s and lends, lends and giues with good alacritie, ſometimes Openly, ſometimes In ſecret, & both, as with good Devotion, ſo with good Diſcretion too. Openly; that Others may ſee her Good Works, & glorifie her Father which is in heauen, Mat. 5.16. In ſecret, that her Left Hand may not knowe what her Right Hand doth, Mat. 6.3. It followeth: Prov. 31.21. She feareth not the Snow for her Family: for all her Family is cloathed with Scarlet.

It was the ſaying of the Prophet David: Pſ. 147.16. Hee giueth Snow like wooll, and ſcattereth the hoary Froſt like aſhes. He caſteth forth his yce like morſells, who is able to abide his Froſts? Indeed there is nothing ſo obnoxious to humane Bodies, as is the extremitie of the Ayre in this kind. It is not long ſince that this our owne Countrey, & our Neighbour Countrey of France had ſufficient experience of it. It is true, that Winter Seaſon is not alwaies ſo violent, but be it, as commonly it is, Garments, and Cloathing are moſt neceſſarie. Our Matron it ſeemes provides accordingly, for all her Family is cloathed with Scarlet, or as it
is in the Margent of our laſt Tranſlation, With double Garmēts: that is, as Conrad. Pellican. apud Lavater. in hunc loc. Some interpret, They haue a Garment for Summer, and they haue a Garment for Winter too, nor her Children onely, but her Servants. It followeth: Prov. 31.22 Shee maketh her ſelfe Carpets, fine Linnen, and Purple is her Garment.

She hath for Neceſſitie, and ſhe hath for Ornament too, and all of her owne making Garments, and Ornaments in their nature are things indifferent, we may vſe them, and we may abuſe them. If ſo bee they be too Sumptuous, or aboue our Calling, or we take a Pride in them, ther's the Abuſe, nay there are many Abuſes, for where Pride is there are many. And therefore is it exceeding good, even in the midſt of our Bravery, to thinke of Q. Heſters wordes, which ſhe Eſther. 14. •…
ſpake to God himſelfe: Thou knoweſt al things O Lord. Thou knoweſt my Neceſſitie, for I hate this Token of my Preheminence which I beare vpon my Head, and I abhor it as a Menſtruous Cloath. Notwithſtanding weare it ſhee did, and by reaſon of her place was of Neceſſitie indeed ſo to doe. But you ſee how Proud ſhe was of it: ſhe, even in all her Glory accounted her ſelfe arrayed, ſhall I ſay like a Mat. 6.29. Lilly? and like a Lilly of the Field? No; but like ſome other Flowers. What? and is it vnlawfull then for Women to be ſo attired? Indeed S. Peter ſpeaking of Women, Whoſe apparrelling, 1. Pet. 3.3. ſaith he, let it not be outward, as with broided haire, and Gold put about, or in putting on of apparel: but did he meane it of all VVomen? No doubtleſſe, as a glorious Martyr Arch. Biſh. Cranmer, againſt Tranſubſt. l. 2. c. 12. Or, his Anſw. to Steph. Gard p. 336. Edit. 1580. obſerueth, for that every One muſt be apparelled according to their Conditiō, State, & Degree. His meaning hereby was, ſaith he, cleerely to condemne all Pride, and Exceſſe in apparrell, and to mooue all Women that they ſhould ſtudy to decke their Soules inwardly with all Vertues, and not to bee curious outwardly to decke and adorne their Bodies with Sumptuous Apparel. Like as our Saviour, ſaith hee, when hee wild vs not to lay vp Mat. 6.1 • . Treaſures vpon the Earth, meant not but that worldly 〈…〉

〈…〉 vnto her, We ſhall ſurely die, becauſe we haue ſeene God: If the Lord Iudg. 13.23. Laſt Tranſlat. ſaith ſhe, were pleaſed to kill vs, he would not haue received a burnt offering, and a meate offering at our hands, neither would he haue ſhewed vs all theſe things, nor would as at this time, haue told vs ſuch things as theſe. Honour as it may ſignifie here, that reſpect and eſtimation which is to be given to ſuch in this world, ſo likewiſe may it here ſignifie that glorious and bleſſed eſtate of the Saints in heaven, when they ſhall haue Glory, and Honour, and Peace, Rom. 2.10. And I am ſo much the rather induced to think that this latter alſo may be meāt, for as much as it followeth in the next words, that in the latter Day ſhee ſhall reioice. Whether it be the Latter Day of her Life in particular, concerning which ſhee may ſay with the Apoſtle St Paul, I haue fought a good fight, and haue finiſhed my courſe: I haue kept the Faith. For henceforth is laide vp for me the Crowne of Righteouſnes, which the Lord, the righteous Iudge ſhall giue me at that day, 2. Tim. 4.7: or it be the Latter Day of the World in generall, when ſhe ſhall looke vp, and lift vp her head, for her Redemption draweth neere, Luk. 21.28. It followeth: Prov. 31.26. She openeth her mouth with wiſedome, & the Law of Grace is in her Tongue.

We are nowe come to that P • rt of a Woman which either makes all, or marres all, I meane her TONGVE.
Nobile Lingua bonum, ſi fari in tempore novit: Nobile Lingua malum ſi fari in tempore neſcit. Borbō. Nobile Lingua Bonum, nobile Lingua Malum,
Eſops Beſt Diſh, and Eſops Worſt, that was to be had in all the Eſop. Vit.
Market. That the Tongue is the Beſt Member that Man, or Woman hath, witneſſe that of a Prophet, Pſal. 108.1. O God, my heart is ready, my heart is ready, I will ſing & giue praiſe with the beſt member that I haue: that the Tongue is the Worſt, witnes that of an Apoſtle, which you heard read vnto you this day, Iam. 3.6. The Tongue is Fyer, yea a World of wickednes: ſo is the Tongue ſet among our members, that it defileth the whole Body, and ſetteth on fire the courſe of Nature. And againe, Ver. 8. It is an vnruly Evil, ful of deadly Poyſon. This Fyer, this World of wickednes, this vnruly evill, this deadly
Poyſon is farre from our Matron, as far as the Eaſt is frō the Weſt: She ſpeaketh not except ſhe muſt, and when ſhe Sermo in omnibus moderatus & parcus, et qui neceſſitatem magis loquendi indicet, quam voluntatem. Hieron. ad Celant. needs muſt, no remedy, thē openeth ſhe her Mouth with wiſedome, and the Law of Grace is in her Tongue. Thus Abigail, thus Livia: the Stories are ſomewhat long. The Summe is this: 1. Sam. 25.32. Abigail perſwaded David even in the midſt of Fury, to hold his hand from murthering her ſelfe, and all hers: Livia perſuaded Auguſtus her Husband to forgiue Cinna a Traitour, who afterwardes ever prooved moſt loyall vnto him. It followeth: Prov. 31.27. She overſeeth the vvayes of her Houſhold, and eateth not the Bread of Idleneſſe.
Senec. de Clement. l. 1. c 9. Vid. Xiphilinū ex Dione Nicaeo in Auguſto, p. 75. 76. 77. &c.

It was exceeding well ſaid by
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Aeſch. in Tragoed. cui Tit. Perſae. Citatur a Lavater in hunc loc. Aeſchylus, that the Maiſters Preſence was the Eie of the Houſe: howbeit the Maiſter cannot ſtill be at home, the Miſtreſſe may: in regard whereof ſhee was of old compared to a Tortoiſe that had his Shel, as it were his Houſe, alwaies vpon his Backe. Now, the waies of her Houſhold are ſo diverſe, partly in reſpect of Servants, & thoſe of either Sex, partly in reſpect of Children, and thoſe of either Sex to, that as ſhee had need of Argus his Eies to bee watching in every Corner, ſo of Gyges his Ring beſides, to ſee, and not be ſeene. This doubtleſſe is moſt certaine that if ſhe beſtirre her ſelfe accordingly, neither ſhall ſhee her ſelfe eate the Bread of Idleneſſe, nor ſhall Idleneſſe eate her Bread. It followeth in the laſt place, and is the Vpſhot of all before: Prov. 31.21. Her Children riſe vp, and call her Bleſſed: her Husband alſo ſhal praiſe her ſaying, Ver. 29. Many Daughters haue done vertuouſly, but thou ſurmounteſt them all.

It may ſeeme here ſomewhat ſtrange that it ſhould bee put amongſt Womens Praiſes, that their Children, or Huſbands ſhould praiſe them. It is the Duty of Children to praiſe their Parents, and the Praiſes that Husbands haue given their Wiues, haue prooved ſo Periculoſa eſt omnis viri de vxore ſua lauda • io. Lud. Vives de Offic. Mariti. l. 1. c. 6 p. 128. harmefull to themſelues, that he is but a Novice in Hiſtory, that hath not Examples at his fingers ends. As of Caudaules in Heroditus,
of Collatinus in Herod. l. 1. Livy, whoſe vnſeaſonable Praiſes of their Wiues wrought at length their owne overthrow, Liv. Dec. 1. l. 1 at the leaſt wiſe much woe. It is true, Beloved, ſo they did, howbeit the Praiſes here intimated, they are not of that ſtraine. Firſt the Children riſe vp, and call her Bleſſed, when being come to ſufficient age, they remember not ſo much the long Matri longa decem tulerunt faſtidiae menſes. Virg Eclog. 4 Toyle of Ten Moneths wearyſomneſſe which their Mothers endured for them in their VVomb, as the Benefit of Education their Mothers beſtowed on them, their Fathers dead and gone. And indeed we of this Place, I meane a many of vs, if any Children in the worlde, haue greateſt cauſe of all, to remember this BENEFIT. As touching the bearing of vs in their Ʋ Ʋombs, what is it they ſpecially do, which all Women elſe whatſoever, perfourme not aſwel as they. They all of them beare, & bring into the world (doubtleſſe all Mothers) but our Mothers beſides their Bearing, and Bringing vs into the world, when they haue vowed vs to the Lord, and brought vs hither, and to ſuch like Places, as did 1. Sam. 1.24 Hannah her Samuel to Silo, and themſelues though but Luk. 10.24. Marthaes in reſpect of their owne Vocations, haue notwithſtāding provided for vs even Maries Coyce how are they ever to be bleſſed by vs. Bleſſed by vs in their Liues, bleſſed by vs after their Deathes, & conſequently in their Memories, who (poore Soules) did ſo much for vs, and ſaw ſo ſlender recompence before their Departure hence. It is a golden paſſage which St Auſten hath concerning his Mother, and I doubt not but a many of vs may apply it to our owne. I,
Non praeteribo quicquid mihi Anima parturit de illa famula tua quae me parturivit & Carne, vt in hanc temporalem, & Corde, vt in aeternam lucem renaſcerer. Aug.
